Content: I’ve used Wonderware MES, which is a good for organizations who use Wonderware System Platform.  Recently we have been implementing the 4.0 Solutions MES built on top of Ignition.  I’ve also taken the custom route in .Net / SQL server, but would will always push for COTS solutions first.

Author: ktal90
Content:
> MES is one of the last pieces of software that a manufacturer typically buys.

To this point by @zackscriven above: I think that's true. We've seen a lot of that. We're taking a scaled down approach where companies can start tracking and managing workflow much earlier even without the full-blown MES aspect. It seems to be taking on. I think that coordinating/collaborating between the people actually on the floor is more important to start early than, say, ERP which services finance/accounting purposes. What do you all think?

Author: enterprise4.0dave0488
Content: We develop MES in Ignition, Rockwell, and WonderWare

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content:
> To this point by @zackscriven above: I think that's true. We've seen a lot of that. We're taking a scaled down approach where companies can start tracking and managing workflow much earlier even without the full-blown MES aspect. It seems to be taking on. I think that coordinating/collaborating between the people actually on the floor is more important to start early than, say, ERP which services finance/accounting purposes. What do you all think?
@Karan I agree with this approach when it comes to MES.  It is a good idea to get the 10,000 foot view of what the customer needs early on, but actually execute  in an agile manner where the customer sees functionality much earlier.  We often find that we have to just show the customer what they need with MES rather than wait for the perfect requirement to come along, this speaks to your comment on working with people on the floor earlier. To @zackscriven's point I agree... manufacturers always have an MES, it is just usually on paper or in excel until they get around to implementing it.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: @sqlwalkermj this is a good point and it is the best starting point -- integrators and developers need to simply ask for what they have on paper and use that as the starting point while also adding the value we know they need -- then using agile, build the rest of the requirements as they use their new found knowledge to innovate.

Author: r.pop
Content: My 2 cents: The traditional MES system will disappear as more and more companies adopt an I4.0 mindset. If you leverage the technology that's available correctly, you can accomplish all the tasks of a traditional MES while enabling your organization to be more flexible in its integration. In my previous role, our "MES" system was actually a combination of multiple different pieces of software. Our focus was an open architecture that allowed information to be passed efficiently and automatically, between the entire eco-system. We had two pieces of software at the core, Ignition and Argonaut, and between those two pieces of software, data could flow anywhere in the organization. From pulling down work orders from SAP, to passing SPC data to QMS Pro, to even calling an API in our CMMS system to assign maintenance work orders. In our pitches to our clients now, we generally steer them away from locking in to a single MES solution, but instead to think about identifying a business need, and using technology to solve it.

Author: e0ph
Content: i think that is the rational approach moving forward

Author: e0ph
Content: i have found that a lot of customers are not rational

Author: ktal90
Content: @RemusPop Makes a lot of sense! You see this in the software industry where business process management has emerged from traditional ERP, which fast-moving software companies stray away from now. Rather, bring in the right tools to do the job and have a solid orchestration layer (e.g. business process management) to shuttle the right information at the right time between systems.

Author: rkwadd
Content: @RemusPop Many MES vendors are not really selling software. They are selling expertise and labor to understand, untangle, and document existing business practices. Then *maybe* make some small incremental improvements. But you can’t sell “I’m smart and your mfg ops are an undocumented mess”

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @RemusPop Many MES vendors are not really selling software. They are selling expertise and labor to understand, untangle, and document existing business practices. Then *maybe* make some small incremental improvements. But you can’t sell “I’m smart and your mfg ops are an undocumented mess”
@Russ from the Internet  spot on... automation is uniform, so SCADA software is easy to integrate.  Business processes and manufacturing workflows are never uniform, which why MES is challenging to many.

Author: rkwadd
Content: Hadn’t thought about the uniformity piece. Stuff like ISO 9001 or Toyota Production System try to apply as much uniformity as possible, but generally no one makes or sells those processes as software.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> i think that is the rational approach moving forward
@praetor- you are the brain surgeon -- your client needs you to push, you are the expert -- remember that.  Not every client is ready to innovate, vet your potential clients and only work with the ones who are ready.  Do not get bogged down with a client who isn't ready.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: MES is the ubiquitous term... and it stuck

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: MOM is an expansion of MES features and indicates a specific architecture built around ISA 95... we dont use the term MOM cuz it confuses consumers.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: but MOM is the more appropriate term

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I use MES cuz it doesnt confuse anyone

Author: pjgeldenhuis
Content: @Miro & @Walker Reynolds aligning on the defenition of MES and MOM is probably a good first step. I just do not think a traditional MES system is the way of the future - to monolithic and process centric.

Author: milori2006
Content:
> MOM is an expansion of MES features and indicates a specific architecture built around ISA 95... we dont use the term MOM cuz it confuses consumers.
@Walker Reynolds Yup. Similar thoughts here. Until the point of pitching where in case of presenting the MOM scope , talking about it as MES vs the known by the customer "just-MES" examples.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @Miro & @Walker Reynolds aligning on the defenition of MES and MOM is probably a good first step. I just do not think a traditional MES system is the way of the future - to monolithic and process centric.
@PJG  agree... MES functions are now split between MES software n cloud

Author: milori2006
Content: Would one elaborate more his/her views in what areas MOM adds values vs MES?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> Would one elaborate more his/her views in what areas MOM adds values vs MES?
@Miro MES is about the execution of Manufacturing and generally points to the software providing the functions -- work orders, efficiency calcs, product codes, etc.  MOM generally points to the business processes that make up operations and include quality tracking, track and trace, scheduling, recipe management, etc.  MOM is inclusive of all the processes that go into executing your business, MES is generally just the stuff you see MES software  include in their off the shelf solution.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The answer is nuanced because the original intention with adding the MOM acronym was to create a new layer in the stack above MES and including MES (MES would be a sub-set of MOM) but that didn't take.  MOM is a term that had good intentions but never really took off.  Most people know what MES is, most have never heard of MOM -- even though the term is 35 years old.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I try to stress to people in our field -- keep it simple... remember who we are working with... we don't need to use complicated terms, buzz words or acronyms to sound like we know what we're talking about -- put the vision into terms the consumer can understand. That's the most important point.

Author: jaffar9703
Content: Are there any good examples out there of PLM-ERP-MES integrations?

Author: r.pop
Content:
> Are there any good examples out there of PLM-ERP-MES integrations?
@Jaffar  We used our MES track and trace app to pull the Bill of Materials from Siemens PLM and Work Orders from SAP ERP. This way we could ensure components that are scanned and added to the assembly during manufacturing match the current active work order in SAP, and then at the end of the process we would call a BAPI in SAP to backflush inventory and print rack labels.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> Are there any good examples out there of PLM-ERP-MES integrations?
@Jaffar there are many examples -- @RemusPop gave you a good one, Siemens PLM and SAP integrate nicely because of the relationship between SAP and Siemens.  (I also like that Siemens PLM is headquartered here in Dallas).  I've also integrated with Upchain and Teamcenter.  The biggest challenge is mapping IDs in PLM to IDs in the ERP, we generally do this in the namespace.  PLM integration is rare... and when it is part of the DT initiative, it generally comes late in the process (phase 4 or beyond -- which is generally 2+ yrs in)

Author: jaffar9703
Content:
> @Jaffar  We used our MES track and trace app to pull the Bill of Materials from Siemens PLM and Work Orders from SAP ERP. This way we could ensure components that are scanned and added to the assembly during manufacturing match the current active work order in SAP, and then at the end of the process we would call a BAPI in SAP to backflush inventory and print rack labels.
@RemusPop @Walker Reynolds Thanks Remus and Walker, track and trace is one of the projects we are looking into but with the inclusion of the supplier's system to provide updates on delivery dates and therefore update our in house schedules. This would most likely require setting up API's. We will most likely use Teamcenter to push approved drawings/BOM's into MES and create a feedback loop to raise change requests/non-conformance's etc ... Our ERP/MES is a bespoke system that is rolled up into one, so it makes some things easier. This is just one of the focus areas for our testbed.

Author: r.pop
Content: @Jaffar I would recommend checking out Argonaut. They were our global track and trace providers, and in my opinion, the best software I’ve seen thus far for that type of solution. We deployed them globally in about 15 plants. Easy to configure...no coding required. https://www.redviking.com/what-we-do/digital-manufacturing/software.html

Author: jaffar9703
Content: @RemusPop Thanks Remus, I'll check it out.

Author: francisco.olano
Content:
[Project] I am moving forward with an opportunity of a project to trace every single step on the production workflow, which contains many steps/different production lines/machines:
- Raw Material Lots used
- Part serial number
- Trace in which Production Line was produced and its parameters (the whole process involves around 5 different production lines)

Author: francisco.olano
Content:
I have checked this module on ignition: https://www.sepasoft.com/products/track-trace/ but it seems to be more that the client needs
Any suggestions?

Author: r.pop
Content: @francisco.olano check my recommendation above. We used it to great success to do exactly what you are describing.

Author: francisco.olano
Content:
> @francisco.olano check my recommendation above. We used it to great success to do exactly what you are describing.
@RemusPop Many thanks!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> [Project] I am moving forward with an opportunity of a project to trace every single step on the production workflow, which contains many steps/different production lines/machines:
> - Raw Material Lots used
> - Part serial number
> - Trace in which Production Line was produced and its parameters (the whole process involves around 5 different production lines)
@francisco.olano We have used Sepasoft Track and Trace many times -- it is a good solution, not a great one and does not fit all use cases.  However, when we have selected their module for the solution it has been in scenarios where we are already using Sepasoft OEE and Production Modules AND there are few edge cases for serialized events in the PLC (serial and lots number transitions).  We ended up building our own Track and Trace solution in Ignition that we use if we can't get Sepasoft's tool to work for our use case.  The biggest advantage when using Sepasoft?  Is that it is an Ignition module and it has all of the benefits that come with being a part of that platform.  Overall, its a good solution, a lot more expensive than it should be but it is highly effective in the correct use case.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Why do most system integrators seem to build their own MES Software?

Author: pjgeldenhuis
Content: Does anyone have any experience with POMSnet who can share their thoughts on the software?

Author: .muhammadatif
Content:
> Why do most system integrators seem to build their own MES Software?
@zackscriven good question 
I think Dave grifith and Alex both are  right persons to answer this question. 
Are they both in this community ?

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content:
> Why do most system integrators seem to build their own MES Software?
@zackscriven After you implement a MES you end up with a bunch of code that can easily be re-factored for the next project that comes along. In my experience system integrators will pick an MES platform to extend or develop from the ground up their own features, functions, modules etc... to add value where other systems integrators don't. The value in this case can either be the ability to competitively bid projects or offer additional out of the box functionality some MES platforms do not have.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Filling the gap with their own solutions for their specific customers needs

Author: tiagocouto3995
Content: @zackscriven As the MES is between the ERP and SCADA/DCS, some integrators have coded MES functionalities in the ERP layer (e.g, material handling, barcodes, labels) as well as in the ICS layer (e.g. Batch control, Workflows), so there is a huge amount of hours creating custom scripts to fill the gap when you don’t have a MES software. So the integrators can just re-use their own framework and library. Remember, not all the companies have a MES installed but they definetely have an ICS and ERP. Integrators use to bridge the gap. Nowdays is much easier to buy and deploy a MES system that already has tons of modules and features already tested and validated.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Thank you @Tiago Couto

Author: khalid06148
Content:
MES rarely works as-is out-of-the-box.  It has to be heavily configured for a specific plant.  From my experience, most off-the-shelf MES packages add a hefty "integration" cost (and time) added on to the cost of the software itself, and rightfully so because each plant is different - even within the same industry.  

On the other hand, If an integrator has developed customizable functionality using their own libraries, cutting down on the configuration/integration time, it makes sense for them to offer this solution.  This would be even more lucrative if they offer the source code or at least make the system highly configurable for the owner-operator.

Author: rkwadd
Content: Because an MES implementation is almost always business process consulting and documentation. A huge portion of the value added comes from getting organized to deploy the software as opposed to from the software itself.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Some great replies here -- my response: SCADA is uniform because automation is uniform.  You generally have digital IO and analog IO and they behave the same in every automation project.  MES is not uniform because business processes are not uniform -- not everyone has digital ERP, not everyone uses ISA95, not everyone uses SPC or DQIP, not all processes are linear.  The competitive advantage in manufacturing is found in the business processes, and that is why they are always unique, in one form or another.  Integrators develop their own MES for two reasons -- 1. MES systems are high priced (but easy to build) and they want the profit for themselves

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: 2. Off the shelf systems have gaps in capabilities (their functionality) and integrators want to fill the gap 1 time and re-use it.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: IMO, there exists no complete, off the shelf MES solution.

Author: ferraz3784
Content: Hello everyone! I’ll like to collect some AVEVA (Wonderware) System Platform opinions regarding MES functionalities integration (operations, quality, performance). What is good, what is bad, what are other platforms that can be compared to?

Author: rahulbala
Content:
> Hello everyone! I’ll like to collect some AVEVA (Wonderware) System Platform opinions regarding MES functionalities integration (operations, quality, performance). What is good, what is bad, what are other platforms that can be compared to?
@ferraz +1. We're exploring AVEVA System Platform as well. Would love to hear the community's opinion on it.

Author: r.pop
Content: It’s a decent software package, depending on the application of it, but it’s also very expensive. We did an evaluation and Wonderware was 12x more expensive per plant than the software we ended up using (Ignition).  Every client, every screen, every connection costs extra. In my opinion, you don’t want to limit your scope. Use technology to inspire possibility, and not have to worry about, how many tags your using.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
> Hello everyone! I’ll like to collect some AVEVA (Wonderware) System Platform opinions regarding MES functionalities integration (operations, quality, performance). What is good, what is bad, what are other platforms that can be compared to?
@ferraz The word on the street is that several large Aveva system integrators are doing a lot more with both Ignition and Parsec. The legacy Wonderware stack is expensive, heavy and does not integrate well into other systems. Backwards compatibility is quite good though. Commercially, the relationships the SIs have with the Aveva distributors is somewhat adversarial. Ignition and Parsec support integrators very well.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @ferraz The word on the street is that several large Aveva system integrators are doing a lot more with both Ignition and Parsec. The legacy Wonderware stack is expensive, heavy and does not integrate well into other systems. Backwards compatibility is quite good though. Commercially, the relationships the SIs have with the Aveva distributors is somewhat adversarial. Ignition and Parsec support integrators very well.
@DavidSchultz Ferraz is right -- Aveva is far too expensive, clunky and lacking capabilities in the MES space.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: @ferraz @RemusPop @DavidSchultz --> I agree with everyones opinion here.  For 10 years of my career I worked both a distributor and a system integration company that used Aveva (Wonderware) products heavily. In my opinion System Platform is a powerful product if you architect the solution appropriately. With regards to the MES offering, years ago Wonderware bought a product called Factelligence which became the core MES product replacing Wonderware InTrack. The Performance offering is the strongest of the three modules, easy to implement on top of an existing system platform application and it offers a strong abstraction layer of line state which other solutions don't have. If you want to know more about this look into how the "Utilization Capability Object" is configured. The operations module is very strong from a backend (database) perspective. You can do Material Management, Specification Management, Labor, Bill Of Material, Work Order Management, Routing, Consumption and Production with Traceability, etc.... The difficult part is how these features are configured.  There are literally three different UI's needed depending on the component you are managing. Honestly in the end of most of the implementations done will leverage the API for the configuration and execution transactions. With regards to the Quality module, I have never used it in production I would typically leverage another COTS application like Infinity QS or Northwest Analytics.  In recent years Aveva has moved the MES offering into a "Model Driven" development and deployment system that leverages the Aveva Workflow (Skelta BPM) product. Aveva is coming around on pricing with Aveva Flex and I believe different pricing around clients and IO.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: I will also follow up and say that the go to market Aveva has through distributors causes issues.  There is a grey area where you have Aveva, Distributors and SI's all going after the same business, especially in the MES space.  You don't see this with IA and other vendors, yet 👀

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
> 
> I will also follow up and say that the go to market Aveva has through distributors causes issues.  There is a grey area where you have Aveva, Distributors and SI's all going after the same business, especially in the MES space.  You don't see this with IA and other vendors, yet 👀
> @sqlwalkermj It is a matter of time before the Aveva distributors are eliminated, especially with the OSIsoft acquisition. Many of the owners are close to retirement. A significant portion of distributor revenue is Customer First (support & maintenance). I have heard they are looking at other products/services to offer. I don't see IA changing their market strategy as it was a key part of their business plan.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: @DavidSchultz this is mostly true -- IA has changed their go to market strategy somewhat.  While they still primarily sell through integrators and sell direct, they are testing the channel partner strategy for efficacy and blowback.  They do have a design services arm and they do push to sign large enterprises as corporate accounts (no license revenue for integrators).  IA does keep the most profitable projects for themselves and recommends integrators for projects they either can't or don't want to do themselves.  IA still does it better than Aveva and RA but they are not completely immune to the temptations of the traditional model.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Moreover, their integrator program is not an accurate reflection of who is best at doing ignition projects -- like anything in this business, it is political and strategic.  Again, IA does it better than anyone else, but its not perfect.  "Premier" integrator tells you nothing about the integrator's capabilities, though IA would like to say that it does, it tells you their level of commitment to serving IA's business strategy.  "Premier" means that, as a consultant, you have lost your objectivity and impartiality because you are contractually bound to lead with a specific solution regardless of its level of fitness for the particular solution.  This is right in line with what Aveva and RA does... and is a problem with the way they go to market, IMO.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Whether or not a project is successful or not is often times a function of many variables the average consumer or partner is unable to see or are completely unaware of.  Changing this is painful and politically costly -- which is why the problem lingers.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
> Moreover, their integrator program is not an accurate reflection of who is best at doing ignition projects -- like anything in this business, it is political and strategic.  Again, IA does it better than anyone else, but its not perfect.  "Premier" integrator tells you nothing about the integrator's capabilities, though IA would like to say that it does, it tells you their level of commitment to serving IA's business strategy.  "Premier" means that, as a consultant, you have lost your objectivity and impartiality because you are contractually bound to lead with a specific solution regardless of its level of fitness for the particular solution.  This is right in line with what Aveva and RA does... and is a problem with the way they go to market, IMO.
@Walker Reynolds Thank you for the insight. I completely agree. One of the challenges of working for an Aveva distributor is that regardless of how consultative they are, the solution will always be an Aveva solution. The market is aware and wary of this. If I recall, you addressed this in your Distributor 4.0/SI 4.0 videos as they will recommend the best technology stack for the application, rather than what they sell.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @Walker Reynolds Thank you for the insight. I completely agree. One of the challenges of working for an Aveva distributor is that regardless of how consultative they are, the solution will always be an Aveva solution. The market is aware and wary of this. If I recall, you addressed this in your Distributor 4.0/SI 4.0 videos as they will recommend the best technology stack for the application, rather than what they sell.
@DavidSchultz spot on -- back when I worked for another integrator, a very famous and well respected organization (20xx System Integrator of the year), we had a problem that Ignition was clearly the best solution for -- and it was made very clear that we could not use Ignition, period, or our WW discounts would get pulled.  I spent 8 months trying to turn a moving ship before I jumped and forged my own path.  What surprised me was just how many people out there were frustrated with the same realities I was.

Author: francisco.olano
Content:
Hi All, we have 9 engineers that have just completed the Ignition training + Certification. 2 with Industrial background, 2 with IT background and 5 with software development background
We want to assign them to an internal project as they get more experience, but I think that it could be a good idea if you have an ongoing project that they can collaborate

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: You should develop an internal project that is a test, requires python scripting, tag namespace development, SQL, visualization development -- aim to have it take 40 hours or so.  Give the project to all 9 people and ask them not to consult with one another at all on it.  Then review the results of each project and order your developers in a hierarchy -- highest aptitude to lowest.  You should know how each develops and what their actual capabilities are before you put them on a production Ignition project.  Ignition is a very powerful platform -- with great power comes great responsibility (early dev decisions that go down the wrong road could kill your system later on) -- you need to know who exactly is the most responsible, and you need to prove it empirically.

Author: francisco.olano
Content:
> You should develop an internal project that is a test, requires python scripting, tag namespace development, SQL, visualization development -- aim to have it take 40 hours or so.  Give the project to all 9 people and ask them not to consult with one another at all on it.  Then review the results of each project and order your developers in a hierarchy -- highest aptitude to lowest.  You should know how each develops and what their actual capabilities are before you put them on a production Ignition project.  Ignition is a very powerful platform -- with great power comes great responsibility (early dev decisions that go down the wrong road could kill your system later on) -- you need to know who exactly is the most responsible, and you need to prove it empirically.
@Walker Reynolds Many thanks!

Author: .dhess
Content:
This has been my favorite ICC 2020 Discover Gallery project so far. Don't get me wrong, they are all excellent projects, and have loads of great take-aways and inspirational content.

Project: Arizona Beverages
Project overview excerpts that caught my attention:
"The batch control system directly interfaces with Rockwell Automation’s PhaseManager feature, which provides ISA-88-compliant PLC code within the Studio 5000 Logix Designer programming software. By utilizing PhaseManager, the design of the custom batch control system would require Ignition to interface with the PLC in the same fashion as competing ISA-88-compliant control software packages do. By leveraging PhaseManager and adopting the models and terminology of ISA-88, Vertech ensured that the custom batch control captures the overall spirit of industrial batching."
and
"The Sepasoft MES Web Services Module was used for SAP/MES interfacing, and the Sepasoft OEE 2.0 Module provided functionality for scheduling of batching and packaging work orders..."
https://icc.inductiveautomation.com/discover-gallery-detail/2020/vertech

Author: davem8428
Content: Hello All, this is just a thought to share some thinking. In ISA activity model Product Definition is in MES and sent up to ERP, this has made sense to me logically for a long time as ERP needs to buy the stuff for BOM’s and know operations you cost them but the tight link to where materials are used and to a detailed process flow is in the MES. Does this change when looking forward to PLM where we want to be able to manage the ‘build’ of specs as they evolve through Product Development to commercial manufacture? I see value in having a standards discussion about where the product and process definition lies and to reference this outside of the traditional L4/3 systems, for PLM and also Ind4 enablement

Author: davem8428
Content: When I say standards discussion I really mean updated guidance around Prod+Process specs as this seems to be a barrier currently generally

Author: davem8428
Content: I see this as a major area MES will have to adapt as in a more peer-to-peer Ind4 world if specs are not in MES and/or distributed more widely a core reason for them goes away

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content:
> I see this as a major area MES will have to adapt as in a more peer-to-peer Ind4 world if specs are not in MES and/or distributed more widely a core reason for them goes away
@DaveM Interesting thoughts!  In general I still see it as PLM builds the product BOM, which is translated into an ERP BOM where materials / items are purchased and allocated for manufacturing, and lastly sent to MES for execution.

Author: davem8428
Content: Hello @sqlwalkermj thanks for your reply 🙂 I agree, to evolve specs through PLM and flow into ERP, MES and LIMS etc - we work mostly in Pharma and here is huge value to bring an actual PLM concept into reality. I was referring to product definition not just for BOM but for parameters and limits related to key work instructions, I see benefit to take this out of MES when thinking about PLM as this product specific data causes a knock-on increase in Masterdata in the L3. What do people think of a more object oriented approach by moving the product definition and variables outside of L3 and into PLM and reference it there, systems like MES then can concentrate on process templates around operations/equipment rather than trying to model every eventuality.

Content: Hi everyone, what are your thoughts on OEE calculation: do it all in the PLC by custom coding to save costs and use your current SCADA for interfacing, or implement an MES package that has off the shelve OEE functionality, or use the IoT platform that often also has this functionality build in ?

Author: jmckeon
Content: OEE and how we calculated is a key factor in what we (we as in our community) do and justification for the effort that companies need to implement change. I have a good diagram that explains the calculation in a simple way

Author: jmckeon
Content: Let me dig it out

Author: jmckeon
Content: We need to capture the total time available to work and subtract all the events that take from that time, once capture we focus on reducing those effects that consume the time for systems to do work.

Author: jmckeon
Content: Jan de ...just seeing the other part of your question....

Author: jmckeon
Content: I would not calculate it at the PLC

Author: jmckeon
Content: Depending on the size of the scope (site or multi site) I would do it on the MES level but some customisation maybe required

Author: jmckeon
Content: True OEE needs to have all the variables that impact on the time available to do work and that is everything

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I've generally done OEE within the MES.  The inputs can be both human and machine.  

MES has a lot of information about the theoretical process (e.g., standard rate, scheduling) and quality.  MES also provides an interface to people.  In my experience, decisions about downtime and quality require human involvement.  It's not always immediately clear how to log events as they happen.  It's not uncommon to have to adjust historical log information.  This can be challenging to model, at least with enough detail, at the PLC level.

On balance, I believe quality is the most "expensive" of the three OEE components.  The implications of sorting, rework, shipping defects, material, production, logistics, etc can really erode profitability.  A lot of the QMS business logic and transactions happen at the MES layer.  This obviously can vary by industry or even company.

Author: jmckeon
Content: When designing line solutions or addressing line OEE issue design out the problems or impacts on OEE and do not pass the problem downstream. Many integrated line solutions with multiple OEM's systems have a negative impact on each other when the are integrated as one line as they are not usual purchased with integration at the core but more on individual production functionality.  So once again the "edge" will be to source of data reality and the MES is where it can be realised however integration of all systems or the method of integration and the architecture can also have a big impact on OEE.

Author: jmckeon
Content: Have also calculated large product OEE on the SCADA level...

Author: abram7918
Content: @zackscriven We are standardising on a few MES systems as a first step, which is necessary to respect our technology legacy.  In order to get real benefit you must standardise processes & consequently MES configurations. I think the ideal is an MES that can be engineered centrally & deployed into a local instance. This allows process standardisation & avoids having to build up specialist expertise at every site to do DevOps.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: @Abram this is what most organizations try to do and fail -- primarily because this approach does not account for a key value driver in manufacturing, innovation.  Standardizing locks down processes and makes them less agile -- agility is needed for innovation.  Innovation drives value.  I agree that standardization is key to continuous improvement initiatives, but at the cost of innovation and agility.  Architecture and strategy must account for both.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Isn't this the reason for workflow driven MES? For example, the receipt of material must follow certain rules (quantity verification, quality checks, etc.), but the actual flow of work in a plant may vary. There is some enforcement but latitude still exists for innovation or process improvement.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: My man -- @DavidSchultz he gets it!

Author: abram7918
Content: @DavidSchultz Yes, thats precisely right & is why there is a limit to what / how much / to which depth standardization can be done, & the variability / innovation happens at lower levels. An objective is to build competence & systems that can be centrally managed to some degree to allow benefits to flow to all (particularly smaller) sites where resources may not exist.

Author: davem8428
Content: For companies with large MES deployments already in place, I would suggest to look at No-Code apps to handle the shop floor flexibility needed rather than customise the MES- same applies to LIMS. For central IT teams in corporations they get the standardisation they are after and operators can get digital WI’s that support their detailed and specific processes all without writing or maintaining any custom code. You do have to govern this, and if the no-code config gets as complex as coding then you might be missing functionality in your level3 systems..

Author: davem8428

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Workflow can play an important role in  complex systems. It's easy to fall into the trap of having an action triggered directly from an event, but how do you then orchestrate a chain of actions? What happens if one action fails and you need to reverse earlier actions? This is the role that Workflow can play. Provide a simple, model based method for separating events from the actions that follow. Zeebe.io is a good tool to explore and can be plugged into MQTT

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Thank you for the comments. I think a WF tool is a no-brainer, but I am not aware of many manufacturers using one. It is quite possible I am looking in the wrong places or not asking the right questions. I will definitely check out Zeebe.io.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: @DavidSchultz  I have some experience using Aveva Workflow (now branded as Aveva Work Tasks), but not directly tied into an MES application. The two use-cases involved Alarm Response Management from a SCADA system and using e-forms and workflows to facilitate the approval of process or equipment changes (MOC). I know that the Aveva MES product transitioned to a "model-driven" approach for implementations, which leveraged the Aveva Workflow / Work Tasks application heavily, but I have never implemented in a production environment. My opinion is that a workflow tool can facilitate the execution of business processes around  ERP / SCADA / MES, etc... Most organizations have SOP's and other processes they follow when configuring the systems we implement, the WF tool just provides a way to manage those processes with software. As @GeoffNunan  mentioned "orchestrate a chain of actions"...

Author: .dhess
Content: @DavidSchultz We implement a lot of "Safe Start" rules based interlocking in our process flows to prevent scrap. These can be a combination of business rules, process constraints, such as qual data within SPC six sigma modeling, and equipment state. The checklist can be very long before the Start button gets pressed.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: That is a good question Zack. Actually I'm taking about reasons why a machine is stopped, which can be a fault, idle. We allow for sub categories also and the user choose from a dropdown. PackML for me models this situation in a better way, which might be what @Mr Pal is looking for. It differs modes from states.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: So in producing mode, the ideal state is executing. If the machine is suspended by external reason, then it is idle, if the machine if holding by internal reason, then you'd get a fault code or ask code for the operator

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I recently caught up with a colleague at one of the MES companies.  They mentioned that they have a very important meeting on their product's placement in Gartner Magic Quadrant.  I advised them to not take it too seriously.  I mentioned that forward-thinking and successful professionals that deploy MES don't rely on the MQ.  At best, the MQ is taken with a grain of salt.  At worst, it's absolutely worthless.

I started thinking about @Walker Reynolds' take on the Gartner MQ for IoT platforms in the recent Industry 4.0 keynote video.  The "bifurcation of thought" thesis was spot on.  The vast majority of the products listed were simply not capable of serving as a core technology enabler of digital transformation for Industry 4.0.  They were mostly IT-oriented products that overlooked the realities of industrial technology.

With regards to MES in the MQ, my take is that it's not really worth even competing many of the "leaders".  Many of the products are "solution-centered" and built on overly-acquired / overly-recycled tech.  Second, the manufacturers foolish enough to buy them are probably not worth having as customers.  They'll be at higher risk of project failure and will be challenging to retain.  And, there is a good chance they're not poised to survive.

I'd like to ask this forward-thinking community the following:

In general, what role does the Gartner Magic Quadrant play in your technology strategy and investments?

What has been your experience with the leading products in the MES MQ?  What have you evaluated or used?  Are any your preferred solution?  Why or why not?

Author: michael.brown
Content:
the MQ's have to be viewed through a "transformation lense" as Gartner is not measuring a domains rate of transformation - nor are they trying to re-define the domain (for Gartner thats another revenue stream - i.e. another Quadrant to publish)

So for MES MQ - its simply a measurement of vision over execution in the NON-transformed domain of MES...the MQ for IOT platforms is closer - but it feels like they are trying re-create the same MES type comparison to a new field thats intrinsically not a "PRODUCT" but a set of collaborative services...

Author: springem
Content: SAP MII doesn't inherently support socket communication or MQTT.  They have a software called Plant Connectivity (PCO) that is their solution to extend their integration offering.  It is built on Netweaver as Java.  They have self service dashboard creation and OEE modules built in, but I am finding that we need to custom build almost everything.  SAP is slowly moving to their digital manufacturing cloud (and incites), but we have not investigated that further.  SAP's Manufacturing Execution software is also built on top of MII.  We custom built our own manufacturing database, transactions, and web apps (SAP UI5) that track labor, quality exceptions, rework, work instructions, and print labels using MII, but we are investigating pre-packaged MES solutions that would replace 80-90% of the custom work we have done.

Author: jasperlouage
Content: Thanks @springem. Would you consider SAP MII hard to costumize, or is it a flexible platform?

Author: springem
Content: MII is easy to customize and it is flexible.  You can use it with or without SAP ECC or S/4.  There are built in IDOC, ODATA, and RFC connectors for integrating into SAP's other platforms.  It can require dedicated resources to support and maintain.  We stick away from custom Java development and use their built in workbench to create transactions.  For web development, we use the SAP WEB IDE and have a tomcat connector to test and deploy web changes from their cloud platform.  MII can also connect to several other systems inherently over OLAP, SQL, and several other methods.  We sometimes are our own worst enemy by not considering system impact with some of the changes we implement.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content:
I understand OEE as a tool for first filtering the causes of losses in order to then implement improvement measures within the framework of PDCA in various areas.

So I would say it makes sense to look separately at the time the machine runs without stops to evaluate the suitability of the current automation solution for the planned process.

The graphic implies that the losses are so easy to separate, however, my experience has been that, depending on the use case, the types of losses blur and everyone sees them differently.

Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228974091_Implementation_of_OEE_-_Issues_and_challenges

Author: zackscriven
Content: 💯 Calculating OEE from a machine isn't always black and white with different machines and different people who might categorize an event differently depending on how you look at it.

Author: zackscriven
Content: For example if you stop a machine because it's producing 10% bad parts... Now all of sudden you are dinging machine availability for what in theory is a quality issue.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content: An event-driven system could be used to identify the main cause of failure and to assign secondary failures in order to distinguish between main and secondary failures in the three areas of OEE. That would create transparency. The question remains how complex this would be to implement and how much added value it would offer.

Author: zackscriven
Content: I think flagging the Event and having it come up in downtime is sufficient enough to be able to know what to focus on to fix

If you are not producing...

The simple question is why?

The answer should be: What can we do to solve that problem.

Author: martinjakobsen
Content:
Hi all. 
I am reaching out to the combined knowledge of this community regarding an MES request for a potential client of mine that I would really appreciate some input on. Some contexts: The client is expanding into a new factory and are looking at replacing their existing MES system (MPDV/Hydra) in the new facility. It is a German company that are doing Discrete Manufacturing (like automotive) including both Component fabrication (primarily machines) and Final assembly (primarily manual processes). They use SAP as ERP and does not have a SCADA system. So far, they are happy with the current MES in their Component fabrication, but they don’t feel they get full value from the system in their Final assembly and therefore wants to look into other MES options. We are in the early alignment phase, so I do not know the underlying details of why they are unhappy with the MES in Final assembly. We also, unfortunately, do not have the mandate to talk a BIG IIoT digitalization transformation. So, my question to you guys is: What alternative MES systems would you recommend as good candidates based on above short intro and why do you recommend it?
Thanks

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Martin Jakobsen, you just advanced to level 2!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
First off, assess their existing MES implementation.  A lot of operations will say "product X is no good" without putting a good faith effort into making it work.  Usually, they botched the implementation and never put resources into remediating the problems.  Either the MES did not meet the requirements of the plant/process or there exists a poor culture of management and accountability.  It's easier to shop MES than it is to investigate why an incumbent process is not working.

Did they specifically implement the MES for assembly?  Or, did they try to "fork lift" an implementation from component fabrication for their assembly operation?  Are they using MPDV's module for assembly (i.e., Assembly Manager)?  If they like SAP for ERP, it might be worth exploring SAP's offerings for MES.

I really like Plex for discrete manufacturing.  The serialized inventory, traceability, and quality functionality are very strong.  It's a very operations-friendly product.  It's actually an ERP too. You could potentially pair it with modules to plan and cost the final assembly operations as well.  I'm almost certain they would like this better than MPDV.

Another suggestion is to explore standing up a SCADA to complement and augment the MES.  Many MES products don't scale and scope well for manual assembly because of their interface.  Their interface(s) are designed for a broad market.  They have all sorts of options to run production and process inventory.  For example, they might prompt users for inputs that are same for each cycle.  In the context of a busy workforce running production, this can be a burden.  It's too transactionally "heavy" for the environment.  Consider leveraging a SCADA to streamline the process.  HMI screens could "drive" the MES.  Paired with some light automation (e.g., sensors, conveyors, fixtures, vision), a SCADA could really improve the manual assembly process.  Many make the mistake that automation only means robots or a substitute for labor.

Author: durgakolli2717
Content: Anyone have any experience converting MTConnect raw data from Agent(XML) to Ignition? I know there is a module (Innorobix) that does that but I am trying to parse the XML data using python script. Any input/suggestion would be helpful.!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
No.  I've typically relied on Kepware's MTConnect driver to parse the data coming off the MTConnect Adapters.  KepServerEx can then serve up this data as OPC-UA or MQTT tags to Ignition.

Did you look into the ElementTree Library?
https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC79/Parsing+XML+with+the+Etree+Library

While this does not necessarily answer your question, you might be better off bypassing MTConnect all together.  In my experience, useful MTConnect Adapters are like unicorns.  They don't really exist in the real world.  And when they do exist, the implementations are extremely incomplete.  I'll happily trade an MTConnect adapter for a native protocol with good documentation.  The protocols, despite there being many, were never the problem with getting data out of CNCs.  The problem was always the machine builders.  They either chose not to build out logic for data consumption or to limit (i.e., locked machines, unlabeled registers, incomplete documentation) the ability for others to do so.

CNC machine builders mistakenly believe that their implementation of off-the-shelf control platforms (e.g., Fanuc, Siemens, Mitsubishi) is some sort of unique intellectual property.  It's not at all.  In fact, a lot of it is awful.  It's recycled code from many years ago.  In many cases, it's an example of what not to do.  There is a whole industry of tribal knowledge to sell and service this stuff without any real understanding of how it works.  People don't buy these machines for their controls.  They buy them because of their mechanical design, reliability, economics, and availability.  The sooner machine builders can realize this, the sooner more than a paltry ~5% of machine tools industry-wide will be connected to a network for data collection.  There is not a industry that epitomizes "solution-centered" greater than the machine tools industry.

Author: kennethds.
zackscriven
Content: Pinned a message.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Theoretically, there should be the same set of tags.  In practice, there will not.  If I recall correctly, it does not require much to build a qualified MTConnect Adapter.  It may be limited to a few basic things like Device/Agent Attribute, On, E-Stop, etc.  This is hardly enough for meaningful digital transformation outcomes.  It can be somewhat comical walking through the floors of EMO or IMTS.  There are exhibitors who proudly tout their MTConnect support, but they barely expose any information in their adapter.

MTConnect Adapter implementations vary by machine builder.  Additionally, they can vary by model.  This is often a function of an asset's native namespace and what was elected to be abstracted.  If the machine builder leverages one of the major CNC automation platforms (e.g., Fanuc, Siemens, Mitsubishi) and follows the reference architecture (i.e., similar implemented namespace), the generic MTConnect Adapters can sometimes provide more data.

I don't have experience building out MTConnect drivers.  I can only bring up what I've observed with the Adapters and Agents.  As for schema, you're probably in good shape if you follow the MTConnect spec first.  There are XML Schema Definition files on the MTConnect Institute site.  Compare these to the Device Doc coming off the Agent(s).  Hopefully, there should not be much variation in schema among Adapters for different makes/models.  The two things I would look out for are versioning and data types.  While likely similar, not all agents are running the same version schema.  Elements have been deprecated or replaced.  Watch the header.  Additionally, data types can be ambiguous as they are implicitly defined by DataItem Categories (samples = numerical, events = discrete).  If an unrecognized tag (i.e., DataItem Type) shows up or something is encoded incorrectly, your parser will need to know how interpret it.  Ideally, the parser should first consume the Device Doc as a basis of interpreting the Stream Doc.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Out of curiosity, what adapter are you using for Muratec?  Is this a third-party adapter or is it generic Fanuc one?  I have not encountered anything from Muratec out of the US or Japan.

Everything I've seen involving Muratec involves the native Fanuc protocol (i.e., FOCAS) or EtherNet/IP. 

Muratec is notoriously challenging to build a useful namespace out of. They have a peculiar way of organizing memory. Mixed endianness.  Poor documentation. There is a lot encoded and inaccessible in the C level. There are hundreds or even thousands of alarms dumped to one bit and the messages are passed as strings to the HMI, but it’s not really possible to segment or monitor them.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
That sounds about right.  On the other hand, some of the solutions represented here were not on this list years ago.  They may have had viable enterprise functionality, but not enough customers with large enterprise deployments.

Many ERP and MES survey results in these reports are skewed by M&A activity among manufacturers in recent years.  If private equity is involved and an exit is imminent, the firm may elect to live with its disparate systems at each site.  Or, their sites may be in different industry verticals or localities that make standardizing on one solution challenging.  Additionally, when an organization does opt to expand an enterprise deployment, they tend to steer towards the more established offerings.  The focus hones in on low risk objectives (e.g., global sales/support presence, bare minimum functionality, reporting, minimize redundant investments) rather than specific functionality to optimize the operation of the sites.  The perceived niche solutions tend to get replaced and, hence, squeezed out from market analyses.

Here's a practical example.  Suppose a conglomerate or manufacturer acquires a mid-size manufacturer in the US running Sepasoft.  Suppose there are other holdings in Europe running MPDV and in Asia running Oracle.  They also have existing investments in Siemens for SCADA.  Additionally, all sites happen to use Dassault for CAD/PLM and SAP for ERP.  What's a CIO pressured for technology cost-cutting to do?  The acquisition's goal was to obtain access to a new market / kill a competitor and cut out redundancies.  They take inventory of everything.  They look at Sepasoft.  They perceive it as another SCADA (being an Ignition module) and there exist fresh WinCC deployments at other sites.  They also can't find anyone who has successfully implemented and localized Sepasoft in Asia.  They quickly decide to replace Sepasoft.  They meet with Dassault, SAP, and Siemens.  Dassault, SAP, or Siemens make an offer they cannot refuse.

Author: alenduranovic
Content: Hello people! Has anyone had any experience in structuring a database according to B2MML implementation of ISA95? I wonder which models should be defined as tables and which as UDTs?

Author: michael.brown
Content: There's no fixed rule to answer this question. It's completely based on the usecase/outcome of the data. Example - If I'm extracting BOMs out of teamcenter for use in a realtime dashboard - I would have a schema for the BOM and a UDT for the machining centers that's processing the WIP. VS if I just wanted to monitor the machining centers and include the context of the PART being worked - I'd extract only the required B2MML XML fields and put them in a CurrentPart UDT.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: @Michael Brown makes  a great point, this is one of those "it depends" questions driven by the requirements.  I always have viewed B2MML as a starting point for how certain aspects of an MES / MOM system should be structured in the backend. While traditionally I have always viewed the PLC / Edge ("UDT's") as a place for current state,   recently I have come across use cases where contextual and historical data sets may be valid to live in both the database as the system of record and in a UDT of some sort for immediate contextual information for streaming to the UNS / Directly to Cloud / Edge Computing Device, etc...

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I've never heard of Trackhound.  I'll have to check it out.

I noticed that Trackhound's Adapter for Fanuc only support 0i and 30i controllers.  Most Murata machines I've encountered have been larger MW series lathes.  They had 18i, 32i-A, and 32i-B controllers depending on their age.  Outside of additional features and axis of motion, I don't know the differences between these controllers and the 0i.  I'm not sure how the registers (aka namespace) would vary from controller-to-controller.

My understanding of most generic MTConnect Adapters for Fanuc controllers is that they scan the F and G registers through the FOCAS Ethernet interface.  The F registers are outputs (commands) from the CNC to PMC.  The G registers are inputs (feedback) from the PMC to the CNC.  This is where most of the standard Fanuc motion control functionality for machining reside.  Most machine builders will use some of this functionality, but not all of it.  Thus, it's common for MTConnect adapters to have missing data.  What data is present is a function of their implementation of Fanuc.  For example, there might be information information present about the main spindles, but not the tooling or workholding.  

To my knowledge, Murata does not have a native MTConnect Adapter and Agent.  There is not an option of selecting what and where the data is published.  The generic MTConnect Adapter will have Fanuc FOCAS addresses (e.g., statinfo_run, F1000.1, G1234) hardcoded in to poll the controller and the publish into the Agent's schema.  The only way to change what is present in the schema is to change the Adapter.  I noticed Trackhound's Adapter was on Github, but it appeared to be compiled.  I didn't see anything that appeared to call up the FOCAS namespace.  You could try modifying one of the other MTConnect adapters.

To change what the agent publishes (i.e., MTConnect namespace), it will requiring changing the adapter looks for in the Fanuc memory tables (i.e., Murata namespace).

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Murata lathes are pretty complex.  Their approach to gantry robots, tool turrets, workholding, etc is unique.  Functionality that one would expect to see in the F, G, or D tables on other machines are in the R tables on a Murata.  A lot of logic is not run in the ladder ("PMC"), but from the lesser-known C language executor.

Murata and maybe Makino have the some of the most complicated namespaces.  The good news is that Murata's programs are fairly consistent from model to model.  So, once you learn something for one asset, there's a good chance it will be applicable to others.

If I get some time over the next few weeks, I'll have someone run a test on a Murata with the Trackhound Adapter.  I'm curious what the Adapter, built for 0i and 30i controllers, would pick up.  Most of what I have access to would be 32i series controllers.

Also using kepserver with FOCAS would give the required machine data that we need or are there any hiccups?  The way I see when we connect kepserver with focas. should be able to  browse almost all of the CNC tags. Is that correct?

Author: lenzo202
Content: Anyone know where planned downtime is captured if not in OEE? How do you know how effectivly you're scheduling downtime?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
You're right.  Planned downtime is generally omitted from the availability ratio of OEE.  This is good because the metric is designed to indicate intentional efficiency of an asset.  This is bad because intention can be continuously redefined.  One of the downfalls of OEE is that planned downtime is modeled as "free" and anyone can quickly redefine downtime as planned.   Most OEE implementations implicitly model planned downtime (or off) as the simple inverse of running or unplanned downtime.  In practice, this can turn planned downtime into an abused catch-all for "this doesn't count".  In the real world, capacity is finite and assets must achieve certain levels of availability to be economically viable.  Downtime is downtime and it has a cost.

There are ways to introduce planned downtime into OEE by using a schedule as a constraint.  It works well in environments with capacity planning issues or poor execution of planned downtime activities.  Examples might include excessively long setups / changeovers or maintenance activity. This technique requires planned downtime to be explicitly defined in the scheduling process.  Any planned downtime activity that occurs outside of its schedule is classified as a form of a unplanned downtime.  So, when availability numbers are low, it's clear that there is a problem with "unplanned" planned down activities.  This would be implemented by having the OEE logic source planned production time from a schedule rather than derived from an asset state log.

Another indicator can be normalizing planned downtime hours against running hours or cycles.  This provides visibility into the level of relative planned maintenance activity over time.

Content: Thanks for the detailed response. That makes sense. Ive seen some companys  hide real downtime in things like exsesivly long change overs. It always confused me as there is capacity to be gained by shortening those durations even if they are planned. Putting the oweness on operations to actually plan planned downtime sounds like a good first step for situations like this.

Author: patjdixon
Content: I have seen presentations that say at the MES layer no inbound ports (from upper level to lower level) should be enabled.  Then how does Batchmaster work?  Isn't the idea to have realtime data go both ways so that orders go from level 5 to level 1?

Author: mparris
Content:
I'm not familiar with Batchmaster, but will speak to how MQTT helps here.

Inbound ports is applicable with firewalls, so if there is a PC on level 1, the tradition is that the firewall on that PC should block all traffic that is initialed externally. So if a user is trying to ping or access the list of files shared of three PC, the firewall drops these requests. This policy significantly reduces a hacker's attack surface.

When using MQTT, the Level1 PC initiates the connection to the broker as a client. So from the perspective of the firewall on that PC, that MQTT connection request is outbound. Modern firewalls are stateful, meaning when the PC's firewall detects this  outbound connection request, it will allow inbound traffic that is associated with that TCP session. For example, the PC initiates connection to the broker and the broker responds to acknowledge the connection, a stateful firewall is typically configured by default to allow that inbound response even if its inbound policy is to drop all inbound (initiated) traffic.

Then when it comes to data after the connection is made, such as an MQTT subscription to a topic representing what the order to be processed is, the firewall will allow that data too, since it's still part of the original connection.

This is largely why MQTT fits in nicely with security policies, since to get data to the lower level devices did not require a special exception to the device firewall. Walker refers to this characteristic as"edge-driven" and is one of his 4 requirements of an IIoT architecture.

All that to say, if Batchmaster supports MQTT, then that is how you could maintain blocking inbound connections and still get data to the lower levels.

Content: Is anyone using, or considering, a cloud based MES? What are the pros and cons?

Author: mparris
Content:
Cloud based MES?
🤪 

It's hard to imagine the benefits compared to the risk of uncontrolled downtime due to all the infrastructure between the factory and the cloud.

When you hear stories of cloud providers having routers shared with other tenants and the other tenant takes down the router due to some misconfiguration, and then you have to prove to the cloud provider that the problem is on their end... It's not so appealing anymore.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It appears TEEP is a cleaner way of doing it as scheduling utilization is a component.  This is a newer concept for me.

Regarding OEE, I was introducing the concept of "scheduled" vs "unscheduled" planned downtime.  Let's use the concept of maintenance or change overs.  Suppose they're not being managed well and are consistently going over schedule.  It's eating into capacity.  This downtime activity that occurs outside the production schedule would not impact availability.  However, this downtime activity that runs into production schedule would.  It would be classified as a form of unplanned downtime like "unscheduled PM" or "unscheduled change over".  Unplanned downtime reporting does not have to have one classification.  It's possible to have tiered attributes attributes to define events.  These attributes can, of course, be filtered.

Here's a more concrete example.  Suppose a workcenter is scheduled to be down for engineering trials for 12 hours and is scheduled to run production for 12 hours.  But, the engineering trials actually ran for 13 hours.  The workcenter resumed production 1 hour into its schedule.  This is lost time that can't be made up without additional cost.  So, over a 24 hour period, the workcenter's log would have entries for 12 hours of engineering trials (planned downtime), 1 hour of unscheduled engineering trials (unplanned downtime), and 11 hours of production (uptime).  The availability figure would be negatively impacted by one hour.

The benefit of this approach is that it penalizes planned downtime activity that happens outside of its schedule.  Because the OEE models planned downtime as "free", it gets abused.  It can lead to problem of high OEE numbers but low gross output.  Running well when running is not necessarily the same as running well as scheduled.

Author: Deleted User
Content: Not sure I follow what you are saying in your concrete example. I would expect OEE to take a one-hour hit in that instance. Overruns should be counted as unplanned, right?

Author: Deleted User
Content: I would agree with you. However I have a couple of Scandinavian customers that are talking 'cloud first' for everything. And there are some cloud MES vendors out there (here's an example - https://cloudbasedmes.com/). The risk of comms-loss and latency issues would make me very wary.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Correct.  When the OEE numbers are reviewed, it would be clear that the reason availability was not 100% was because engineering prevented one hour of production.  The action would not be to invest in maintenance resources, but engineering resources to conduct trials on schedule.  So, instead of the plant patting themselves on the back that they had 100% uptime (12/12), it would actually be ~92% uptime (11/12).  Engineering would be held accountable for that ~8% deficit.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Setting aside data governance issues, I believe most performance and security concerns of cloud are overstated.  Everything from global airline reservation systems, stock exchanges, and national medical systems have been successfully deployed in the cloud.  These services are on the same level of criticality as an MES.

Yes, the cloud introduces new risks to manage, but many of those can be mitigated and their costs can be offset with benefits.  Many manufacturers take a “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” mindset to their apps and slowly decay into irrelevance.  Even when they host it, they barely enhance or upgrade it.  At some point, the decade (or two) of stagnation offsets any perceived benefits of stability.

Worried about availability?  It’s hard to beat redundant hardware and redundant data centers.  Worried about disruptions from the public cloud?  Bypass it and use more dedicated resources.  Worried about connectivity?  Use diverse fiber, backbone carriers, SD-WAN, BGP, MPLS, etc.  Worried about downtime?  Forge an SLA, develop an outage protocol and leverage store-and-forward at the edge.  Worried about security and compliance?  The provider’s SOC reports will rival what most organizations can offer and attest internally.

Cloud is not a hard-and-fast rule, but it’s always worth considering.   It’s not appropriate for all manufacturers.  At the very least, it’s an intellectual exercise that will cause one to reexamine architectural habits and traditions.  When one tries to lift-and-shift to the cloud, they usually are either unsuccessful or they don’t reap the full benefits.  Whether it’s SaaS or IaaS, cloud is different infrastructure and requires a different approach.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: As to your original question, yes.  I’m a big fan of Plex’s MES modules.  Plex has been doing cloud about as long as Salesforce and Netsuite (~20 years).  The traceability and quality functionality very strong.  It’s not an MES for every process, but it’s certainly performant.  In most cases, functionality will drive selection before performance does.  I’ve seen it do everything from deep lot management to large BOM assembly to ultra-fast production processes.  The real limiting performance factor are the stored procedures in the database.  Optimizing API calls goes a long way.  Most implementations I’ve seen in North America can ping the datacenters between 6ms and 40ms.  It works well overseas.  The largest complaint is that, to preserve performance, one cannot execute their own unapproved queries on the production databases.  They must use an API or query on the reporting databases.  This is not necessarily a bad thing and not unheard of in on-prem applications.  It's probably not a good idea to "SELECT *" on a live MES database anyways.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Here are the pros and cons of cloud MES…

Pros:  It’s remarkably fast to deploy.  All customers are running their application on the same code base.  Instead of supporting a sea of disparate versions and customizations, the vendor can better support and enhance the product.  This makes issues easier to reproduce and, hence, fix.  With SaaS, the vendor has more of an incentive to maintain their product to retain their customers.  The whole ecosystem (e.g., vendor, partners, customers) tends to be more collaborative and drive more innovation.  

Cons:  You're married to the vendor.  That's the case with on-prem too, but you're really married when it's cloud SaaS.  There are much more limitations in what can be customized.  You’re at the mercy of the product roadmap.  If it's not common functionality or something beyond what is typically done in the targeted industry verticals, you can run into problems.  This can be mitigated by being less reliant on the vendor for everything.  Having a SCADA that can augment certain MES functionality can help.  As with many things, it pays off to be strategic about what one buys vs builds.  It’s best to build and customize where it’s a competitive advantage.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Here's an interesting story from the founder of Plex about how they pivoted from on-prem client/server systems to cloud in 1999.

*The next critical step for the new solution was to figure out a way to drastically reduce the total amount of source code we would have to manage over time. I thought, what if we could store the behavior of our software in the same place our customers store their part data and inventory data? The idea was to store the behavior of the application in the form of database data rather than in the form of source code. The idea of “Customer Settings” was born. All the customers would run off a single set of source code, but we would use the Customer Settings tables to provide each company a custom experience, tailored to their particular needs. Principle #3 would be achieved.

Instead of having multiple versions of our source code floating around out in the world at our customer’s locations, we would have a single set of source code. At our office. Under our control. A meta system. And people would somehow connect to. This would mean that every time we added a new feature or capability to the software then that work would become a permanent part of our solution, not just a one-off customization that we did for one customer, but a new capability that we could instantly share with all our other customers. This was one of the key benefits to the new approach.*

Author: Deleted User
Content: Looking at the Plex website, and customer references, I get the impression that their target market is SMB/SME manufacturers. In other words, it's a multi-tenant MES. Would that impression be correct?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Correct.  It's multi-tenant MES and ERP.  It's basically a full-suite ERP with the plant-floor operations functionality built out first and then accounting and HR last.  With most ERPs, it's usually the other way around.  The multi-tenancy has no bearing on the size of the customers.  That's just the architecture.

They do have a large base of mid-size manufacturers.  Those were most of the early adopters and oldest customers.  The majority are in the $50M to $500M annual revenue range.  The core verticals are in discrete (e.g., automotive, aerospace, industrial, metals) and some process (e.g., food & bev, chemicals).  Mid-size is definitely a target because there are more opportunities to acquire that business.  This is more of a function of the market at-large and investment cycles driving replacement.  Within the past decade, a lot of large and well-known manufacturers have signed.  There have been two themes here.  First, there are large firms that want to rip out their legacy investments (e.g., SAP, Oracle, QAD, Infor) that have not been delivering enough value for their operations.  The other theme involves M&A, divestitures, or diverse business units.  Instead of a "big-bang" replacement across-the-board, the product might get deployed selectively to certain business units.  It might get implemented where it's a good functional fit, fast to deploy, or where it was cost-prohibitive to expand an incumbent solution.  They'll then integrate it with the legacy ERP or a financial management suite running at HQ.  Because it's cloud tech with a consistent data model, these "hybrid" or "two-tier" ERP models are becoming somewhat common.  Whether it's a $10M firm with one site or a $10B firm with many sites globally, the product scales pretty well.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: I think it depends of the size of the plant, how cost effective it gets and what functionalities are being used. PackIOT is cloud based also, but as we always say, we are not an MES. As a reporting tool we don't stop the line, as you exemplified. Pretty much like MES 4.0 in this sense. For larger customers, it can be on premise.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
For the sake of discussion, let's pretend PackIOT is an MES and all the concerns that come with it.

Do you currently leverage some sort of edge or site level "collector" (e.g., gateway, UNS) to relay into PackIOT?  Does it have cache'ing or store-and-forward functionality?  Have you found that this remediates most issues with cloud connectivity?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Musings on MES architecture...

I've seen some traditional architectures where the PLCs are "married" to the MES.  They're so tightly coupled that they cannot run independently of each other at all.  I wonder if this approach, in the long-run, does more harm than good.  It makes things fragile and inflexible.  It can make any change incredibly disruptive.  It's architecture that, as is common in industrial tech, assumes everything will always work and never change.

There are a lot of scenarios in which an MES does not necessarily need to be completely present every cycle.  Transactions can be timestamped and queued or batched.  From a reporting perspective, everything "feels" real time even if it's not exactly processed that way.  The more critical moments involve things like setups or loading source inventory.  This information can be made available in a UNS or SCADA at the edge.  The production process can theoretically "carry-on", within limits, in between these critical moments.

Is the problem with cloud connectivity or is it the way we architect MES in the stack?  If the architecture is more "loosely-coupled" or "service-oriented", do the problems subside?

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Yes, it does have a store and forward database on a site level collector, as you mentioned, and this is enough when connectivity is reliable. When the connection is back, all messages are processed and reports are updated. Setup is a special case. When it is done, the operator has to input to correct time in the past and all calculations are not affected because as you mentioned everything is timestamped.

What’s your opinion ? Do you think there should be more than one meaning what cycle time means at different companies ? Is there any standard for it ?

Thanks in advance,
- Barış*
