Author: ianskerrett.
Content: I am sure you know more about K8s than me 🙂  However, I am interested in the use of clustering technology in the OT setting, especially for high availability.  For instance, running HiveMQ in a factory and in a clustered environment to ensure ha.

Author: irish_engineer
Content:
HA within a single facility would be very difficult (and in some scenarios, not possible) HA is first a function of the network and second of the clustering tech. On the network side, you need physically isolated networks for HA. In Amazon or Azure, this is geographical isolation (i.e. the cable in the ground carrying signal is different between cluster nodes). Within a factory, the switches, routers, cabling, server location would all need to be different for HA. As the network cable entering the facility would be singular, this split has limitations.
That said, Kube can help respond to spikes in data coming from PLCs. So if the CPU spikes, Kube would scale the app across its nodes and everything would just work. It’s not HA but it is scalability. Once you have the CPU and RAM on-site, you will be good in most cases.
For that type of setup, you should look at Rancher running on Openstack. You get the ability to deploy many Kube clusters without the Kube inside Kube stuff. As you would need to assume the cable entering the facility will break at some point, you should also think of large volumes of storage, with Ceph being the go to for these setup today

Author: mparris
Content:
I think the first step of interest is given an application, such as an MQTT broker, is running on a PC,  how can one protect from downtime if that PC fails.

Most MQTT brokers provide clustering at the application level, but it would be interesting to know for an application that doesn't cluster (SQL for example) what it takes to combine N computers in a cluster where when one fails, the application continues running.

Author: irish_engineer
Content:
What Kube gives is a guarantee that once the CPU and memory is available across a group of nodes, your application will get its configured cluster sizing.
If a server the application is running on dies for any reason, Kube will make sure the application that was deploy on that server, is redeployed somewhere else to maintain the application cluster sizing. It also handles the networking and connections to shared storage.
The question for non clustering applications is more about the application itself and not than Kube. For example, it an application stores critical data in RAM, when the server it is running on that fails, nothing can be done to recover that critical data.
On the question of SQL and clustering, many SQL DBs to offer clustering and HA setups. For one example see https://mariadb.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/mariadb-platform-high-availability-guide_whitepaper_1001.pdf

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yes.  Each station will have their own theoretical rates for maximum efficiency.  Additionally, you can have an aggregate for the whole multi-station line.  This is similar to the way one might have an OEE for a plant or an area of a plant.  It's common to monitor the overall OEE, but then focus on an underperforming station's OEE to make improvements.  This makes it clear where there is a bottleneck or constraint negatively impacting overall performance.

This can happen on multiple PLCs or one PLCs.  It doesn't matter what is producing the data.  What's important is that activity is being tracked to produce the necessary data for calculating OEE.  This might take form of a sensor at every station or even an operator interface.  Even in a manual process without actuators present to "do the work", automation can be beneficial playing a more passive role.

Content: To add to what @js shared, if you don't have any way to automate data capture at a station level, the next best thing would be to provide an interface to digitize manually generated data at source (phone/tablet etc). Even digitizing after capture (using pen/paper and then entering into a computer later) is a good starting point and better than no data at all.

Author: benveenema
Content: Although possibly better than no data at all, the issue with manually captured data is trust. You can't be sure of the accuracy of the data and therefore you don't know that the results or information is a lie. We are dealing with this very issue in our own plant at the moment.

Author: srihari9539
Content:
That's true. In all cases where data is manually generated this is a challenge (even highly automated factories have at least some instances of data and information that is generated by humans and requires manual logging). However, I do believe there are ways to mitigate this. 
Most people tend to blame inaccurate data on operator discipline or non-cooperation. I don't always agree with this. In my experience, the two biggest reasons for inaccurate data collection are 
1) Too much friction in the data collection process - An operator's primary focus is the task at hand and if it's too tedious and distracting for them to log data I wouldn't blame them for resisting. 
2) Wrong incentives - if the person logging the data is going to be appraised based on the values logged, there is a perverse incentive to fudge the numbers. No one should feel threatened. Rather than just being a directive by management, companies should be willing to share in the value generated from having access to accurate data with all stakeholders in the business, especially operators. If its just a one way value exchange between a company and its employees, it will rarely work. 
Would be interested to know others' experiences in dealing with this.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Spot on. The first reason is why I am not a fan of manual downtime codes. You end up with a lot of "9 - Other". The second reason can lead to a lot of strange behavior. When I was at Emerson, they used a three-year rolling average to determine the number for a payout bonus. We figured out we made more money by slacking 2 years and then hitting it the third that incremental growth year-over-year.

Author: benveenema
Content:
Love these responses! Number 1 is the primary issue we have at the moment and I'm looking forward to fixing it.

Number 2 is difficult to balance well. Even if you tell an operator we don't want to blame you, we just want to help our processes improve, they likely still be worried about the data being used against them. Perhaps anonymizing data would help mitigate this but then you miss a valuable data point.

Author: benveenema
Content:
This looks like a very cool integration! I love that IFM has created UDTs for Ignition. Every sensor manufacturer needs to have UDTs/Function Block/AOI's whatever you want to call them, available for integration.

The one hesitation I have is that it does not appear edge driven. You need to manually create the instance of each UDT in your perspective and point it to the IO block and port. This is not scale-able, and is Ignition-centric (builds a wall on a couch - if you replace Ignition, you loose all that work)

IFM does have MQTT support though for some of it IO-Link masters. This means you can configure the sensor on the IO-Link master (which you would have to do either way) and then point it at the UNS (Ignition Server in this case). This makes it edge driven, and Ignition Independent, which is scale-able.

Author: the_clan_of_rob
Content:
@Ben Veenema @youri.regnaud @Durga Kolli I had a discussion with our US IO-Link Product Manager about why our MQTT doesn't publish RBE. He said this has been an ongoing discussion internally and that currently they chose to do it based on a time interval because consistently defining "change" for all the available IO-Link devices has been the challenge.

Maybe you can all help enlighten me on this. Using a pressure transmitter as an example: cyclically over IO-Link you get the vendor ID, device ID, pressure (in steps of 0.1 psi) and switching status. It makes sense that the vendor ID, device ID, and switching status would all be RBE. For the pressure though, would you want it to only report the pressure if it changes by the 0.1 psi step? If that's the case, pressure rarely holds that steady so you'd be getting constant reporting anyway. Or do you want to define what "change" is for each use case? If so, that would have to be logic built in to the IO-Link master.

Author: benveenema
Content:
It might not be too bad too to publish on change even with your example of the pressure sensor that changes in 0.1psi increments.

Yes, this could be a lot of publishes but it's going to be limited by the polling rate of the IO-Link master. If it polls every 10ms, which would be pretty fast that's still only 100 publishes per second. Yes, this could be an issue if you had 1000's of these but a lot of systems are able to handle 10's of thousands or more publishes per second because MQTT is so lightweight.

Another option would be to have a min time between publishes setting. So everything is RBE, unless it just published, then it has to wait out whatever setting that is.

Author: mparris
Content: Yeah, an option on the step change (0.1 deadband filter) and maximum publish rate (500ms, for example and drop all other changes) seem to make them most sense

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The contemporary UNS-oriented architecture evangelized by this community does not necessarily replace the components of the ISA-95 "automation pyramid", but it rearranges them.  Each node still serves its purposes.  The only difference is the integration is more practical and less convoluted.

OEE is a very popular feature to offer in automation products.  In a very solution-centered way, it's offered up at all layers of the stack.  Buyers get distracted by flashy dashboards and performance metrics.  They overlook where the data is coming from, how its processed, and whether it can scale across their operation.  I would suspect that more manufacturers are familiar with OEE than what an MES is.

If we think about what an MES is, it's a system of executing manufacturing.  It definitely knows:  inventory processed, inventory rejected/scrapped, workcenter state, workcenter schedule, theoretical/standard cycle times, etc.  It knows these things because it does (i.e., transacts) these things.  If we think about what OEE is, it's a historical representation of what the MES transacted.  Hence, OEE is driven by MES.  While not all data originates in the MES, it does converge to and traverse there to execute production.  Sometimes OEE is a separate app/module and sometimes its a mere report.  I believe it's safe to associate this as MES functionality.

If you're looking for more formal roles of OEE in the automation stack, check out "MES" and “MOM" in "ISA-95".  There are all sorts of papers on this topic.

Author: benveenema
Content:
I often get confused as to what belongs in an ERP vs an MES. It seems to me there's a lot of overlap. Both have tools that are used to execute manufacturing. 

Example, often MOs are issued from an ERP which to me seems like more of an MES task. Is this a function of a 3.0 ERP mantra where the bloated ERP is the single source of truth instead of the UNS?

It's the role of ERP reduced in a 4.0 company?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think what makes it challenging is a lot of major ERP firms have “full suite” offerings. They might offer up modules for specific industry verticals along side their core financial and human capital management modules. In some cases these modules are the result of acquisitions to maintain or expand market share. This creates confusion about what ERP is and isn’t.

Some ERPs creep down the stack. At the same time, some MES (e.g., job shop products) and SCADA apps creep up. Product managers don’t necessarily follow what ISA dictates. They’ll build product they can market and sell. Sometimes this means blurring the lines.

I would say that the role of ERP is not diminished in I4.0. I’d say it becomes more important and more usable. I think what is different is that we’re less likely to see bloated full-suite deployments. First, it’s too hard to successfully implement these “big-bang” projects in a reasonable amount of time. Second, the functionality is not equally good or supported across the board. For example, a module that has been abandoned for a decade is probably not very innovative. 

In the cloud era, best-of-breed has become a reality. With version-less software built on modern architecture, integration is much easier than its been in the past with on-prem. Mixing and matching is much more common. I’m seeing a lot more two-tier ERP for financials, separate HCM, separate CRM, separate transportation management, separate PLM, separate tax engine, separate invoicing by locality, etc than I have in the past. This used to mean a horrible user experience and was horrible to maintain. Cloud and platforms have enabled more diverse app ecosystems.

2) There’s not a definitive answer for what’s MES vs ERP. MESA comes closest, but they have a model of functions rather than a straight definition. ERP was coined by Gartner with an actual definition at the time, but colloquial usage of ERP has no sanctioned or universally accepted definition now. So you’re confused because so is everyone. It’s just confusing.

Author: durgakolli2717
Content: Question: What is the best way to log Errors/Alarms/Faults with OEE metrics? for example I am trying to record downtime with the error that has caused it but If I have multiple Alarms (programmed as arrays in PLC) How can I log multiple alarms with 1 downtime Event? FYI - In Ignition I have created OEE UDT and mapping the tags from PLC.

Author: mikael4164
Content:
We handle this in the PLC to ensure that only one alarm will be reported as responsible for the stop. When the machine stops the PLC code will check active alarms during one program cycle and set an integer tag to a value corresponding that particular alarm. The OEE/Downtime system triggers an event when that integer goes from zero and uses a lookup list to store the correct stop cause. This ensures that you always get one stop cause. 
In cases where more than one alarm is triggered in the same program cycle, the actual order of instructions determine which alarm that will be stored as stop cause. In this way you do have some priority control.
Hope it helped😊

Author: zackscriven
Content: Pinned a message.

Author: durgakolli2717
Content: Thanks @Mikael  for the response. That is exactly what we came up except that we are doing PLC part in Ignition because we don't have flexibility to change code in PLC. that being said consider this case: 4 Independent stations running  by one PLC. they do have individual Alarm arrays for each cell and also Major and Minor Alarm Array combining all 4 stations. In this case, logging multiple errors makes sense as you might have Station specific alarms and/or Major Alarm. Any suggestion on how we can approach this?

Author: mikael4164
Content: How do you handle the OEE calculation? Is it done individually for each of the four stations or for the combination of all four? Do all four stations stop if only one of them has an alarm? If you calculate OEE individually for each station I believe you don't have to handle the Major and Minor alarms (that combines the stations). If you treat all four stations as one machine and do the OEE calculation on that you will have another situation. If that is the case you cannot really say that the machine has stopped when one of the stations stopped since the others are probably still running. The result of such a situation is a decrease of throughput which the OEE calculation will catch as Performance loss (P). Thus you should log the station alarms as performance losses and I guess that could be done by looking at the individual station alarms. If for example the Major alarms stops the whole machine you can use these to handle stop cause. Maybe this was kind of a confusing answer but it is important to know on which level the OEE calculation is done and what stops what....🙂

Author: durgakolli2717
Content: The Four Individual stations - and one Material Handler Robot as a whole that's the Equipment/Machine/Cell (Whatever we want to call it.😁 ). If one Station E-stopped (Major Alarm) the others still run so, we are planning on doing OEE for each station with there station specific alarms and OEE for Material Handler (And How we calculate it? I am not sure at this point.). This specific Machine/Equipment is bit confusing however the main goal is to provide as much info as possible when the machine is down. The problem I see here is I can only log one fault as a reason for downtime event. which makes me ask another question, Can we do Two types/levels of OEE on 1 Machine/Equipment? First level (internal to each station) and the Second level which give us top level view of the machine? It will be similar to OEE and OLE I guess at this point except that it is not a line it's just One Equipment/Machine/Cell..🙃

Author: mikael4164
Content: We have similar setups and the way we proceed often depends on how we foresee to use the data. If the individual stations are very simple it might not make sense to complicate things but if you want to be able to compare performance between stations you need to handle them as individuals. One important thing to note in your setup is that you will have some dependencies between the stations and the Material Handling Robot. You will have situations where the robot stops and material is queued up and finally causes the upstream stations to stop. Depending on buffers and position of these stations it might happen that they stop independent of each other and if the stop is short it might be that some of the stations does not stop at all. This will impact the OEE differently on the individual stations which will complicate comparison of OEE data. We normally "pause" the OEE calculation for a machine that is starved (no incoming material) or blocked (downstream queue) and set the machine state accordingly to visualize in reports. We do OEE calculation on Line level and machine level but we only use the term OEE (not OLE). There are probably a lot of different ways you can do this and I am not really sure what standards tell but the important thing is to create OEE layers that enables you to pinpoint the direction when doing improvements. In your case I would chose individual OEE for the stations. You can also do OEE for the robot and on top of all you can do OEE for the whole cell. This will give you a good granularity. If eg the whole cell is stopped this will trigger a "blocked" state for the stations meaning the cell gets the blame🙂 and you will see this in the A of the OEE for the cell. If a station stops you will see this in the A of the station but eventually also in the P of the cell. There is a lot to to discuss in this topic and I guess there are a lot of opinions😃.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: From my experience we usually never have an accurate priority list of alarms that drive an automated downtime reason. We usually will do one of two things --> 1) OEE system will see the down event from automation and the operator will assign a downtime reason from a standardized list. At this point if our system was seeing multiple active alarms, we prompt the operator for "Fault Association", and they will pick from list of Faults that were active during the downtime event. Note we typically don't pull these from the PLC directly, rather from a Time-Series Historian that is capturing all the alarms and events on the line.  2) We only use the alarms for further root cause analysis.  Meaning the OEE system collects downtime events and the operator will assign the downtime reason from the standardized list and nothing more. Separately the Time-Series Historian is collected alarms and events from the line.  We build datasets (downtime events on an asset, alarms and events leading up to OR active during the downtime event) and build Reports or even stream to ML engines for analysis on root cause.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: The functions I hear associated with MES are: OEE, Scheduling (possibly incl. next-in-line positioning of materials), Quality track and trace info, and Recipe Management; could also include Lab mgmt data or item BOM or other things you might think of as ERP  or even SCADA functions. It seems to be fuzzy. The functionality that "must exist" is what the vendor says it should be based on the target they're selling to. Hope to hear others chime in on this... @zackscriven

Author: benveenema
Content:
Seconded!

It is blurry what belongs in MES. I think this has to do with the history of ERP systems migrating all across the stack in an effort to vertically integrate. All software vendors will do this to some extent, and MES vendor might migrate up for example which further confuses the issue.

MES is a system most 3.0 companies don't have so it's natural we are somewhat confused as to what it does and doesn't do.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
The lines between MES/ERP/SCADA have become blurred in the last few years. ERP companies are doing more in the manufacturing space and SCADA companies are doing more in the MES space. Both Purdue/ISA and MESA define MES along the lines of functionality and time horizon, rather than the "layer". This is becoming increasingly true within the context of Industry 4.0 and the UNS. Definitionally, an MES comprises the following functions:
• Data acquisition
• Production scheduling
• Personnel management
• Resource management
• Production tracking and dispatch
• Traceability/genealogy
• Quality control
• Process management
• Performance analysis
• Document management
• Maintenance management

Content: The following is from ISA-95, but I don't find it to be very helpful. The thick dotted-line is meant to represent the boundary between Layer 3 and 4.

Author: patjdixon
Content: I would like to sugest the following analogy, which might work for an audience that is not automation savvy.  MES is like the waiter at a restaurant.  They take an order from your table (ERP) and deliver orders to the kitchen (layer 2 and below).  They also collect information on that order (batch record) such as the customer complaints that it was too salty or took to long to deliver.  That is the core of what level 3 (MES) is.  Anything else is either functionality that can live anywhere (OEE) or an enhancement, like the chocolate mint in the plate with the bill.  Does that work?

Author: patjdixon
Content: Thanks for the reply David.  I have a few questions:

Author: patjdixon
Content: My questions are:  When you say Data Acquisition, is this some other kind of Data Acquisition that does not occur at level 1 (connecting to field signals)?  When you say Personnel Management, doesn't that happen at Level 4?  For Document Management, is that part of the automation stack?  Doesn't Document Management happen at every layer?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: You can think of the MES functions specific to manufacturing events. For instance, the data acquisition piece will be material movement, downtime events, OEE calculations. The MES will track this data. Personnel refers to people involved in a manufacturing process. If I am going to make a product, I may need an Operator role and Quality role involved. The MES will define this need. Yes, there is all kinds of documentation produced, but this is referring to documentation like shift reports, quality checks, work orders, etc.

Author: patjdixon
Content: Got it, thanks

Author: patjdixon
Content: Perhaps a better analogy is the kitchen manager.  The waiters are taking orders from customers, like the ERP system does.  Now the waiters (ERP) tell the kitchen manager (MES) about all the orders, and the manager (MES) needs to dispatch the orders to the right chefs.  The MES knows who makes fish, chicken, salads, deserts, etc and makes sure the orders get placed properly and delivered, as well as track any quality issues.  Is that better?

Author: benveenema
Content:
An interesting question came up today in our Digital Transformation Team meeting today regarding the quality metric in OEE.

Does live OEE calculation require inline inspection (100% or otherwise)?

Author: benveenema
Content: We have a lot of machines that make 100's of low cost parts/hr. We currently don't have inline inspection, it's handled on a case by case basis. This is something we need to work on separately but how could we get an accurate quality metric without inline inspeciton?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is very common.  I've never seen an instance, at least in discrete manufacturing of reasonable complex products, where automated inspection can detect every single failure mode during production.  In reality, there are surprises.  All sorts of real-world variation (e.g., material, environment, people, process) can throw off even the most advanced inspection systems.

Most MES suites will have some sort of inventory, production, or rejection module for handling these sorts of quality transactions.  Any decent MES implementation should have both a programmatic method (i.e., API) and user method (i.e., GUI) for quality transactions.  The latter is especially important.  Depending on the environment, this might consist of some sort of console for someone to "log" piece-by-piece (e.g., good, scrap, hold/reject) as production is ran.  Or, if there are is some sort of inspection process that takes considerable time, an interface to good back adjust the records (e.g., X-Y-Z good, Y scrapped, Z on hold for suspect defect) works well.  Either way, the OEE engine will consume this data and calculate accordingly.

Things to look out for:

-If you perform any sort of sorting or rework, have a way in the MES to distinguish between this and normal production.  Otherwise, this could "muddy" baseline quality metrics.

-Consider architecting your MES to support "first-time-through" or "first-pass-yield" metrics.  These are particularly useful metrics for process engineers.  If an organization has particularly low material costs or has supplier quality problems, there is a tendency to undervalue the cost quality and impacts to productivity.  These don't speak "loudly" as a line item on an income statement or most quality KPIs.  First-time-through provides visibility into the integrity of a production process.  It makes it clear whether a line is producing product at an appropriate level of quality without any special intervention.

Author: benveenema
Content: So is it correct to say that, many times in mid to high volume discrete manufacturing, the quality metric is not real time and is a lagging indicator?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Depending on the inspection process, yes.  It's definitely not uncommon.  Some organizations will take the chance on running production while the wait for a verdict from quality.  They likely found the productivity benefits exceed the cost/risk of having a quality problem.  Or, they have their process control in order and can run with a reasonable level of confidence.

My personal preference is to have both real time and lag.  Generally, it's optimal to have transactions happen in real-time.  It's much more realistic for someone to classify something accurately as it's happening than recollect what happened over the past eight hours.  But, sometimes, not all the right information is present.  It can take time to inspect, diagnose, clarify, confirm, etc.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: This has come up in every OEE implementation I have ever been a part of. @js responses are spot on. If you don't have inline quality and are re-working the part back through production one option is to run that "Re-Work Order or Part" where the machine / process is "Not Available for Production" (Un-Scheduled). This would not impact OEE, but rather the Total Effective Equipment Performance measurement over time. Most implementations I have been a part of use first pass yield and allow for a part to be Scrapped or marked for Re-Work some time after it is produced, both potentially impacting OEE in some way.

Author: benveenema
Content: Hey @tom02686 I'm curious how the UNS integration went (or is going)? Does Libre play well as a "node in the ecosystem"?

Author: tom02686
Content: Software yes, there is a Libre Edge component that collects factory floor data via MQTT/OPC-UA and publishes up to main cluster (cloud or on-prem). Libre-Edge is written in golang, so we there binaries for arm/linux/windows/containers e.t.c. No hardware solution *today*

Author: tom02686
Content: More of a data sink than a data-source today. The openness comes about through a GraphQL API into what we are calling the Manufacturing Knowledge Graph. We've essentially taken the ISA standards, including workflow, put them into a graph database and tied in historian connectors. The GraphQL API works super well for querying and subscribing to contextualized historical information. I can enter the graph through any object, equipment/order/personnel e.t.c. and traverse to the data i'm after. E.g. Show me all the machine events/quantities for this order or get at that same data via equipment -> properties -> history or this person -> orders -> equipment -> properties -> history e.t.c. Workflow can be driven via subscriptions to changes in the graph (e.g. order start) or mqtt to kickoff some logic, so I guess you could define a bunch of these and publish back into a UNS

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
Thanks, @tom02686.  If I understand correctly, you've coded into the Graph the nodes (links) for ISA95 standard models --- plant/ area/ line/ machine/ object/...events...counts, etc, (at least what's needed to calculate OEE) that could easily map to corresponding UNS nodes, which could subscribe to changes. 

So more questions, maybe for the community: 
1. Wouldn't the API become a bottleneck for use of the UNS to feed current-state visualizations, real-time decision support? 
2. If Libre Edge data collection is report by exception, how easy would it be to publish to multiple destinations or an additional MQTT broker simultaneously with publishing to the Libre main cluster?

Trying to get my head around this. I do see the benefits of a Graph data structure by your description, Tom.

Author: kalpanasaraswat2230
Content: My question: How to include PMEA in MES

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: What is PMEA?  Is this form of Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (e.g., FMEA, PFMEA, DFMEA)?

Author: tom02686
Content:
Great questions!
1. Depends on the data-set. I'm not worried about the transactional/master data, that is stored in dgraph, which scales with sharding. Some performance metrics for dgraph are (here)[https://dgraph.io/blog/post/performance-throughput-latency/] and (here)[https://dgraph.io/blog/post/benchmark-neo4j/]. For time-series data through the graph, yes this could become an issue. It depends on your historian setup as your're at the mercy of the timeseries database. Some additional latency is added as your're essentially proxying that data request through the graph; this is the trade off for single/federated api vs multiple apis
2. At the moment we only have a single consumer on the publish channel back up to the cluster. If I had to solve this right now, I'd just use an MQTT Bridge

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Without knowing more about your industry vertical, I'm going to take a discrete manufacturing and automotive approach to answering this.  Some of the terminology and methodologies of quality may vary.

The simple answer on how to include FMEA in MES is through Checksheets from a Control Plan.  Many organizations will create FMEA documents as required, but they will reside in a filing cabinet or a file server far away from those running production.  Often, the only time they're reviewed is during an audit or to fulfill a customer requirement.  I believe the best way to embrace FMEA is by making it "live" and operationalizing it into production.  When a FMEA is "stale" in a spreadsheet, it will always remain disconnected from the organization.  Engineering will evolve the product, operations will evolve the process, and the FMEA will become more irrelevant.

A strong Quality Management System is best enforced with closed-loop processes.  This means embedding it into engineering and production business processes.  It requires an entirely different mindset of engineering quality into a production process as it is conceived.  This is fundamentally different from making tweaks to a production process or adding inspection to comply with requirements after the fact.

The FMEA should consume data models from the ERP / PLM.  This information will be used to form the basis of all the requirements and failure modes.  Next, an accompanying Control Plan should be built for the FMEA.  This will contain everything detect, control, and remediate the risks outlined in the FMEA.  When it comes time to run production, a Checksheet will represent an instance of the Control Plan.  It will contain all the process control as prescribed in the FMEA and Control Plan necessary to run production.  These Checksheets should be embedded into the MES interfaces.  The MES should require completion of Checksheets based on production events (e.g., setup, tool change, material change, cycles, time).

Author: kirtanderson
Content: @Paulo Vitor - As with OEE in many other processes, the number produced has very little value for anything other than a blunt object to hold over the heads of operators. The Downtime and Throughput components will have value to you. It's the CI value that you derive from the context associated with your DT events and "slow-run" or non-optimal throughput events. How you calculate that metric and how you use it to improve is what matters.

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
several years ago, we built an asset-based model of two entire refineries for a US-based producer in Kansas and Oklahoma using the OSI PI and Asset Framework platform. (This is where we started to understand that the platform was a dog and would never scale.) 

There was never a true OEE calc done in the process for a couple of reasons, but the primary one is that no one in the business could agree on how to measure it (we had warned them that it would happen that way). 

Once the model was complete and the time series was being collected, we started to help them analyze the process issues that were occurring by trapping events, based on time series and applying context to them. As the DB of events grew, the ability to apply advanced tools increased and a path for continuous improvement emerged.

My point? - In your industry, the concept of OEE doesn't directly apply but the underlying premise of the data infrastructure model and the need to contextualize event-driven data is absolutely identical. There is no magic wand to efficiency or CI in O&G. It's just critical thinking and hard work.

Probably not what you were looking for - sorry.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
I agree that OEE is going to be more difficult for continuous process and may even impossible for certain applications.  To your point, the biggest hurdle is going to be getting everyone to agree on how to measure it.  I think this issue actually gets easier for more regulated industries.

One application I have been looking at for the would be running OEE calculations on purified water skids, specifically for the pharma industry.

Availability is easy:  What percentage of the time is the system available when required

Performance shouldn't be too bad:  What is the output based on the feedstock?  I.e., based on "x" GPM incoming, we expect to see "y" GPM outgoing.

Quality is usually the hardest, but in a regulated industry, this parameter is usually set for the producer, in this case Quality:  <1.2uS/cm@25C, <500ppbC, low micro count, low endotoxin (WFI).  Different facilities can set different levels for themselves, but that's the base per USP.

Using this: A=95%, P=100GPM out (when 110GPM out expected) = 91% Q= 82% (uS/cm: 1, target 0.9, ppbC 11, target 15), OEE = 89%

Author: pathakchi
Content:
I am thinking instead of using a specific target value for a parameters why not use a target 2 x standard deviation?
And for multiple parameters we may use weighted average based on importance of their priority for calculating avg performance value....Any thought??

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
Yeah, that could definitely work, it will just depend on how tightly you want to control the process.  I think the pharma industry usually uses a 2, 3 and 5 standard deviation system, for action, alert, and alarm (might be a bit off on levels and terms, but you get the idea).  You just have to make sure that system doesn't conflict with any hard limits.

Also agreed on the multiple parameters, I used an equal weighting in my example, and I believe that might be standard.  That said you could always create a variance with unequal weighting that might work better (i.e. OEEx).  I would definitely change the name of the parameter (even if it is just adding a subscript) if you're going to adjust the underlying calculation.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
It is important to differentiate between an MES system and an Analytical system that calculates OEE. (Some people call these systems MOM for Manufacturing Operations Management).

The E in MES is the crucial part. An MES manages Execution, which means organising the materials, people, equipment and time to get things done.

Continuous processes (Mining, Oil&Gas, Cement, Water&Waste Water, and others) have less need for "Execution" in a production sense, and typically have other application that manage the "Execution" of other tasks like Maintenance and Quality.

A good MES brings the relevant data sets together to allow new optimization and automation of the business, regardless of what you're executing.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: OEE is most definitely "optional".  It's mostly a awful metric. The constituent pieces are OK, but not adequate for measuring the effectiveness of a modern manufacturing operation.  Safety, energy/resource efficiency, and on time performance (doing the right things, not just doing them fast and to high quality) all matter at least as much.  And TBH the quality component of OEE is usually complete bullshit since very few business can do 100% in-process quality testing, and even fewer retroactively charge bad quality detected downstream to a specific shift for recalculating OEE.

Author: nickn5549

Author: rickbullotta

Author: rickbullotta
Content: There is no single metric that is appropriate to assess overall manufacturing performance in every vertical segment.  Never has been.  Never will be.

Author: arnesvendsen
Content:
Thank You Geoff, I am not bragging much about it, though.  When Bianca Scholten wrote the book in around 2007, I was one of the very few USERS in Europe, actually implementing 95 in practice. We took the B2MML schemas and built a SAP-integration in 2001'ish.  I owned the Prod-IT strategy and got a free license to play from our CEO, would never happen to day. 
Next step in that story was  in 2004 to choose an MES system for the 65 sites in Arla Foods, we chose WW between a handfull of the classics at that time. We forced WW development in Lake Forest to structure the Production DB (aka PEM) to 95. Now running on 50+ Arla sites. 
Some friday night in 2006 I came across a new stuff called LightHammer on the web. 10 mins later I had a phone call from a guy called Rick Bullotta, who still impresses me today  .. 
Now, Lighthammer managed to get sold to SAP, before I was ready to buy, so I ended paying a minor fortune to get SAP MII - also now running on 50+ Arla sites. 
Since Arla threw me out in may 2018 (where I started ASTICON.DK), my focus has been on IIoT, however most companies here around in at "Industry 2.9 .. 3.5'ish" so I make my bread and butter as MES project manager and IIoT advisory as desert. 
Btw: Bianca wrote another book in 2009, which actually describes the Arla MES roll-out. But - its old news ..

Author: andersgustav
Content: *Industry 4.0 Community Discord - what a gang! - Just sayin!*

Author: arnesvendsen
Content:
@Zack The reason I posted in the MES channel, is that it IS MES data I play with - its production order and batch data from our Batch server, so this is all SQL relation tables and not time-historian data.  Grafana seem quite good for that kind also. And YES, I am in the building of a FIVE-dimensional UNS 😇 . 
1) By this I mean there is the "Asset or EQUIPMENT model" - the tree-structure (enterprise-site-area-cell-unit..) which some call the 95 or Purdue model, I think of it as the ISA-88 model, where I think it originated. 
2) Next after Equipment, the MATERIAL model is the most common one ( material-IDs, classes, uses, shift-over matrices etc etc). 
3) To keep track of your BOM/Recipes, you need the DEFINITION model, defining the Formula=BOM=which material go into your product,  PLUS the Recipe-procedure (describing the step of the work to be done, PLCwise or manual).  
As we now, know our stainless steel, materials, recipes - we can start receiving orders from our dear customers ..
4) To actually get something produced in your plant you need, what I call the ORDER model, the production plan you get from some ERP-heaven above, the breaking down into batches (or: if you are producing "discrete" , into work orders etc etc. ) . In 95 this is the Request model (the requested plan) and the Performance model (the actual produced...)
5) Finally the always forgotten model:  The PEOPLE model (defining users, groups, access, capabilities, track-of-training, cerficates etc.) So far I have avoided this, but IF you are in Pharma it does make sense to document if the operator is capable ....
With these 5 model, your UNS can "produce anything from milk to moon rockets". Enjoy the friday when you wake up over there. (I am GMT-2 zone, 🇩🇰 )
(This was actually the short version of chapter 3 of the 95 book, mentioned above, you just saved 120 USD - not having to buy the book on Amazon)

Author: geoffnunan
Content: I completely agree with the beauty and the beast analogy. That's a big part of why the Libre architecture is the way it is. Extensibility is key both in schema, business logic and workflow. You need to be able to "Plug-in" new micro-services that can add new functions without breaking what's already there. That's the power of the Apollo GraphQL Federation Gateway that sits at the top of the Libre stack.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Ross James they aren’t as unrelated as height x weight. That’s ridiculous. Here is how they are related. Your machine can only run when it’s available. You can only produce parts at a certain speed. At that speed only good parts count towards valuable production. That’s why they are multiplied together. It’s a unit less scale. OEE number goes down not good. OEE number goes up, that’s good.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Imagine a production line where technicians produce strands of some high tech fiber.  Shift 1 runs the machine full out for 8 hours and gets a 99% OEE, but the heat buildup causes the nozzles to jam up on Shift 2, leading to a three day outage and a 0% OEE.  Should we reward Shift 1 for their awesomeness?

Imagine an assembly area where workers are told to strive for 95% OEE but because of trying to maintain that frenetic pace for hours, they end up with injuries that keep them out of work for 6 months.  Is that a good way to manage operations?

Imagine a heat surface treatment process that can crank out twice as much product on full speed but consumes 4X the amount of energy (and generates significantly more CO2) while consuming 8X more cooling water.  Is that better or worse?

Imagine a packaging line that ran 96% OEE but a week later it was realized that the wrong labels were put on the bottles.  Do you think that OEE number gets corrected?  Unlikely.

Imagine a specialty chemical facility where different products are manufactured and due to a variety of reasons, OEE varies by product (stochastic aspects of downtime and quality) - but since the operators and supervisors are given a bonus for OEE performance, they choose to run the orders for Product A and B on their shifts, deferring the orders for Product C and D which end up shipping late and costing customer goodwill.  Was that a win?

Everything in context and balance, and don't use a single number to gauge performance.

Author: zackscriven
Content: The machine OEE goes down. You only yell at the operator if the performance is low. It sounds Rick like the Max production speed needs to be lowered if it’s causing an overheating issue. Or they need a duty cycle. With planned stops. That’s the solution here in your first example.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Example #2… 96% OEE is unrealistic. 85% is world class OEE. A machine should be designed for an operator to run it at full speed without being frantic.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Example #3 that depends on the Real Cost and Real profit. OEE does not take that into account.. but you can set the max production speed set point to a number that optimizes this.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Example #4 yes it needs to be updated. And it can be very easily. All OEE calculations should be recalculated on the fly based on the raw events.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Example 5.  This is exactly why machine learning and AI should tell you which product to run on which line.  Also you can (and should) schedule your max rates based on what product you are running,

Author: zackscriven
Content: It's the *target* speed setpoint.  If you are running at that speed then you have 100% performance.

Author: koios6274
Content: @zackscriven I thought it's the maximum speed. If you have a general machine that has 100% quality and 100% availability (go with me here) and it is running at 70% speed - even though that is setpoint the OEE would be (1)(1)(.7) = .70, not 1.0. That's a big thing in improving overall OEE is determining what the machines are actually capable of running. More often you are trying to run it max as possible but I've worked with packaging OEMs, for example, where they say they can package 200 units per minute but in reality it's running around 150 (which would be 75%). Finding out why it isn't running at the rated speeds of 200/min is a way to improve OEE. Perhaps the PLC coding is bad, or there is a delay in the process due to some SQL DB lookup / inefficient coding etc etc

Content: You are right... **Target** speed setpoint... not the actual.

Author: zackscriven
Content: The point I am trying to make is just because a Machine is theoraticaly capable of producing 1000 bottles per minute... you might set the target speed setpoint to 500 because you are filling a viscous substance into the bottle.  Therefor a 450 BPM rate would be 90% of the 500 bottle target setpoint.

Author: zackscriven
Content: For that specific SKU

Author: koios6274
Content: In that example could you not increase the performance by finding a faster way to fill the bottle? If you set it for 500 and it runs at 500 and you think you have perfect OEE, you now have significant lost opportunity. Who's to say what the limit is for a given SKU? I see your point ; I'm not sure what is "correct" but from a pure theory standpoint I would think you are cutting yourself short and assuming perfection if you are running 500 and a setpoint of 500.

Author: koios6274
Content: In that regard though, you could say OEE is relative. What's the main point of "doing OEE"?  I would answer that as saying it's to identify inefficiencies in the process and gain insights.  Sometimes you don't know how you are running. Once you do, if you have a comparable metric to view across lines now you have a way to measure the relative performance. Also you can identify where the inefficiencies are and where to improve.  Most often (but not always) the main issue is availability, which is why downtime tracking is so critical and often the main focus.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I still don't quite understand this play when it ultimately is still under the same ownership.  I would argue the EAM product makes much more sense in the Infor portfolio than Hexagon's.  I don't know how Hexagon could manage or sell the product better.

I recognize Hexagon has been trying to reinvent itself as a "manufacturing intelligence" company to stay relevant in these I4.0 times, but their track record of integrating acquisitions has been spotty.  Having worked with and integrated Hexagon's core metrology products for years, I'm increasingly puzzled by the rest of their portfolio.  They're often very "solution-centered".  They create a lot of standalone functionality that is redundant or not interoperable with everyone else a business may have.  It's a very siloed approach.  And in many cases, the products can be inferior.  Perhaps they're targeting smaller organizations with ad-hoc processes that may not have stood up applications (e.g., QMS, MES, EPR, PLM).

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: You seem to have answered your own question. You are right with your assessment that Hexagon takes a very siloed approach and that's where EAM was a fit as it was sold in a lot of competing ecosystems such as SAP and that were not core manufacturing such as transportation, utility, O&G, etc. The other solutions that are manufacturing and industrial heavy such as LN and CSI already had a lot of this functionality and fully integrated with the core ERP. So rather than maintaining two different codebases, it would make more sense to grow the existing codebase within CSI and LN and fill the massive MES hole with LightHouse acquisition. On the other hand, now Hexagon can sell a lot more when they are going to couple EAM capabilities at the plant level, similar to what Rockwell is doing with FiiX and I believe they bundle another quality product with it, which is standalone too.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: No getting rid of EAM was a master move for Infor even though it was one of the best products in their portfolio. Only savvy investors can think of that far ahead and get rid of their darlings.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: A little confused on this statement from the white paper. Would the “Common Data Model” be a similar concept to a unified name space?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: CDM's tend to me more of an entity (or entity/relationship) model that can be used on both physical entities (people, assets, materials), business processes, the "stuff" that goes through processes (orders, shipments, service tickets, etc.), and the telemetry/data that this all emits.  Different beast than UNS mostly, but I suppose you can look at a UNS as a special kind of subset of a CDM.  I usually found CDM's inadequate in that they are very - ahem - "data" centric and don't model actionable services that well (CRUD APIs really aren't the same thing).  I would love to see "methods" or "functions" added to the UNS approach (and CDM approaches) so we have a common model/repository for all the pieces we need to stitch together composite apps.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's a Microsoft-driven concept for interoperability.  
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/common-data-model/

You won't be able to "shoehorn" your business into a CDM, but you might be able to "shoehorn" or adapt (parts of) CDM into your business' UNS.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: At the risk of being redundant, this is EXACTLY why it is essential to make functions/services first class citizens in the UNS at some point.  Which is going to require some fundamental changes to MQTT and the concept of a broker IMO.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Microsoft is starting to refer to this as the "Dataverse".  I'm not sure where the portal is between the "Dataverse" and the "Metaverse" though.  When I get to my assigned cell in the Metaverse and insert my power, data, food, waste, and meds tubes I'll let you know what I see.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Canonical Data Model is more a generic term.  I suppose you could consider it a UNS if you emphasize the distinction of current state and reusable structure.  

A canonical form is the simple form to rule them all.  It's the form that is all the other forms adapt to or, ideally, is natively supported.  I like to think of it as like the "standard" dialect of a language that broadcasters or a government might use.  Canonical form frequently comes up when working with various transactional standards in financial services or supply chains.  Instead of building out a point-to-point map of each data representation, they might map to a central form distributed through some form of middleware or translational service (e.g., service bus, service oriented architecture, value added network).

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yeah, it could provide a platform for all those Dynamics partners that have historical been in the business of customization.

I feel like this is their strategy for OPC-UA support.  It's think they think it's a shortcut to create this ecosystem of deep industrial vertical domain functionality on top of their platform.  OPC-UA aside, I have hard time imagining people building products on top of Microsoft's IoT platform.  I can see consultants building custom implementations for large enterprises, but not products one would go to market with and monetize.  To Microsoft, they might complain this is inventor syndrome problem.  To inventors, they might complain this is risk.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It's a cost/pricing thing too.  Most of the cloud IoT platforms (and IoT data stores) start to become prohibitively expensive at high data/transaction rates.  Fine for consumer stuff and smart city stuff with lower data rates.  Less attractive for factory/industrial applications.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think broadly the cloud IoT platforms lose their cost effectiveness at scale, and a DIY approach starts to make a lot more sense.  And if you think of a 3rd party IoT platform on top of a commercial cloud platform, there's a lot of people trying to make margin on that, with the cloud vendors rarely if ever discounting.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Note that this assumes that the DIY team fully understands how to architecture for scale, reliability, and security!

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: Microsoft sort of has rebranded/commercialized it but most vendors that have integrated systems use CDM in some shape or form to enable replication among different products that they might be serving through a common interface. They did it to counter Salesforce and Oracle ecosystems. The CDM is targeted and collaborated among vendors that are MS-friendly such as SAP, Adobe, and MS. CDM would not be sufficient for most orgs. They would need MDM strategy for their systems and then obviously UNS is a different beast. But my understanding would be that the contextual information form UNS would be part of the overall MDM strategy as you still need business data even on the shop floor, vendors, customers, products, people, resources etc.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
What’s everyone’s thought to the % success rate for MES deployments? Same for ERP upgrades? 

Reason I ask is the 2 companies I have seen deploy MES(s), it took 2 attempts make it a usable solution. One company even when into litigation with the integrator it was such a failure. 

I would say both failures were in the timeframe of 2010-2015. Do you think some of the new 4.0 solutions/concepts will reduce failed MES deployments? 

Or it’s more about the people/processes involved in the upgrades/deployments?

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
No fixed answer.  Depends whether you consider MES a "product" or a set of functionalities.  Similar to ERP, "big-bang" MES implementations (millions of dollars per site, massive amounts of master data required, all modules implemented) have a fairly low success rate.  But sometimes when they're required for compliance reasons, there aren't a lot of options until recently with some of the new-gen MES solutions like Tulip. 

In my experience the key in most industries is to be able to implement MES modularly and in parallel with other I 4.0 technologies, and ONLY choose MES platforms that are open and extensible.

Author: arnesvendsen
Content:
Agree ..  the BIG MES rollout' days are over.. We did it in Arla 2004-2015 to 50+ sites  - but it was only possible because it was a COOP = farmer owned company, no shareholders checking every Quarter. Long term thinking allowed ..
I have asked for "common data models - across MES products" for 20 years ..  I think it MAY becoming possible with UNS building - then using different components/differen suppliers in-towards the same UNS.
In this forum we by the way mostly talk about UNS as the  equipment-hierarchy (IIoT is mostly about collecting data), but the hard work start we talk MES with a large 'E' as in Executing the production. Then I need the material-model and the order/batch/recipe model in my UNS. I am missing realworld examples of this in the forum here.. ?  (not to talk about inventory/warehouse execution ..)

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
In my experience, the challenge is that most integrators don't have as much business experience to challenge the needs and assumptions that businesses might be making about their own needs. And most business consulting and project management firms have very little clue on technology, architecture, and the underlying systems. 

This is the major reason why these implementations fail. 

And the blame typically goes to the integrator. 

Most software implementations require aligning on the people, process, and technology. But it's hard to find a company that has mastered all 3 equally well along with more than 15 systems involved in the architecture. 

The more you implement, the better you get. 

Most people who have figured out the formula for success try to implement the system on a piece of paper first before they code anything. Now the developer community might argue that isn't that against the agile principles? Well, Agile never said that you should be skipping the key phase of requirement gathering and design. You should iterate where it makes sense. Agile was never meant to create a bunch of stories and start coding. This is especially relevant for systems where you don't have access to the code such as MES or ERP. They require far more time in the requirement gathering, process re-engineering, and data cleansing phase than the traditional software dev projects.

Here is an episode with Charles Rich who failed the first two. But then by 6th, he figured out the formula for success by investing a lot more time in the pre-implementation phase. t.ly/kV7A

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: We went from the failure of the Apriso Delmia MES deployment, despite a successful first deployment, to the success of deploying "Manufacturing Apps" via the Tulip platform. Adaptations are no longer a problem, the teams take ownership of their apps and are able to improve them regularly. Tulip has changed the rules of the game by replacing the notion of Center Of Excellence MES with a Community Of Practice of Apps Builders

Author: aristotelestn
Content: What do you think about the MES from Parsec or Traksys? And for Hybrid applications (part continuous and part discrete)?

Author: infiniteluna9165
Content: I completely agree the integrator involved is a large factor to the success of deploying an MES. I recently was involved in my first onsite MES deployment, and this was one of my key take aways towards a successful system deployment.

Author: arnesvendsen
Content: A good integrators can get the most lousy software to work reasonably. A great software can be spoiled by an un expérienced integrator...

Author: arnesvendsen
Content: MES succes = clever-end-user x competent-solution-integrator*2 x ✓(good-software)

Author: billbither4379
Content: Just joining in on the conversation. I totally agree about choosing systems that are open and extensible but we know that those are far and few between in our industry. Fortunately, there are more modern software vendors with open APIs that are coming up through the ranks. We have the tools now for a DIY approach to MES, but we're starting to see vertically integrated software systems take pieces of MES and execute on them better than "all in one" MES systems can, which reduces the need for System Integrators.

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: Agree, but DevOps or NoOps become critical to manage at scale several SaaS/PaaS solutions in secure and synchronize way. Manufacturing is critical operations, a Manufacturing stack needs a kind of DevOps stack (versioning, CI/CD, release management, …) even with SaaS, no code solution (check configuration, build new release, …)

Author: billbither4379
Content: Ideally connecting several SaaS solutions will not require any custom code, so no need for version control as these integrations are maintained by the vendor themselves. If you're building custom code to integrate or using low-code / no-code tools then versioning becomes important. Low-code tools that I've been using have this built-in.
