In fact, I'm preparing an internal study whether the cost-effectiveness of implementing a consolidated platform would be better than developing the entire application using the agile software development concept (mainly in terms of fast delivery of value to industry areas and TOC / Cost). Have you done any comparisons in this regard?  (remembering that we are a medium-sized company)

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: Hey @js , sorry never came across this one before. I wish I could help. But yeah I agree Luke Smaul might know. Here is his LI profile if you need it. https://www.linkedin.com/in/luke-smaul/

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The pessimist in me says avoid developing your own MES unless it's a core capability your org has in-house and is willing to commit to.  If there are compliance or industry requirements involved, exercise caution.  For a system integrator, this might be viable if the solution could be productized across a customer base.  Avoid reinventing the wheel.  Life cycling software is non-trivial.  For a manufacturer, even with a staff of developers, extending and integrating an off-the-shelf solution can create enough work to go around.

Here's my script for shopping:  Don't take the analyst community too seriously (e.g., Gartner, Forrester, LNS).  They're more like affiliate marketers than advisors.  Go through in-depth technical demos.  Avoid getting distracted by shiny dashboards and gimmicks.  Ask what's happening behind the scenes.  Get an understanding of the assumptions and limitations of the product.  What you see may not necessarily be reproducible in your own environment.  There will be a degree you must commit to their business process or vice versa.  Spend time with customer references.  Don't be afraid to look for dirt.  Do the firms that have had successful implementations bear a resemblence to your own?

Objectivity and transparency can be tough to come by when a firm stands to gain from you signing with a particular solution.  While it can be hard with closed ecosystems (i.e., "certified" partners), look for independent firms to assist with selection and implementation.  Having incentives aligned makes all the difference.  This is especially important if this is a new experience.  It's also not a bad idea to find a mentor in a similar industry that has gone through the process.  They can provide candid advice on what is and what isn't realistic.

Another option is to explore the various no-code / low-code or platform approaches.  Tulip has been brought up a lot here.  Some in this community "stretch" their SCADA / IIoT platform to provide MES functionality.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: The only thing I would add to this is to write down every single requirement (that you have to write anyways for testing) and focus on DIFFERENCES than similarities. 90% of the selections fail as most people look for similarities. Your implementation will be successful if you focused on differences, and differences do not mean boundary cases. It means that you are looking at the core positioning of the solution. Every solution is designed for a very specific purpose, industry, and the size of the company. Also, simplify the processes as much as possible and tailor them to the solution you are buying. Sometimes it could mean challenging your CEO.  That's where independent consultants can help as you as an internal employee will have a hard time challenging your executives and board.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Great perspective.

When focusing on differences, how do you balance broad vs deep capabilities?  Absent some very specific requirement that constrains the options, this is something I've found to be challenging.  It, of course, becomes more clear with hindsight in phase 2 or 3 implementation scenarios.  Provided it's not junk and can be reasonably adopted, initially, I've leaned towards broad out of caution.  It's nice to have a tool that an entire organization can use but, at the same time, does not merely scratch the surface.  If there is not enough depth in functionality, it can create all sorts of opportunities for improvisation and ad-hoc processes.  It can perpetuate the very conditions that lead to selecting a new system in the first place.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: As you correctly pointed out, the more experience you have under your belt, the better you get. If you are seeing a lot of ERP (or any packaged software MES/WMS/TMS/P2P) implementations and their failures on a daily basis, you get better at what's deal-breaker and what's not. It's very hard to have this experience internally when you have seen 4-5 companies and implementation in your entire life. That's where independent consultants can add a lot of value. But not all independent consultants are created equal. Some are spreadsheet junkies and never implemented or written a single line of code in their life, while others who are super deep technically might lack that business perspective that is required to assess and challenge the executive team.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Not sure if I answered the question. Also not sure if you asked the question or that was part of conversational writing. But yeah, balancing broad vs deep is a lot of work  and back and forth negotiation in comparing the level of effort, results, ROI, risks, etc. You are looking at a lot of dollars to go through this process, but you will have a much easier life during and post-implementation. 

Most people who think of ERP implementations as binary don't understand that the requirement and design phase is a critical part of any software development process. Just because you are buying packaged software, it doesn't give you any discount from the requirement and design phase. Also, most people don't understand how difficult writing these requirements are. Most requirements that we get from our clients after they have spent more than 6 months are typically not even close to what we like to see. They are either too generic or fancy wish lists without a clear understanding of how software design and architecture are supposed to work considering the constraints of all packaged software involved.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I was curious how you or others approached this during selection.  Experience, both in general and especially with the products themselves, certainly helps.  

I guess if I had to some it up, my approach would be "Focus on the core requirements, but don't box yourself in.  A minimally viable approach can backfire as an organization evolves.  Think about how to grow into rest of the product with future requirements."

Do you put much emphasis or consideration on other functionality that is bundled in?  Have you ever eased up on the core requirements as a trade off for broader functionality?

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
The way we like to approach this, obviously in the ideal scenario, is how each of the requirements is going to be addressed across the system boundaries both in the as-is and to-be state and well-agreed by all parties. We can't simply ignore the boundary cases. We like to understand the underlying drivers of what's driving it and how valuable that is either for the customer or for the business. If the business can't answer why they need something, then it's probably not needed. But we like to focus a lot on the SO THAT part of the user stories until we get to 5- (or 15-) WHYs nailed out. This is where we get a lot of ammunitions to negotiate with the CEO and the board either "you are crazy to DO this" or "you are crazy to MISS this."

Here is the classic, politely speaking, requirement TRASH, that we get from directors of sales, marketing, Ops, finance, CEOs, even IT directors or CIO at times. This is the requirement that just came in from a customer on how to do this exercise. We have done several rounds of coaching with them, but it's still very hard for them to think from the system's perspecitve. So we need to keep doing this until they understand. The more rounds you do with them, the more they understand why software development and ERP are hard and what to ask for. 

As a Customer Service Representative I want our ERP system to be dynamic, fast and easy to use  
-    So that we can easily look up customer ownership product history and use history while on the phone in real-time, without using multiple systems as sources of customer history 

I can't give you all the details of this client. But this requirement does not mean anything and in fact, if we incorporated this, it will hurt the state of the system overall across the system boundaries.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: The more you train them during the selection phase, the more they will understand how to write test cases and ACTUALLY test. The more they test, the more they will adopt the system. Otherwise, most software packages become the IT/OT tool hated by most business users. Again, if you try to do THEIR job, they will never learn. If you want to teach them how to ride the bicycle, they have to learn it themselves. You need to let them fall, make mistakes. If you don't go through this exercise, they will always complain that bicycles are not flexible, slow, and NOT easy to use. What makes ERP or operational software so hard is the training and adoption. But most companies like to approach it as the technical or from the perspective of problem-solving.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Are you saying to train them in how to select software in general, or train them in using the software they use, so they can manage the lifecycle of it (adapt to changes etc).

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Awesome back and forth between you and @js by the way! I feel like a kid watching his two favorite soccer players playing ball between each other on the field!

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I’m still left wondering, isn’t the requirements gathering what everyone does to select between seemingly different options? User stories are a more fine-tuned way to help the communication of said requirements and be more user-focused rather than technical (a way to paint a picture)? It is such a hard process to go through and most users don’t even know what they should require, let alone know what questions to ask. Neither can anyone really see the needs of the future. I at least wish it would be simpler in a unified namespace architecture. Like choosing an MES, should in only need to be focused on core MES capabilities and open architecture. Perhaps add a industry or vertical-specific specialization. But as long as the solution integrates well with a UNS, the whole capability gap isn’t that much of a big deal.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: @Jon Forbord  I'm saying, the earlier you involve them in the process, the more buy in you will get. You are responsible for technical side of things. But they are the ones who are using it. Unless you coach them riding bicycle has a little bit of learning curve, they won't understand. If you involve them during the assembly process of bicycle, they will have more appreciation for science. If you gave them the bicycle and showed them how efficient you are in riding the bicycle without them trying and learning the baby steps, they will start complaining and give up on learning bicycles and might claim that this bicycle sucks.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Thanks, makes a ton of sense!

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: Irrespective of whether you are talking about manufacturing or software engineering, the fundamentals are same. If you are manufacturing something, you don't throw a steel bar in a machine and wonder what happens. You go through the process of R&D, design, feasibility, and then if it makes sense, you manufacture. The more advanced you are in the process, the more expensive it gets. Also, if you don't know what your are looking for, what are the odds that you will be test something that you don't even know what you want? Most people think of software development as coding, that's typically the easiest part, especially when you don't even know what you want. The challenging part is always writing user stories, testing the feasibility, getting everyone to agree on a solution, building a good test plan, and delivering within budget. If you follow the process, you will never want to touch any IT or OT projects even in your dreams. This is why we always recommend that it's always easier to buy a digital product then building it.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: The intent of requirement gathering is to implement the whole solution on a piece of paper first, which will always be cheaper than actually implementing it. The user stories could be technical or non-technical. The whole idea of  user stories is to discover the underlying drivers for the requirements, so they are easier to understand, but offers you ability to negotiate with your business users. If you don't ask for business drivers, they will never tell you. And if you implement as is, most likely they will never be happy with the solution. The process of going through the user stories help them refine their understanding and they will have more appreciation for your work.

Author: john_cindrich
bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: This is flattering, @Jon Forbord.  ERP/MES projects are about balancing/transforming expectations of stakeholders and persevering through.  Using your soccer analogy, I feel more like "Bend It Like Beckham" than David Beckham.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I would recommend going down the path of an MES selection process as if it were a clean slate.  This will enable you to make more informed and sound decisions even if there is a high likelihood you will coalesce around an Infor solution.

First off, if MES requirements are only OEE and asset state, it might be worthwhile "stretching" a SCADA to fulfill these requirements.

Infor generally has strong functionality for various manufacturing verticals, but it's far from the only option.  It's important to assess how this MES will fulfill your requirements.  While consolidating as much as possible into the ERP is a worthwhile endeavor, do they know how feasible this is?  What do they intend to do if there isn't a good "home" for a critical business process?

There's some natural synergy here.  Infor's ERP and MES offerings will have complementary data models.  They're intended to be sold and implemented together.  But, that's ultimately an assumption.  Why?  In the real world, there is variation.  The ERP in place might be older version that does not integrate [well] with the the latest MES version.  It may have been implemented on a narrow budget for a narrow scope (e.g., accounting and hr only).  It might have an incomplete data model to interface with an MES.  The implementation partners may need to be called back to finish the job.

If you do opt for Infor, you'll likely have the solution "sit" under the ERP.  Infor's native integration will likely exceed what you could build out on your own.  This will provide a consistent user experience and security model.  It will also yield less surprises.  Straying from this from this should be reserved for unique and differentiating use cases.

Infor has web service interfaces that will expose various transactions (e.g., inventory, assets, boms, scheduling, production).  The UNS, through an IIoT or DataOps platform, can call up these services to indirectly exchange this data to other nodes in the ecosystem.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Practically, this would consist of a mix of native point-to-point integrations and custom one-to-many integrations.

**Native integration**
If the ERP and MES have complementary functionality and turn-key integration, it's worthwhile leveraging this.

[ERP] <- native integration via APIs or shared database -> [MES]

**UNS Integration**
As there is more to your business than just ERP and MES, you'll need a way to exchange this intelligence elsewhere.  Leveraging a UNS will provide a consistent data model for your business to consume and produce.

[Broker] <- MQTT -> [IIoT Platform / DataOps] <- HTTP -> [MES]
[Broker] <- MQTT -> [IIoT Platform / DataOps] <- HTTP -> [ERP]
[Broker] <- MQTT -> [IIoT Platform / DataOps / SCADA]
[Broker] <- MQTT -> [IIoT Platform / DataOps] <- native -> [Other]
[Broker] <- MQTT -> [Other]

**Solution shortlist**
Ignition, Factory Studio, or HighByte could serve the role as IIoT Platform / DataOps / SCADA.  This will orchestrate the integrations and UNS.  This could even be "bridged" to other integration solutions you may have in place (e.g., iPaaS, Infor OS).

As far as MES, there are a lot of options.  Depending on the future role of your Infor ERP, you could even look into the manufacturing-focused ERP (providing MES functionality) in parallel.  I would advise "kicking the tires" at Infor, Plex, SAP, QAD, Accumatica, Kennandy / Rootstock, etc.  Personally, I'm biased towards cloud as I'm not fond of upgrades and lifecycling.  I'm sure others can chime in with their preferred solutions.  In short, become an educated buyer and determine how these these could fit into your requirements.

As discussed earlier, there is a possibility a platform (e.g., Ignition, Tulip) might be able to fulfill the requirements.  You could leverage a module (e.g., Sepasoft MES in Ignition) or roll your own.  The important thing here will be the scope.  If it's too big and requires too much customization, it will be too hard to stand up and support.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Thanks for asking the question. Before I respond to your inquiry, I did a little bit of research about you, your team, and your company. Before you do anything, the first thing you might want is to find the product name from Infor and the version. Also, who is hosting it? You might actually burn yourself by looking at Infor marketing material. The reason for that Infor still carries way too many products and their marketing team struggles with how to do this in the most simplified manner. 

Based on my understanding of your company, this PDF is absolutely irrelevant for you, unless you are running Infor LN, which is very rare to see in a small shop like yours (I am assuming that you have your current company highlighted on your LI profile). This MES is nothing but a partnership agreement between Infor and FORCAM’s industrial IoT solution. Infor LN may have a little bit of out-of-the-box integration available, but for the most part, it might be implemented for very large accounts, which might be meaningless for you. Again, it's very hard to predict what they might have unless we start digging into the message-level capabilities of each integration point. 

My assumption would be that you either have Syteline, Visual, or one of the old versions of BAAN. This MES capability would not be relevant for these systems as the PDF is specifically targeted for Infor LN. For each of these systems, you might have different capabilities, integrations, or systems available depending upon the version, market share, and deployment method, etc. Once you tell us a little about your current ERP product, I will be more informed with my commentary.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
If I were you, I would start with the current architecture diagram and identify the role and responsibilities of each of the systems in the as-is state. 

Once you have that down, document all your needs, especially the business drivers, on why you are doing whatever you are trying to do. Then document the to-be state with each of the old systems identified, their roles and responsibilities documented in the new state, and then assess how each of the MES systems you highlighted would help you accomplish your goals. 

Identify the systems that are pre-integrated with your new architecture and do a solid gap analysis of each of the combinations. How much dev? How much integration? How much testing of the existing process flows as when you touch a wall in your house, you are likely to bring the roof down if not planned well? Once you have that down, then analyze which would be the cheapest and least risky path that your executives might be able to chew. 

Or your project might always remain a dream.

Basically, these decisions are not as binary as you would think. We are talking about the interconnectivity of very, very complex systems. So it can't be Ignition vs FactoryStudio. It has to be what's most relevant based on your budget, size, and systems in your current architecture.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
While I agree with the overall intent of this message, I would be careful in providing blanket recommendations for Infor. Some Infor products have very deep manufacturing functionality, but others are equally terrible.

Even though Infor might be commercializing some of the products as their own, it does not mean that they will always be complementary. Even the acquired products may never get the common data model or be integrated as other mainstream products due to the lack of market and revenue share and therefore lack of funding in supporting those products and integrations.

Even if you opt for Infor, the products are likely to be integrated as you would integrate a third-party product like Ignition. So it will feel as if it's a different product. Not all add-ons or integrated products will be buried inside ERP as the native functionality.

Also, keep in mind that while Infor OS looks technically very strong on paper, it's one of the most poorly documented iPaaS with very little training available for developers. In fact, when you raise these questions to Infor support, they will struggle to answer as well. While Infor OS is free and bundled as part of the product, you get what you pay for. Infor ERP products are the only ones that have really great training and documented screens etc. 

As long as, you have clear boundaries of the systems and not overengineering any of the systems or integrations and integrating with APIs, etc, you should be able to integrate a third-party MES system or find something that is already pre-integrated.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @samguptawbsrocks, you just advanced to level 5!

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: I would highly recommend reviewing this review since you are exploring the offerings around Infor. We have reviews for other solutions and vendors as well on the same channel. Happy to provide the links if it helps. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=agfjDg7Yh2Q

Author: john_cindrich
Content: @samguptawbsrocks @js  Thank you both for taking the time to share your advice! There is a lot there so I'm going to take a bit of time to review it in depth. Very valuable information and I appreciate it.

Author: grahamimmerman
Content: for any of you who missed it, our "Death of MES (as we know it)" panel can now be watched on youtube! Over a thousand people were there live and over 3000 registrants for the event. Tons of great questions and conversation, hope you all enjoy: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5DR3IZ0ok6w

Author: arnesvendsen
Content:
I joined the first 30 minutes and then dropped out.  It is easy to talk down on so called monolitic MES systems. I think the panel was four great guys from some definitely clever start-ups. It is like, many new players come into the manufacturing space with offerings to "collect data to actionable info". That what they all talk about. 
YES, is it relative just-go-do to collect data & stack them in a purdue-tree-structure somewhere.  BUT, the real hard work in the plant floor is the "E" in MES == Execution and realtime coordination across dozens of PLC/devices. Order/recipe/batch control with automated processes - mixed with manual workflow operator processes. 
This execution part of MES "being close to and integrated with the SCADA/PLC control - THIS is the heart of the factory - cannot ever stop working. 
And for this, I still trust the more mature MES systems.  I dont see a scalable Wonderware MES system as monolitic (it MAY be expensive, but thats an other discussion)   Function per function - of course you can always find some other better software piece out there.  
UNS/MQTT etc "modern" models and interfaces DO make it possible to introduce more applications/more interfaces, than we would like in the old days - 3 years ago - but I would still be careful in opening the ball completely with too many applications in the same factory - which was some of my take-aways from the call. The guys did their best, but we have to respect the complexity out there..

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
I am going to have to agree with this comment. While you can talk about the greatness of your solution, It's never cool to disparage the competition or competing solutions, especially when you are trying to challenge something that might still have a larger market share than your newly coined idea. 

Also, unless I misheard something, I found some comments amusing in the recording, especially from Ryan Chan. I believe that he tried to claim that the analytics layer such as Power BI or Tableau is the source of truth. As far as, my understanding of the source of truth goes, that's not how sources of truths are supposed to work. The source of truth belongs to the operational repository that are controlling your transactions. For products etc, it might be ERP. For customers, sometimes it could be CRM. For shopfloor-specific datasets, you will have either MES or your internal database depending upon your architecture.

It's kind of interesting that the people who are trying to challenge the integrated solutions don't even have the fundamentals of integration down.

Author: billbither4379
Content: I haven't reviewed all of the comments, but in talking with Ryan, he means the source of truth is the data warehouse. An ERP could be that data warehouse. Or it could be a unified namespace. Doesn't really matter. Power BI and Tableau are great at reporting on this data when the built-in reports don't cut it, or the data is coming from multiple sources of truth. I don't see any comments that I made (or have been making) as disparaging to competition. If I did - it was not my intension. Merely expressing that we are starting to see the industry changing based on what we we seeing directly in front of us (fragmentation of the market, failed implementations) and more manufacturers choosing vertically integrated SaaS solutions to solve some of the MES problems.

Author: billbither4379
Content: I think you missed the best part of the conversation! The "HOW" is the hardest part. We have gaps, there are tools. Which is better, hiring an outside consultant, or building it internally? There is no right or wrong answer, but we are starting to see an alternative. There is one thing that I'd say most existing MES systems have right. Leave the connectivity to another product. You wont find  MES systems that also are good at connectivity. It's just too hard to do both. But should the MES also have accounting built-in when we have such great horizontal tools used by millions of companies? What about e-commerce? List goes on.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
I think we have discussed this before. There are a lot of layers to his commentary, and some of it could be confusing the way you guys are using terms such as "data warehouse" and "source of truth" interchangeably. Even in this comment, the way you have used the "data warehouse" term could be misleading. Here is one article that describes data warehouse, 
 Source of Truth (SOT), and System of Record (SOR) in great detail. https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/difference-between-system-record-source-truth-santosh-kudva/

Traditionally (speaking in lay terms), you had two databases due to the limitations of database technologies: 1) OLTP 2) OLAP. Even today, the fundamentals are the same when you have multiple systems in the architecture as the system of record, unless you are using some of the technologies such as Snowflake that might NOT require moving your data to a different database before you could use them. Even HANA from SAP seems to claim to do this that you no longer require OLAP in the architecture. While it can help with superior embedded analytics as part of transactions, I have not seen OLAP to be completely gone with HANA. Also, just a little bit of caution, while I understand Snowflake at a conceptual level, I have personally never been involved with implementations utilizing Snowflake in the architecture, so I am not entirely sure how the architecture would work in practice.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Now let's review the role of OLAP and OLTP. The whole idea of OLAP was to move data to a place in the flattened structure where it's easier to consume for analytics or reporting. Some companies even convert this into the NoSQL data structure as it is friendlier for reporting, and you don't require the same degree of transactional integrity in the OLAP database as you would in OLTP. Also, OLAP was created to avoid any performance issues with your OLTP datastore. Even if your OLAP goes down, who cares? It's not as important as your OLTP database as it is not affecting your transaction processing. Traditionally OLAP has always been delayed, and even today, most companies don't require real-time reporting. They are fine with near real-time. But they can't afford to have their OLTP go down as that would mean that they are not able to book sales order, not able to create production order, not able to pick/pack/ship, and finally not able to cut the invoice--which is typically the bread and butter for most companies.

Now when you claim that ERP as a data warehouse and technologies such as Power BI and Tableau are helping with a source of truth, you are almost implying that you are talking about the analytical side of the problem. While you need the complete object for both transaction processing and analytical reporting, as far as the scope of integration goes, the source of truth for the analytical data warehouse is irrelevant.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Now let's talk about the source of truth for transactional processing. This is where the pool is WAY deeper in getting the transactional consistency and integrity across the systems as more systems you have in your architecture that are likely to keep fragments of your business objects, the more planning you need to do in terms of which system is responsible for keeping which bit of information and which one to trust when there is a conflict. 

The more systems you add to the architecture, the more failure points you will have, the more work the systems need to perform during the transaction, which will delay the cycle time of your core transactions. It might mean sales orders taking 2x to close or to release a production order as it needs to do more work in combining the fragmented bits of information and reconciling before you have the state of a business object that can be trusted to process your transaction. And once you have updated your transaction, if there are any changes to the core object and you again need to go back to each system and ensure the business object is updated in each system to ensure transactional integrity in the next transaction. While this might appear easy on paper, it gets really hard when you have multiple systems hitting millions of transactions and trying to get the attention of your transactional system. Once you have a queue built up, even because of one issue, most other systems will start failing, and the problem might become even worse.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
This is why it's always important to minimize the system footprint as much as possible and reduce the number of systems that touch your core transactions in any shape or form. This is also the reason why 50% of the market share of enterprise software vendors is still controlled by the ERP vendors and ERP install base, and it is growing at an exponential rate. While SAAS applications are great and have a role to play, the integrated SAAS applications being used as core ERP or for transaction processing will never work in practice. 

By the way, this is exactly what Infor (that you seem to hate) tried to do in 2002 and that you are trying to champion in 2022. The whole premise of Infor was that I am going to get a bunch of really sharp financial people from private equity and going to buy every SMB ERP and point solution and will try to offer packaged and integrated applications served by Infor OS. Well, this is great, but when you are going to get integration and design issues due to SOT conflicts, there is only so much Infor can do. While Infor has come a long way in testing their integrations and are one of the best, the experience will never be the same as you would get from products that were designed from scratch and that rely on the database layer for reconciliation like SAP, Acumatica, or Plex as opposed to the integration/no-code layer. This is exactly what other enterprise vendors are doing right now. They are trying to create pre-baked integration using some sort of iPaaS either owned by them or through a third party, whether you talk about Epicor, ECi, IFS, or Aptean.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I was watching this question was curious how it would be answered.  I know nothing about Tulip.  I'm reaching around in the dark.  But, I figured I'd jump to induce more conversation.  I'm looking into this because I've gotten very curious about this platform.  It comes up more and more.  I have not figured out a clear idea what its role is alongside a well-implemented SCADA, MES, and ERP.  

Here's how I would approach this historian question.  First, I'm surprised something like this does not exist natively and why an external historian is required.  I would imagine this would counterintuitive and source of friction for the intended demographic of tulip.  The Tulip's Edge IO interface product has use cases of logging analog inputs similar to the way a PLC and SCADA would.

Does the 'Digital History Record' module meet your needs?  If not, why?  Is it a relational backend and not performant for time series data?

Tulip apparently has MQTT, SQL, and HTTP interfaces.  If you had to hook up a historian, you could probably do it a few ways.  Without knowing all the details of how the data acquired, I will assume the process value has made it's way into Tulip (even if it's not necessarily required that it originates there).  You could have Tulip publish the value to a topic in an MQTT broker.  A historian, such as Canary, could subscribe to the topic and historize the process values.  To review the data, Tulip's SQL client could query the time series through Canary's ODBC connector.  Alternatively, Tulip could probably read/write to Canary via Canary's HTTP-based APIs.  Lastly, it would be a question of how/where to display the time series graphs on a Tulip screen.

https://tulip.co/library/apps/digital-history-record/

https://support.tulip.co/en/articles/2221480-how-to-write-a-sql-connector-function

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
We're using Tulip at work. It KIND OF has some historian capability but nothing like Canary. It's a fairly young company and is still going through some growing pains. For instance, for analytics you can choose machine state data or application/table data, but you can't mix data from the two. I believe this is primarily because the machine data table is a noSQL (MongoDB perhaps?) and the application tables are SQL based. There are plans to unify them but it hasn't happened yet in version 6. Maybe by version 7 approximately a year from now.

Also, it doesn't support MQTT directly and I've called them on this before. I believe they are claiming MQTT via Kepserver which is what almost everyone uses to collect machine data from CNCs and PLCs, etc. And it's really "one way". Tulip uses OPC/UA to suck in everything from Kepserver. 

I think we really need to understand what the OP meant by saying "integrate". You could have Canary or Ignition or Factory Studio or <insert platform here> get the data from Kepserver the same way Tulip does. If you're talking about data collected from within Tulip which is part of the main data tables, things get a little more tricky. You can use the NodeRed query nodes but I think you're limited to 100 records per query, probably the same via the REST interface.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: I feel that something that doesn't inherently support batch context, or even simple event framing (inherently marking when an event or process started and ended) requires tons of customization and in the long term isn't easily supportable and scalable.  Being able to relate discrete data to time series data is capability that set the legacy historian companies like OSI and Aspen apart in pharma manufacturing, and something that we've replicated at Quartic.ai in a more modern platform.  I'm sure others will get there in due time.

In looking at their marketing and support content online, I suspected there were some discontinuities.  I kept wondering why NodeRed was frequently used as the "glue" to extend the product.

These are some major limitations.  But, I can see why the product is successful.  It looks a hell of a lot of easier to stand up and use than a SCADA and MES.  The UX looks great.  It looks like it solve a lot of practical problems in manufacturing.  It would be cool if something like this were embedded into one the major MES products.  One typically must "extend" the MES with a SCADA or HMI to create these efficient interfaces for operations.  It can be too much for smaller orgs with less technical resources.

Author: arnesvendsen
Content:
Happy New Year to Everyone here on Discord !
On the ISA88/95 synch.  – Yes I agree with @RickBullotta – the short answer is “ask Dennis Brandl” who is man in the middle of both standard efforts, still today, 25 year later.
Just these days, there is a call by ISA for people who want to look into a revision of ISA88, so if you have the time and the patience it takes .. (I don't)
My view of ISA88: 
It has two equally important parts:  
A)    The automation/PLC module structure:   UM – EM – CM (unit, equipment, control module).  I think more or less every PLC-program in the world follow this structure anyway, as its just common good sense. This way of thinking – including the sequences & state machines, typically built into the equipment modules – this is useful in ANY automation, not just in batch processes. 
B)    The Recipe/Batch part of ISA88 which defines very clearly Formula(=BOM) and Recipe procedures: This part is quite closely adopted in the Batch “engines” such as Emerson, Siemens, WW-Inbatch etc.. Not so many sites use this part, and this is the part overlapping to ISA95 by the way.. 

When I started the DT at Arla Foods  in 2002’ish, I realized that out of 65 factories, only a handful of had the business complexity, demanding a full blown Batch-execution system. So I let these few sites in peace, to run with Inbatch and similar batch engines, already in place. In favour to help the other many sites having nothing..
From 2005-18, where we implemented 50+ sites with MES, I went for the ISA95 model. As we had chosen Wonderware MES as the platform, all I had to do was convince WW to develop a 95-structure MES-traceability database. 
The solution (still in play on all sites and kept updated), is collecting order/batch/traceability data in uniform way – easy to pass on to SAP.
We had to build our own Recipe system on top of WW platform, so we made a 95-structured Recipe database with segments, material and equipment specs etc..

Author: arnesvendsen
Content:
...
Actually we built most of the MES components. You will end up with a lot of code anyway, so choose a MES/IIoT system, that allow for decent (.net/python) coding, NOT proprietary “scripting language” 

NB: The batch engines are really clever applications and often very clean ISA88, but they are rare animals, here in Denmark there would be 5 guys, competent in Inbatch, choose something more mainstream .. 
I don’t know if this makes sense or not – so back to the start of this post – I do think, we should have a youtube with Walker and Dennis Brandl on the call. @zackscriven

Author: lukesmaul
Content:
GE (I know, I know, boo GE) actually created a very cool Intellution iBatch (aka Proficy Batch) to Plant Applications interface.
It took the iBatch event files and parsed them into MES events so you could do things like batch to batch comparisons at the recipe step level. 
It also automagically created your S95ish plant model for you in Plant Aps.
I became intimately familiar with the interface about 12yrs ago when I had to rewrite all the sprocs from SQL to Oracle. I was then able to create OEE metrics from the batch data. 
It was a cool implementation but after owning an iBatch system for Pfizer I’d never wish the software on anyone (sorry Gary Howard in case he’s on here 😂)

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: At OSI (boo OSI?) it was done a bit differently than GE, where the original PI Batch Subsystem originally could only consume S88 (from  any OpenBatch BES like IBatch or DeltaV Batch (boo Emerson)) or create a virtual S88 model with an internal interface and triggers.  When PI Batch moved to PI Event Frames many customers wanted to consume S95 Equipment models and recipe instructions from the MES and link them to the S88 events, but due to the systems being GxP it became cumbersome as a brownfield conversion (besides being technically difficult).  I would not necessarily recommend the full S88 control modules in an MES, but systems that can consume and merge S95 and S88 hierarchies and events and combine them with time series data for reporting and analytics are very valuable.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: That makes a ton of sense. If I recall correctly, the tricky part was agreeing what a s88 event meant in the S95 world especially when reporting on things like OEE. I do remember when we got it right though things like investigation times for  Manufacturing Incident Reports (MIRs) went from hours/days searching in historian and EBRs to minutes in the new MES reporting engine.

Author: jbonhage155

This is a great article you have posted. I'm just starting to learning about OLAP analysis... below is another good refererce for all wanting to learn more.
https://www.sqlservercentral.com/articles/dax-for-sql-folks-part-i-intro-to-dax-power-bi-and-data-viz

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Jon, there are way too many layers in this discussion. And it seems all over the place.

The source of truth is relevant for each data set. And  the datasets could belong to any of the departments. Then you have operational/transactional datasets and analytical datasets, which tend to behave differently. The people who only worked on the analytical layer seem to think that the transactional layer doesn't matter at all. And just because the analytical layer might be slightly easier to program and could be faster, it's by no means a replacement of the transactional layer. In the traditional sense, we had two datastores, OLAP and OLTP, which both served different functions.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
And they both were required in the architecture. Keep in mind though, your OLAP doesn't exist, until you have your OLTP down. So the source of truth is far more important in the OLTP layer than in your OLAP layer. Sometimes, they might share the source of truth. But since your OLTP layer is doing the heaviest lifting in the org, you want to make sure you are treating it super well and not overloading it with the unnecessary workload.  You want to remove the study as much as possible from your core transactions. Remember, while a little bit of reflection and strategy may be required during the game, you don't want to be studying during the game.
That brings me to the point that you might want to think of this as if preparing for a game vs actually playing the game. While preparing is imp, it's not as imp as the actual game. Just because the prep might feel easy and you might be allowed to be a little creative, it's not a replacement for the actual game itself. 

Yet another way to think about it would be to think of insert vs select statements in SQL. They both serve different purposes. The insert would be more of your transactions and select would be more analytical or study layer.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Now to your point about where Snowflake fit in the architecture.

Traditionally when you think of OLAP and OLTP, you needed to move data from your operational datastore as it would overload the operational system, which is a big no-no in the enterprise architecture. So, what companies did is that they moved the data to a quieter where no one may be watching them, flattened the data for analytical needs as the analytical dataset doesn't need to be as relational. Some companies even converted it into the NoSQL datasets as that's designed for faster analytical processing, but by no means is it a replacement for the relational or operational data store. And then they put a lot of data science/AI/ML on top of it to get the trends and insights they needed from data. 

Now to transfer this massive data in a batch form without bothering your operational system as much, you needed a tech that was designed for bulk data move that could work during the night when everyone else was sleeping and operational datastore was not as angry as it would be during day time. And this is where ETL played the role. ETL was a gold mine for SIs like Accenture or IBM, as while the ERP implementation etc might last for a few months or years, the ETL and analytics layer has far more unique needs for each company. So they literally camped out inside the company to build data warehouses and ETL layer.

Now the only thing Snowflake has changed in the architecture is that you don't need to move your data from the source as its tech didn't affect the operational data store as much as the traditional databases. So now with Snowflake, you don't need the ETL layer anymore (at least, technically), which is a huge cost saving for the companies and that's why Snowflake is such a massive hit.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
I like to think of UNS as "rich people's problem" as at least I have not seen the good, bad, and ugly from the architectural standpoint. So, unfortunately, I don't have enough data points to be able to comment. But the overarching concept of UNS is not new. Traditionally, there have been three ways of performing message-based integrations 1) synchronous/point-to-point 2) asynchronous but still linear 3) event-based architecture. 

The event-based architecture exists even among most programming languages and most enterprise systems nowadays as linear processing is rarely enough to accommodate today's business needs. If you pay attention to .Net or Javascript, they all support events. Traditionally only front-end technology supported event-driven programming as the backend didn't need to be as dynamic. But things changed and now most programming languages support event-driven programming backend and front end.

Just the way, programming languages would support these events INSIDE a system, the idea of event-driven integration is similar but it's outside the system boundaries. And it's designed to integrate the systems and not to build the system. When you talk about the integration of transactional/operational systems, ETL is not a right fit as it's designed for bulk data movement from database to database. iPaaS would be the right fit to connect all your transactional/business systems but it's not going to have message-driven capabilities as it's designed to be very asynchronous and linear in nature. This is where a lot of systems such as Tibco Business Events played the role as they provided that event-driven glue to connect all different systems. But as the name reads, the idea here  was for business events. The purpose of it wasn't for the operational events.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: Now what UNS is trying to do is for the operational events similar to business events, which obviously is a different beast due to the nature of datasets and amount of data you need to collect for these operational events. It also connects hardware. So obviously, that's far bigger in scope than any business events technology. Unfortunately, I am not in a position to predict where this all will land, and if we will ever have SuperUNS or operations folks taking over the enterprise. 😆  But as far as my understanding goes, they all will co-exist in the architecture as they all have a role to play. But the scope of UNS would be limited to the operational datasets and not to the enterprise datasets. Operational datasets are typically too-much-information at the enterprise level.

Author: rushi07688
Content:
What is fundamentally different in EAM, CMMS and MES.?
If you go by the definition they seem to cater to same purpose. Right?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: A CMMS is an MES function (work order management). An EAM has a CMMS as a component, but also includes enterprise data about the asset. https://www.upkeep.com/answers/maintenance-software/eam-or-cmms-systems

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
EAM is often fancier word for CMMS.  CMMS is kind of an old-school term.  I don't know if it's just me, but I think it's silly to call something "Computerized".  EAM is theoretically broader, but I don't know why one would want CMMS instead of EAM even for one site.  All of these are software for running a maintenance department.

MES is running a production (and associated) departments.  As the name implies, it's for executing the production plan.

Examples:
-Production activity gets recorded with an MES
-Inventory is processed and/or managed with MES (and sometimes WMS or ERP)
-Repair activity for machines is managed with the CMMS/EAM
-A catalog and inventory of spare parts will be in the CMMS/EAM
-The list and progress of scheduled production (e.g., work orders, jobs, kanban) will be in the MES
-Managing a changeover on a line will be done with the MES

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
There is a lot of overlap with EAM, ERP, and MES. Traditionally, these systems were not integrated and CMMS/EAM was sold standalone. But nowadays, a lot of manufacturing solutions might have EAM functionality fully integrated with the ERP. MES may have partial functionality as well. The trick is always in how you would make these systems work together for your process.

I would love to know a little bit about the source of truth in this architecture and what datasets will be flowing back and forth between systems:

-Inventory is processed and/or managed with MES (and sometimes WMS or ERP)
If the source of truth is ERP for the core inventory datasets, MES might process the inventory as it moves through the production process. But managing inventory inside MES. Are you serious?

-Repair activity for machines is managed with the CMMS/EAM
Agreed. So what datasets does EAM consume from ERP when not pre-integrated as these are financial assets that must be managed inside ERP?

-A catalog and inventory of spare parts will be in the CMMS/EAM
Are you talking about just the MRO items or anything else? The core inventory must be stored inside ERP.

-The list and progress of scheduled production (e.g., work orders, jobs, kanban) will be in the MES
Agreed. Yes MES will consume the job orders and schedule from ERP and process as instructed by the ERP.

-Managing a changeover on a line will be done with the MES
Agreed

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Great insights Sam, much appreciated!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I cited examples in the guise of differentiating MES and CMMS/EAM.  Rushi is a student learning about manufacturing technology.  This wasn't a detailed discussion on architecture and integration.  Generally, I prefer full-suite ERPs for the very reasons you asked those questions.  It has superior module-by-module integration.

I was trying to illustrate the point that one might work with core inventory in an MES, but definitely not in a CMMS.  Some MES firms offer inventory management modules.  It's usually not full-blown capability of well-known WMS or manufacturing ERP solutions.  I've seen these used in the context of meeting specific traceability requirements that an incumbent ERP may not.  In an ISA95 context, you're right, this is technically level 4 and ERP.  But, in the product marketplace, the lines between MES/MOM and ERP offerings can be blurry.

Regarding spare parts, yes, I was referring to just MRO.  Maintenance applications will often have their own inventory management system.  In a full-suite ERP context, I've often seen maintenance modules "share" with the same inventory engine that might also manage supplies consumed in production.

Author: philseboa

It’s when you get to high availability or redundancy situations that the Ignition pricing isn’t clear.  And some clarification (more details) as to what is in each item on the price list (particular the edge stuff - not clear which features are in what and how they all fit together).  Lastly, it’s not clear if optimal modules are per server, per site, and also how they fit into high availability/redundancy pricing.

When it comes to complex architecture, this is where it helps to discuss whats required with someone like us as there are a few different ways to create the structure to optimise for scaling.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I used to be in sales as an account exec at Wonderware and I remember the massive spreadsheet I needed to do a quote (or ask a distributor to do it).  Glad you’re simplifying it all dramatically!

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
This video on MES mentions some of the core things that an MES does, but leaves out some important things.
- Recipe Management - MES is typically the source of manufacturing recipes (or Standard Operating Conditions and Procedures). It's where you define HOW stuff should be made at a level of detail that makes sense to your equipment
- Quality Management - When the MES is the source of recipes, monitoring the process to ensure it stays within acceptable quality limits, and managing the workflow of quality deviations.
- Inventory Tracking - Creating the links between actual raw materials used and the batch/lot/unit produced on an order, along with the time-series process conditions that the order was produced under, and any exceptions or deviations that may have occurred while that production order was being produced.

OEE is generally the first step, but rarely the full vision for MES.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Although those are very “vertical specific”. The requirements across the spectrum of discrete to batch to hybrid to process are quite different as you know.  A recipe is as irrelevant to an automotive plant as an engineering drawing change is to a beverage plant or a schedule is to a refinery that produces the same thing 24x7x365.  Historically MES applications and frameworks tend to fit tightly within a couple verticals.  What works well for making planes might not be suitable for pet food.  And making gasoline is quite different from making biological pharmaceuticals.  At one point I think there were 14 or so identified subverticals for MES.  I’ll see if I can dig that doc up.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
100% agree that there are different areas of focus across verticals, and it's very difficult to build a front-end application that tries to be all things to all people. (SAP ECC6 is a great example. It does everything but you need your whole career to figure out how to make it do anything)
I do believe this is the major driving force for a "Headless MES". Honestly, the backend is not significantly different between verticals. Automotive plants have recipes. Those recipes might look different to a beverage plant recipe in the front-end application, but the backend is the same. A standard backend data model can happily cover both (Libre as a back-end serves recipe management for Beverage plants, Automotive Parts Manufacturing and serialised discrete plants, as will as pharma batch based processing)

Author: nickn5549
Content: Haven't seen any MES to include Maintenance/Calibration Work Orders and normally they all have an asset register in them...

Author: nickn5549
Content: What type of database is better for MES backend?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I will clarify. A CMMS is a Level 3 function. Most MES suites focus on the manufacturing side, not the maintenance side, which is why you don't see that as a part of it.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think it's useful to distinguish between where things technically reside in an ISA context vs the "blurry" reality of the automation market.  In general, it's easier for software firms to "expand" than it is to "land".  It's lower cost to capture incremental revenue with complementary products from an existing customer than it is to forge a new relationship all together.  This is especially the case at the lower end of the market where manufacturers may not necessarily have a holistic approach to their technology and business processes.  They may be content automating one thing and leaving everything else as ad-hoc manual processes.  They either don't know better or they're not at a scale where inefficiencies are apparent yet.  If they don't elect to stand up disparate point solutions without an integration strategy, they'll seek an offering that can be bundled with something that they have.  Either way, the goal will be low-cost and low-sophistication.

This is why there is a lot of "shop floor" software with all sorts of modules that may not be necessarily classified the way an integrator or architect would.  They're marketed to family businesses.  This is not a market that specs "I need best-in-class technology to architect and run my business processes at Level 3 MES/MOM."  In reality, the idea is to market a "one-stop shop" for everything a smaller firm may need regardless of how well it actually works.  The prospects might initially seek certain core manufacturing capabilities but might eventually use complementary functionality (e.g., Maintenance, Time & Attendance) to drive their selection criteria.  This plays into the whole "solution-centered" mantra discussed in this community.  Sales and marketing teams at software firms exploit this.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is a great point about backend processes not being dramatically different.  One of the most common pain points I've seen with MES is not necessarily how it processed data, but the interface.  It can be either too little or too much for something that must be used over-and-over again for a specific purpose.  The front-end can make a material difference in the day of the life of someone that must use an application several hours each day.

Related discussion on augmenting MES with SCADA interfaces:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/740336189449699408/824975438697857065

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Very true.  I know of an ERP that had, at one point, 300+ different configurations for order management.  There was so much redundancy.  It got to a point where each complex implementation would involve copying a favored config and then customizing it to the customer requirements.  It was absolutely insane sorting out the differences.

A lot of times this is driven by customer requirements/customizations instead of a product management function consolidating the requirements into a manageable of set of extensible configurations.  Order management is something that always seems to be treated as an overly unique requirement, but I think part of the issue is customers don't necessarily convey requirements similarly and those that implement don't pick up on the patterns.  There is a tendency to constantly reinvent the wheel.  It takes a lot of experience and exposure to different verticals to avoid this.  At some point, the technical debt grows so large that it's like project/career suicide to take it on.

Author: chrisbixler
Content: Hi All - Still new to the discord group and learning where to navigate to. @Brian Pribe pointed me here to share my MES stories. I have been part of multiple MES systems but my first experience was the most interesting. It functioned as a full fledged ERP/SCADA system. It was called TotalTrac and was on the java platform and had a SQL backend. It did everything from receiving product through shipping and invoicing. At the end of every month, it would create a flat csv file that was sent to accounting for upload into Microsoft Dynamics. It had barcoding on the shop floor and recipe control. I think it was ahead of its time. I often wonder why you don't see more MES/SCADA systems so you could build out a better scheduling tool.

Author: chrisbixler
Content: The last product I worked with was JD Edwards Enterprise 1 and it had almost no MES capabilities. I was pushing our company corporate office for a MES overlay so production could better complete tasks. The number of computer clicks an associate had to make to enter a step of a work order was crazy. It was all in the name of corporate cost accounting. What is everyone else's experience with MES?

Author: brianpribe
Content: Why did accounting want it month by month?

Author: chrisbixler
Content: They thought it was too hard to import on a daily basis. They thought there would be too much error. So 1 upload per month was purely to guard against error. I don't think it was a great way to do it but these are some of the things small companies still deal with. I worked for another company that used Microsoft word to write job recipes and stored everything in quickbooks. They used sign off sheets to confirm things shipped to be invoiced.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Oof. Yeah I worked for an integrator that still did everything manual. RFQ, PO, Invoice, Shipping, everything.

Author: mlstaunton
Content: I'm establishing an enterprise solution design for #mes for my organization (metals industry) where we're building on the vision of an integrated stack  of Data Hub (Cloud) > ERP > MES > and with significant tech/app. diversity in the SCADA and PLC/HMI layers.  The challenge I'm trying to solve is how to best manage the interfacing complexity between MES and the SCADA/PLC layers.  My initial thought is something akin to a ESB/service bus to  map standard messaging from MES (like a schedule, backlog, PDI) to each end point/target in L2 - with a goal that is two fold: 1) not customize my multi-plant MES application end-point; and 2) establish a pub/sub messaging (broker capability) as needed to multiple consuming sources (1:n).  Based on my preliminary analysis - enterprise class solutions for ESB seem to be overkill, but MQ solution might not provide robust message mapping or transformation functionality.  Any lessons learned or best practices to share?  Much appreciated in advance.   Cheers!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The complexity of MES <-> SCADA/PLC integration will generally be 99.9% limited by your MES, not your SCADA/PLC system.  Also, if you're mostly just interested in this integration for reporting purposes, you can do that integration "after the fact" with your analytics layer.  If you want to download setpoints/settings and upload actuals, you can either pull or push, depending on your scenarios.

Author: mlstaunton
Content: Thank you, Rick.   So the integration I have in mind is based on standard messaging from MES like the publishing of material identify (what material is available in the production backlog for any given production step) or PDI (which would include equipment-level recipe set points). I have a standard message out of MES (preferably) but the end points are diverse . There are scores of L2 PLCs (different vendors/OEMs) which too often require different message structures - and sometime different protocols.    I want to minimize the customization of the message and its structure at any given endpoint (source or target) - and move the complexity (mapping/transforming)  to a proper mediation layer for the the shop floor.   This is a common pattern among business systems - but I'm curious to know if this is a recommended practice MES-to-shop floor world.

If you don’t have an example for that specifically, I’m also curious about what features or functions an MES software implements well that ultimately drove a business decision to implement over other software vendors evaluated?

Author: marioishikawa
Content: One thing I'd say and that customers ask for and it is very hard to do is to consider that the system will not only be ingesting real time data, but also eventually old data. Let's say, data from yesterday that for some reason could not be retrieved due to network issues. Then you have to recontextualize, like running a backlog of old data to a UNS.

Author: dep05d
Content: Along those lines, one of our biggest struggles over the years has been shift maintenance. Between holidays, training sessions, planned downtime, company picnics, seasonal staffing, or whatever else, shift data is often wrong and we don’t know until the site complains that their daily/weekly kpi’s are inaccurate.  We had to build in a 2 week grace period for historical shift edits , then all the logic to handle late arriving shift adjustments that trigger a wave of historical data updates, which then need to be sync’d with downstream BI tools etc.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Late-arriving data is hard. We built handling for it into Libre so we can go back in time and re-process. This ability also allows us to "Back-test" rules and algorithms against historical data before migrating them into production service

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And anyone who is tracking quality issues accurately (other than those who can do 100% inline inspection) will frequently need to post date and assign quality defects.  Though most don’t.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: It's not just those use-cases. More and more we get into algorithm style applications that need to be back-tested over historical data. When you build these types of apps, you expect that the use-cases you need to cover exist in the historical dataset, so you test the model until it works, and then let it run. Then you encounter a new edge-case that has never occurred before. Now you need to change the algorithm and re-test it over historical data.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yup - I see that as a slightly different scenario though - playback vs late arriving data.  Lots of similarities for sure. But some datastores really sh*t the bed when trying to store late data due to the way they shard or index the data.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: What we see is that customers are more demanding and they care less and less about the internal limitations. Does a job need a correction? They don't expect just to correct the final number, but also the charts for hourly production, which requires an aggregation different the the simple totalization on the job. And then comes OEE, that must match not only for that job, but for the shift, day and week, and so on.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: Production data edits are always a bear to manage. We typically work with end users to put processes in place for editing data routinely, usually around when data is consumed in reports: (shift / day / week / etc…)

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Thats only really a problem if your system does not scale, and your forced to persist your calculations, or if your architecture cant handle event chaining for calculation updates. With a solid architecture, late arriving data is no problem.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: What I mean is, is not easy to do that if you did not plan it beforehand. There are several ways to do it  but as you mentioned before, it is hard to do. It adds a good complexity to the system (in a good way). So far I found no better way than to also reprocess the entire chain of events also.

for example:
- we have an "activity" called ignition_on, which has start & stop triggers (JS functions checked against each state)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Joe, almost NO ONE supports SpB.  There's a lot of mythology out there regarding how widely adopted it actually is.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I've been speaking with a lot of vendors who have told me that they have very little customer demand for SpB support, FWIW.  That might simply be because they're working with customers who have a lot of legacy, or maybe it's just because only a handful of smaller players support it natively.  Or because it doesn't meet their functional requirements.  Hard to say.  It would be a worthwhile study for one of the analyst firms to really pick it apart and get some hard data.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And lastly, you'd be doing your company a great disservice by putting technology decision criteria ahead of functional and economic decision criteria.  Your users have a business need to solve, and could likely care less if it's written in Cobol or Erlang, whether it support SpB or XYZ if it meets their needs, is cost effective, quick to deploy and learn, and "just works".

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: There is a separate MQ category for this.  I believe it's called IoT Platforms.  This is just the MES segment.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Agreed.  This has been greatly exaggerated.  This is about the same for OPC-UA or really any other protocol at the MES or ERP layer.  Even B2MML.  Most the integrations are native HTTP-based APIs for various methods (e.g., add inventory, record production activity, log asset event).  Most of these IoT protocols are for telemetry.  This works reasonably well for a dashboard or a historian, but not necessarily an MES.  Most MESs do not intake raw data, but specific transactions derived from raw data.

Sure, SAP has some OPC-UA interfaces.  But, almost no one is going feed "Data Access" straight off of PLC tags into the MES or ERP.  It's huge misnomer that an OPC-UA device sitting at the Edge is plug-n-play with SAP.  The data is going to be acquired and contextualized with a SCADA or integration platform before any transactions happen.  Most demos I've seen involve method calls.  What these demos don't disclose is that they require elaborate reprogramming of the asset's controls and development of very bespoke OPC-UA Servers and Clients.  It's significantly more work than having a modern SCADA or integration platform execute API calls based off of tag values coming from assets.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Do you use AD? Access groups in AD can be structured however you want. What I've found important is to give users a common user and password to access everything...if each system has different credentials and they have to remember all these and also remember their Windows credentials....then problems start. Either they don't use some of the systems or save credentials in the browser everywhere (we have about 500 terminals in manufacturing) and basically, security is none/voided.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Wherever is applicable, yes - UNS, ERP, MES, Production Schedule, CMMS, etc. Smaller Apps that deal with a single area like eIQC (Incoming Inspection), Check-in, eTraining (more has to do with Departments/Teams)  not really.

Author: nickn5549
Content: The main thing is operators can do ALL their work from a single screen (you know, that thing smartphone for business), now is more to unify also the backend...get to the MOS as Libre is calling it.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Started this thing 10 years ago, and now the work is to align it to the MOS (Manufacturing Operating System) concept. Which, I think, MOS is much bigger than UNS or just an MQTT Broker.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Some of the apps in the Dashboard are already benefiting from the UNS/MQTT/Node-Red intelligence (my micro-MOS) and are updated automatically with critical information from other systems. Like Production Schedule - linked to MES (our MES came without a Prod Sch), CMMS and bots raising alerts/notifications for products that are 'problematic' based on historical records - quality, size (fit on the machines), capability (machine on a certain line can't place certain components that a certain product has, and many more in the pipeline). The next thing is a bit of AI, especially for PM and maybe for Quality. And after that change the SMT machines parameters based on feedback from various inspections - SPI, AOI, X-RAY....long way to go. Even big OEMs that are building these machines are still tinkering with this kind of stuff in their own PoCs, nothing released yet that is capable to work cross-vendor and cross-platform.

Author: nickn5549
Content: In a decent size EMS is so much data floating around that can be linked and used by everybody (transparency, data democratisation) to make better, faster decisions.

Author: nickn5549
Content: An example of benefits from the micro-MOS linked to Production Schedule. You don't have to run the Quality reports anymore (in MES, pretty ugly reports and awkward to configure), are run and linked automatically under the MO in the Production Schedule interface. Get a notification and have a look - 10 sec, compared with 10min before the inception of the micro-MOS.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It needs to be far more granular than resource level in my experience.  Also it is often desirable to separate “design time” (editing the configuration) from “runtime”.  Also don’t forget to consider permissions for “systems”, not people (API access) and for those in other organizations that are part of your value chain.  Lastly be sure to deal with issues of token and account expiration.

Author: gregory.g.
Content:
Hi guys. 
I personally would gather data in range of 1-5min to longer cycle times in MES. Today we  focus on relevant performance data for OEE calculations (Production) and HACCP  data for enabling SPC functionality (Quality) within MES. The kind of data that you directly want  to correlate with a manufacturing order. 

Other process (and faster) data for Root Cause Analysis (for process, opex, reliability engineers,...) would go to a dedicated historian with good trending tools.

Keeping system performance in mind, what kind of process data would you rather put in MES versus a dedicated Process Data Historian like Osisoft or Canary? Or would you use the PDH as a main source for everything?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Put transactional data in a true database and cross correlate with historical data using time fences.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: You could use something like Quartic.ai and use its inherent capability to time fence or event frame MES and any other event or transactional data, then use other inherent capabilities to perform reliability analytics, faster root cause analysis, and predictive and prescriptive analytics.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Thanks for sharing this.  This was an interesting read.

I would say Plex would not be in conflict with any Siemens standardization efforts.  There are end-to-end Siemens, Mitsubishi, Fanuc, etc automation shops that use Plex as their ERP and MES.  Plex is exposed through HTTP-based web services and ODBC.  MQTT support is on the roadmap for the Asset Performance Management (ex-DATUS) product.  The native protocols associated the automation products of Rockwell or Siemens (e.g., CIP, S7) are largely irrelevant in this context.  In nearly every case, native protocols get normalized as OPC tags through Kepware, Ignition, Tridium Niagara, etc.  In substance, the only Rockwell part of Plex is the ownership.  Whether you have a plant full of ControlLogix or S7-1500, they're largely going to connect the same way.

While I think it's worthwhile to consider a product's parent entity and how that might impact product investment, it's important to technically assess these solutions.  What's under the hood may not align with what's marketed.  There has been so much consolidation and acquisition in enterprise software.  These large product portfolios are more like a Byzantine Empire than an aligned ecosystem.

Author: gregory.g.
Content: You are right. Plex is actually still a good consideration but we already had 4 in our shortlist. I agree that the MES brand does not matter that much in the end. Although we have a partnership with Siemens, we don't like the MES they are providing. This list is a very rough selection draft.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It depends on what you mean by cloud?  Do you mean SaaS?  Or do you mean deploying an "on-prem" MES on IaaS?

As for SaaS MES, I've been doing it for a while.  The best part is that the more timely product enhancements and that upgrades became a thing of the past.  Also, because it's a service and everyone runs the same version, the vendor and partner/user communities are more engaged.

They're different beasts.  With on-prem MES, you're more likely to see some sort of major disruption (e.g., fragile infrastructure, internal staffing) and slower time to resolution.  With cloud MES, you're more likely to see minor disruptions (e.g., rapid deployment caused a bug, partial performance impact) and faster time to resolution.

Any concerns of cloud pale in comparison to power outages, staffing shortages, asset downtime, process issues, supply chain issues, etc.  Setting aside some data custody issues in regulated industries, I believe most of the concerns over cloud are overstated.  In the end, it's just a different type of distributed architecture.  If one tries to "lift-and-shift" what they've been doing for decades, they're going to come up disappointed.

Firms used to put in a private branch exchange and complex telecom circuits at every site just to make phone calls.  They evolved to using shared services and to even cloud.  The key to the success was not "forklifting" the incumbent solution forward as architecture evolved.

Related discussion:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/740336189449699408/839021799203143700

I know of some customers that use it as a point solution for manual assembly, testing/validation, digital work instructions / guided workflows.  The small customers typically don't have much else.  The bigger customers tend to have larger unwieldy solutions that lacked functionality for specific operational use cases.  It seems like they've pivoted more into a being an MES-like product in recent years.  It reminds me a bit of Tulip, but less customizable and centered on more-specific use cases commonly found in automotive.  Their solutions may have been custom in the past.
