Author: richardlynch
Content:
Hi all, I see MQTT as a good fit for collecting telemetry plant floor data from the MES below ISA 95 L3.5 and getting that data to cloud for Storage/visualisation.

But is MQTT also a fit for integration with L4 site logistics systems or application 2 application integration, or poling external public API's?  EG:
 
a)    Transactional L4 inbound/outbound site logistics
MES integration with onsite weighbridges, security boom gates, number plate recognition.  If MQTT is a fit would a broker instance for same site UCS be deployed at L4 and another broker instance at L3 and have them channel MQTT through he IT/OT DMZ firewall, then have MES pub/sub into MQTT L3. broker.  or is this real time communication of L4 site operational events, , to read from NPR and open boom gates and the like while a truck is waiting, not a good fit for MQTT?

b)    3PL SaaS services
MES integration for booking slots, truck number plates, or notification that an incoming truck delivery has passed a geofence and is 5 minutes away and relay that to the site MES system so it can get ready to receive

c)    Enriching MES system with external data sources 
like public API's to collecting temps from weather services, or pricing from energy providers etc
Can this be done with MQTT platforms only, or are iPaaS solutions like boomi/mulesoft better fit for purpose for those external REST/ or business transactional integration?

Author: mparris
Content: @DavidSchultz

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
There have been many conversations around this topic. Short answer is tools like HighByte Intelligence Hub are used for L3/L4 data. This is done with APIs, SQL queries, etc. One of the missing pieces is message handlers (confirming the intended system received the message). There are ways to address it using MQTT, but my opinion is this is more of a work around.

The big question for MQTT is should this functionality be added to the specification or handled by implementations of it. In other words, keep MQTT as is but tools like IH, Cogent DataHub, Ignition modules expand to support L3/L4.

There are also platforms that support the entire enterprise. There are other technologies used along with MQTT for this. Libre Manufacturing is one of them. I have not looked at UMH, but it appears to be similar. Not only does Libre provide a UNS architecture, it includes and API endpoint and data storage.

The next few years will be interesting for sure as the market coalesces around all the new technology.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
With all these "but MQTT doesn't handle [methods, explicit messages, transactions, etc] well" conversations, it makes me wonder more about AMQP.  Put simply, AMQP is sort of a hybrid of pub/sub and client/server.  It's also capable of more than a "topic-tree" namespace.  It has worked really well as a service bus in other verticals.  Microsoft (along with its partners), having been an active player behind the standard and using it much throughout Azure, has seemed to be the only advocate for AMQP use in the industrial realm.  While it's much more full-featured and flexible, AMQP lacks the simplicity and efficiency that has drove adoption of MQTT in the market.  I can't help but wonder if AMQP could be (or could have been) a useful tool for these challenges further up the stack.

Regardless, the fact that most solutions in the MES and ERP layers are exposed as HTTP-based web services shouldn't change much.  Even if we're not using request/response workarounds with MQTT, we'll still be using protocol workarounds for the application nodes.  While it's certainly easier to adapt like-paradigm protocols (e.g., request/response to request/response), it's still a massive hassle.  I believe that whatever technology or solutions that best minimize this hassle will win out.

In others words, if one can't convince the application providers to natively adopt the technology, they must make it economical for end-users/integrators to adapt their applications themselves.  It really concerns me when we trivialize this part.

Coming from the PLC/controls/SCADA world anything in the cloud scares me (internet goes down, production goes down) ...but maybe the advantages of cloud outweights the risk and your point below is really good---

"Worried about availability?  It’s hard to beat redundant hardware and redundant data centers.  Worried about disruptions from the public cloud?  Bypass it and use more dedicated resources.  Worried about connectivity?  Use diverse fiber, backbone carriers, SD-WAN, BGP, MPLS, etc.  Worried about downtime?  Forge an SLA, develop an outage protocol and leverage store-and-forward at the edge.  Worried about security and compliance?  The provider’s SOC reports will rival what most organizations can offer and attest internally."

Author: akoscs
Content: When I need request reply over mqtt I have my entity who should be the server (in req-repl) subscribe to a topic something like entityname/req. then any entity which wants to req-reply with this entity publishes to this topic but ads a UUID to the request and before publishing, it subscribes to the qtt topic named like that UUID (or repl/UUID or similar). When the entity gets the request over its mqtt subscription it publishes the reply to the topic replies/UUID. Basicaly have a topic to publish a targeted request and add the reply topic name to the request. Worked well in many cases where I would have needed req-reply.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
It took me most of yesterday to work around the fact that you don't have access to the current datetime in Table Analytics. 
We need to know the average age of orders in an area and we have the timestamp when it was received but it hasn't left so there's no end timestamp. I added an "Aging" interval column to the table and then used the Tulip Node Red API to perform the table query, calculation, and then table update. We wanted the result in "days" so I have it running automatically 4x a day to keep it "fresh".

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
@akos I've been using camunda and Zebee for 8 years now and am a big fan of the features. I'm not such a big fan of the java stack, the external dependencies, the need for a postgres database, or the fact that external services are forced to pull their jobs, rather than being event driven.
So we decided to re-write camunda from scratch in golang as a fully cloud-native, event-driven, distributed, high-availability, scalable solution where we have complete control over the code-base.    
We are able to integrate BPMN processes into the Equipment Model, so that the rules for triggering a BPMN process can be defined on an equipment class. Each equipment that belongs to the class then has that functionality. BPMN processes can also be triggered directly through GraphQL.

An example of what you can do with this might be something like scheduling maintenance when pump efficiencies drop below an acceptable level. On the equipment Class for a pump, you could define properties for the pump speed and flow rate, and you can have a calculated property for efficiency (Gallons/Minute/RPM or something similar). You could also have a static property for the acceptable efficiency.
You can then define a rule that say something like "If the efficiency of the pump is below target for 10 mins, trigger the BPMN process CreateMaintenanceRequest". 

We are using NATS for sharing state between BPMN worker nodes and run in Kubernetes, so have access to native load-balancing across services.
As the rest of the platform is GraphQL native ( we forked the Dgraph project earlier this year and have been adding to the functionality of Dgraph to make it do what we want ) it's now easy for us to subscribe to events, define business logic, update the DataHub, call external services and the like.
We are a long way through the development of all of this right now, and will have a release in the first half of 2023.

If you are after manufacturing specific workflow maybe look at www.gotillit.com . We've been live for a few years now with some great case studies from small manufacturing to multi site highly complex environment. I normally don't talk much in this channel since most of you are developers/makers. We deliver something more out of the box. Low code/no code. We had self-deployment done (zero consulting/engineering ) and implementation driven by SI. On top of workflow its a packaged solution including scheduling (with AI optimizer), SOPs, Chat, OEE, Edge solution, two way integration with webhook and mqtt, embedded analytics with dashboard builder, quality management, order execution, track and trace.  All subscription based cloud. We host everything. No installation or infrastructure. 
Not the solution for you to fully custom build a solution or self host. So not for everyone. But we got customers live with scheduling, workflow, sop and dashboards in 6 weeks and now the sme are continuously improving and extending the workflow, no tech skills. All done internally with a team of 3.

Your MES is partially shop floor partially “office” and n my opinion, that is the bridge between enterprise and shop floor functionalities. (Not as architecture, as functionality)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I'm a bit unclear on how much of Libre is open source or not.  Can you clarify?

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
Hi @RickBullotta - the answer to your question is a simple one - Libre no longer exposes, or is likely to ever expose, any open source components.

The why is a bit more nuanced and has two primary parts:

1.  When we started out with Libre,  the thought was that Open Source would be the channel to market that would best serve Manufacturing as a whole while also being a commercially lucrative COSS. We assumed that VCs would be happy to invest because of the incredibly disruptive potential of the platform. That didn't happen. VCs do not see the market as big enough, the problem being new enough and they generally view Libre as just another ERP-type consulting led sale with a multi-year lead time. None of these things are true and so we're happy to bootstrap and use strategic partnerships to do so. Unfortunately, that leads to: 

2. Enterprise customers don't see OSS as a positive and, in reality, probably have much more of a purely negative view. As you well know, developing software (especially with an SDLC to comply with 21 CFR Part 11 / ISO 27001 ) is not cheap. Even if we were a COSS, we would need to drive Enterprise licensing and adjust our roadmap to the wants and needs of those customers in order to underwrite our development costs. It's actually easier to cater to that base if we are not OSS.

The Enterprise view of OSS combined with our choice to bootstrap make the decision to close the codebase a rather straightforward one for us.

However - Not being OSS doesn't mean that Libre is not Open. As a headless backend it's in our best interest to be as open as possible and we do that through our protocols and configuration - MQTT, NATS, GraphQL, etc. and our base schema, which is an open international ISA95 standard. 

Honestly, The Libre Platform as a traditional product, but with an incredible level of openness, is probably much more what the industry needs right now than an accessible codebase.

Author: dvy___
Content: How do you handle extensibility on the backend and database?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
We use the awesome Apollo Federation Router to stitch together different graphql api from different services into a single graphql schema and endpoint. This allows customers to extend the api with their own services without needing to change any of the product code.
The database schema can also be easily extended by adding additional types to the existing schema. This is done via an API call.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Hi Rick, Apollo GraphQL Federation is a bit different to normal query federation, and these differences mean that it does not have the same challenges.
In our stack, we are using a distributed database (our own fork of Dgraph) and federated joins and unions are handled within this distributed database.

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
Hi @Deleted User - thanks for your comment.

In the very first iteration of Libre we developed a stack that consisted of a Grafana dashboard and a series of Camunda workflows and UIs. Those sat on top of an InfluxDB instance with a Postgres DB for context. The data stores were populated by NiFi flows from the plant floor. For what we were doing, it functioned fine and produced the intended output, but it was too much work to change the outputs or add to the system and there was NO WAY the customer was going to be able to maintain it.

What this taught us was that, for the most part, Mfg is not ready for a component-based open source solution because there just aren't enough unicorns to do the work. For every @Deleted User or @akos or @RickBullotta, there are thousands of techs and engineers that want exactly what @jpmoniz described in his post above. "A throat to choke" when it all goes sideways.

Since the status quo of Rockwell, Siemens and AVEVA was (and is) completely untenable, we opted to use our 150 years of collective experience to write the "glue" between the best OSS platforms on the market and that became Libre. Although we quite literally cannot afford to contribute it back to the community because of the cost of dev and maintenance, what we have done is created something that the industry has never seen - Open, headless, infinitely scalable and standardized configuration out of the box with a single access point, federated API and an unlimited use license based on sites. It's certainly a giant step in the right direction.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I’m totally aligned with that approach (commercial wrapper on OSS plus proprietary code). The one thing we also tried to do is to give back to the OSS components we utilized with patches, features, etc.

Author: kirtanderson
Content: We've done some of that, mostly in Influx (edge interpolation) and Grafana (custom panels for ISO 22400) and will probably continue to so do for those platforms, but our fork of DGraph is significant enough and specific enough to what we are doing that I don't see us contributing that back.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: I had written an answer but then took inspiration from @zackscriven and decided to just ask Chat GPT. "Act like an Industry 4.0 expert and explain what MES is and recommend a good book on the subject"

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
As an Industry 4.0 expert, I can provide a more detailed explanation of MES systems and recommend a book that covers the topic comprehensively.

A Manufacturing Execution System (MES) is a software system that connects and manages manufacturing operations in real-time. It provides a holistic view of the production process, from scheduling and resource allocation to material flow and quality control. MES systems play a crucial role in the Industry 4.0 ecosystem by enabling the collection and analysis of data from various sources, such as machines, sensors, and workers, to optimize manufacturing operations and improve overall efficiency.

MES systems typically include modules that manage production scheduling, workflow management, inventory management, labor tracking, and quality management. They also integrate with other systems, such as Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) and Product Lifecycle Management (PLM), to streamline and automate processes further.

One of the key benefits of MES systems is that they provide real-time visibility into the manufacturing process, enabling manufacturers to identify and address issues quickly. They also enable manufacturers to optimize operations by improving efficiency, reducing waste, and increasing productivity.

As for a book recommendation, I would recommend "Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES): Optimal Design, Planning, and Deployment" by Heiko Meyer. This book covers MES systems comprehensively, including their key concepts, benefits, and implementation strategies. It also includes case studies and best practices from real-world implementations, making it a valuable resource for anyone looking to implement an MES system.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: My answer was similar but I stressed more on how it a collection of modules, rather than a single entity. And to me you can build MES modules in software that isn't stamped MES. I have certainly build OEE and downtime modules in SCADA. I have seen OEE modules consisting of sensors and the Cloud.  To me if you take data from the ERP layer and combine it with data from the Plant floor, then you are looking at MES functions. But I couldn't recommend the books.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
One OEE projects I was involved in we were not allowed get any data from the PLC. 
so we installed three sensors, one at the machine outtake, one after the reject station and one at the end of the line.
 WE connected those to a S7 1200 PLC, and using a bit of logic, had rules so if the first sensor was triggered the machine would be counted as running.
If no sensor was triggered for 2 minutes then the line status was stopped.

We also made a .Net front end and a SQL express backend I think, that  allowed a supervisor to enter in the scheduled operating hours.
And then every time we had a downtime event, the operator was required to enter the reason for the downtime.

It wasn't an ideal solution but the customer got a lot of value from it and for the next line we were able to get data from the Line PLC and do a more proper job.

I have seen Siemens with mindsphere achieve something similar, with wireless sensors talking to a MindSphere Gateway and the OEE module in MineSphere.

Both of those to me are examples of OEE modules, with no MES as such.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The other example, was a system I inherited as an end user and ultimately replaces with a MES

the WO was read down from SAP, into the SCADA (InTouch) and used to start the filling machine.
There was some logic in the PLC to trigger a downtime event, i.e. no fills for 2 mins
The operator would then be required to enter the downtime reason on a Popup window in InTouch
that Window called a script that entered the downtime data into the DB
There were a number of downtime reports and OEE calculation that were then available to the Plant.
There was normally a need for the supervisor to adjust the time the machine was scheduled for so it wasn't ideal
In order to restart the Machine, the downtime reason was needed.

Certainly not how I would do it today, but again MES functionality, or an MES module with now MES.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Walker's latest video (Why you need to build your MES)....think I had an aha moment....stellar content as always.

MES is more than just a database, or connector, etc...MES orchestrates  all plant level operations. It is the DB that transacts inventory, and uses a barcode to scan in lot codes + the vendor specific machine SW that programs its + the IoT sensor that manages a feedback loop + inspection results (etc. Etc. Etc.).

My biggest misunderstanding was that MES is a database....it also includes all the plant floor applications, services, connectors, visualizations etc.

Also makes sense why you need to build an MES vs. buy...no 2 operations are the same, meaning no 1 ots product could meet any company's unique requirements...

So that is the 3.0 pyramid....in 4.0 does that mean no "MES", instead use a machine API, and communicate directly to UNS for all transactions (like a payload reporting results from a machine cycle, or recipe).

"Core 4 and add other shit" 😆

Author: rickbullotta
Content: A UNS by itself would be a woefully inadequate replacement for a traditional MES system in most industries.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
"No MES' was the wrong thing to say.. "MES" is really orchestration of plant floor operations, so in that regard, UNS acts as the intermediary between processes and steps. QMS, Machine software, Transactions/routing are all there, but instead of direct connection to these applications...you simplify by communicating to UNS, and allowing it to manage the communication from there. 

E.g. (and credit to Richard Shaw here), UNS will reduce need for Point-to-point communication,  and a single payload msg can provide data on quality, process validation, recipes etc. Then subs for relevant data get what they needed, and also handshake for process control as needed....

Author: sammysevens777
Content: So if that frames it better.....wasn't that OPC's goal? Vendor A, vendor b cant talk, so let me facilitate that exchange? UNS is more flexible with pub/sub, but it gets grey when i juxtapose UNS with OPC (tech stack etc. is different for sure...)

Author: sparkylarks
Content: To me a UNS is what I consider "Enabling Technology". It doesn't give me value by itself per say, but allow me develop other systems/applications/devices that can quickly and easly give value.  It is a bit like a database, Installing the Database and even putting data doesn't give value, the value come with what I do with the data and how I take it out.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: MES is harder to define what it does because you could have a MES without the Core 4. To me it is a suite of functionality that help you to execute your manufacturing Plan. You can still make product on the machines with it, but you can't see the bigger picture or coordinate across machines without it. Currently the MES in lots of plants, is Tim/Tom/Mary/Ringo.....  A MES solution is made up of the different MES functions to help stage and carry out the execution plan.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Nice, enabling technology, spot on!!

Author: joshuastover
Content: Well said. UNS is the structure of your business. We get asked a lot "where do I install a UNS" quite a bit. It doesn't "go" anywhere. It's a structure of the business and all the events in it, enabling you to have a single-source of truth for all data and information. New applications can be more easily integrated because they can be pointed to the UNS, and consume the data it needs.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Almost always there's some middleware in the mix that the IT department uses for integration and as a sort of "firewall" around the ERP.  Sometimes that middleware is from the ERP vendor, sometimes not.  But that's the approach you can usually get permission for.  Even some of the ERP APIs that you think you might want access to unnecessarily expose sensitive information.  By using a middleware approach, you can effectively build "views" or constrained and purpose-built APIs.  Same for the other direction - instead of having to learn the semantics of a specific ERP API call (which can be VERY VERY complicated), your IT department can provide a simplified API that maps into the more complicated backend APIs.  This is why SAP still sells/implements a lot of SAP MII today (my old product - and it's over 20 years old).  It hides a lot of complexity and saves a lot in services.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Yeah, part of the problem is "now or later?" All of our SAP instances globally are somewhat stand alone and of various versions. Memphis is R/3 which other than patches is still essentially the same platform since we launched it to replace BPCS in 2008. There's been a plan for years to get everyone on the same version but the $$$ to do so has gotten in the way thus far. Our Malaysia plant is on 4/HANA.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: All the more reason to abstract them away via middleware.  That way you can likely avoid modifications to plant systems even when the ERP version changes.  Most transactions around orders, BOMs/formulas, confirmations, material movements, maintenance, quality, and so on are very similar between versions and are generally backwards compatible.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: I love Walker's quip on being a CTO driven to innovate, or a CT-NO. IT needs a formal process to review requests to read data from the ERP. Otherwise it's 3.0 all over again. I've always thought a neat 4.0 use case is feedback on part quality from machine inspection / testing being relayed back to procurement. If a vendor's parts consistently have defects/issues, then the process level controller should be able to alert procurement and let them know to follow up with the vendor....there is so much opportunity to shrink the gap between OT and IT here for business value

Author: hobbes1069
Content: It's not going to happen quickly but we have begun to be accepted at the official OT group within the company globally. In general we're very conservative across the board so it take time unfortunately.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: That's fantastic, well earned. Need to position yourselves to make change....then come down with an iron fist 😆 ...only kidding of course!

Author: adamk3461

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: That’s a good question when you use Highbyte and Tulip together. Tulip's way of calculating states is very interesting (Machine Trigger) but transforming machine data from a CNC for example into machine states can be complex and require reading several dozen tags. In such cases, Highbyte will be more efficient to compute machine states and Tulip applications will be easier. Secondly, Tulip does not (yet) have the ability to publish machine states to an MQTT broker. As a result the machine states will not be available to other applications. Again, Highbyte makes machine states available to independent consumers. Finally, whether Tulip or Highbyte, the tags are not saved so it will not be possible to recalculate the machine states, if the data is wrong or if the rules change. Store or not your raw/telemetry data in a time series database is an important architecture choice that is not cover by Tulip or Highbyte.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: With the embedded broker in HB now, you can keep the state of your instances in the broker, can't you?  They don't currently have truly persistent retained values though, last I knew.

Author: rakitha2445
Content: Hi @kail82 did you end up doing a good comparison with Tulip and Ignition? I'm interested to know what you found.

Author: kail82
Content: hi @Rakitha  Yes I got detailed advise from @Richard Shaw . Please find  below

Author: kail82
Content:
They are both IIoT platforms, after that the differences are quite stark.
Tulip is a no-code (for the most part) platform when has a lower barrier of entry, but also for the same reason has more limitations. There are only so many widgets to choose from. And while it's mostly HTML 5 based, it lacks the adaptability of HTML for mobile vs desktop views. Mobile apps are either separate, or duplicate views within an app.
Both Tulip and Ignition are a "clean slate" in a sense. but Tulip includes things like machine monitoring out of the box. It also has Part 11 compliance for business that need it. There are three distinct buckets where data is stored. App completion data (variables and records stored in an immutable database), table data (think a typical SQL database but integrated, and without JOINS), and machine state data. All 3 have separate analytic engines behind them and data does not cross between them.
That being said, you can use apps to push data into each of the three where needed (as long as SOMEONE is running the app).
In many ways Tulip is "complete" in that it has the analytics, applications, and data storage all in one platform, whereas in Ignition would would have to procure those separately.
What Tulip doesn't have (YET!) is MQTT. I'm told it's coming. But you can access external SQL and HTTP (REST) data sources.
Ignition is more "modular" so you pay for what you use. In that sense you do have more generic access to your data, which I wish I had. But we chose Tulip so the average engineer could create an app to "scratch his itch" so it wouldn't have to be done by professionals.
We do however, control specific apps which are more complicated that most where we don't allow just anyone to modify it.

Author: rakitha2445
Content: Hi Kali, thank you for your reply. Actually my company just started using Tulip as well and i was curious to know if we made the correct choice. Going by your answer Tulip seems to be the best choice for our application. I was thinking that ignition might be an option for Historian, UNS and mqtt broker. But it looks like canary and hive MQTT are better options for those functions as well.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342

Author: nash4.0
Content: Hello everyone. We are currently looking for a modular low cost MES MOM capabilities (performance tracking OEE) etc. that we would like to deploy in our factories along with UNS architecture. I am down to 3 platforms tulip or parsec or sepasoft. Does anyone have any inputs on pros cons of these options

Author: flowurpatch
Content:
Hi Nash,
I found the same 3 vendors in my MES / MOM search list not too long ago.

Parsec has some impressive built in capabilities.  Prices may be on the higher end depending on what you want it for, but generally seems to follow the 'you get what you pay for.'  You may be able to save on licensing costs with say Ignition/Sepasoft, but you may have to spend more on custom development yourself/via integrators.  I have only gotten into some basic Sepasoft videos and vendor demos , so can't speak properly to how it stacks up.

We also examined Tulip.  The 99% no-code, 'people on the plant floor can build applications philosophy' really appealed to me (my previous company's home grown MES followed this philosophy to impressive effect), but I couldn't get approval from management to explore that route.  I would love to try out Tulip when I have time and budget for sandboxing.  Democratizing access to build MES modules and applications is a huge cultural shift away from the gatekeeping and siloing of past automation/IT/tech culture.  It's still hard, however, to build systematic, quality, smart tools.  But a few key resources who can teach/guide best practices to a wider group who already understand an operation/facility, can get a lot done.

From what little I know, you'll be in a decent position with any of those 3 platforms, but it all depends on the specifics of your situation.  Are you clear on how these platform's functionality and cost match your scope and requirements?

Author: sammysevens777
Content: You'e one of the few people in industry ive come across that see the value of low code environments.....have you seen these models succeed (outside of your org.)?

Author: flowurpatch
Content: I have not had the chance to see these specific models succeed yet, but it just seems like a matter of time.  Think about Spreadsheets.  Spreadsheets effectively allow people who cannot do traditional programming, build and run a Database. (not that you should do that, a joke of mine is that my job can be summarized by "No more Spreadsheets")

Author: flowurpatch
Content:
It just seems to follow logically to me like this:

There are now droves of skilled software engineers, developers, UX designers, etc. across the world.
Eventually a group of them will realize there is value in creating a high quality product, that folks who cannot currently / are not likely to build actual script based programming, but are smart and want to make data flow better (so they can see some information (contextualized data), e.g. how often a certain machine breaks, or how many good parts they made in a shift). This is Tulip's entire business approach. There are enough people in the manufacturing world, probably in Operations, who understand that the Operators and Technicians are the most important people in the organization (P&G's all employees are "Technicians," Gemba walks etc. from Lean Manufacturing), AND who see value in leveraging those folks' knowledge to improve their lines, business units, facilities to ask for it or if they see it, recognize the value.

My guess is this comes from cultural/classist gatekeeping.  If you're poor you don't get to go to college and learn how to program.
Versus, 'We as an organization will succeed, if we can leverage the as much knowledge from the most number of our staff to improve our business.' Imagine you hire a janitor who shows you a time series chart of cleaning consumables data by factory department, that they built, in low/no code.

This was something I missed in my past life because I was unknowingly stumbling my way thru digital transformation. I will never forget how important it is to get buy in at the right times.  I implemented excellent MES solutions with integrations to our ERP, put big screens on the plant floor, showed management: OEE charts, Paretos of live top losses by department, live factory work queues, etc. and they didn't care.  "We're too busy struggling to produce enough units this quarter." was the answer I most often received when I asked why we can't move faster with implementing more.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Very big thinking here Patch....and I'm with you. I am an engineer and consider myself functional enough to do most software tasks, but the ability to empower an organization through low-code, and give people the power to whip up their application (which is a template in most cases....access a DB, pull data, load it for an interface, and act on it), is a lot easier in low code than standard coding (even with GPT and all the other AI tools)

The big kicker is what you said...leveraging their knowledge.....production folks are brilliant and know their problems very well, empowering them with technology to resolve their problems more effectively is a great strategy to scale. I always mention that manufacturers are not google/facebook....we don't have droves of SW engineers laying around for work.....so we need to make software more accessible, and one way is with low code....well said!!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I'll take a bit of a contrarian view just to get us to think this through.  Obviously I'm a big fan of low-code approaches to manufacturing software based on where I've worked in the past.  But I'm not sure the goal should be to let "anyone" develop apps.  Instead, I think it's about enabling a broader range of people to develop apps and to break through the IT/software guru backlog.  Having more people in the company or at your partners who can build these apps quickly based on user input is what I think the end game should be - not necessarily every employee building apps.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: The logical outcome of every employee building apps seems like the current outcome of most SharePoint servers. Not sure if you really want that.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Back to MES stuff...

Can someone help me illustrate an example for MES in detail(code would help)

- ERP sends a work order to MES (part#, quantity, etc.)

- MES uses part# from work order to define a route, plan and assign resources. Is there a lot of setup involved prior to this step? (E.g. cycle time, overall build time, station scheduling, timing, routing etc.?). A route should populate a work centers job queue with the expected serial #s or product for process verification

- work order begins, and part is either identified (barcode or other) and approved for route through MES handshake, or  machine independently verifies

- process is recorded into a record in MES indicating what happened (cycle time, product manufactured, quality, etc.)

- MES aggregates this data across all work centers/machines, and at the end if successful closes work order and consumes inventory (backflush)

Am i on the right track?

Author: douga.7429
Content: Yes, but what is your end goal who is your audience?

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Just learning for now, audience is me 😆

Author: douga.7429
Content: The most simplistic way to think of MES is as a workorder system for production operations.  The standard and related committees came up with OEE which is a score of how efficiently production ran.  Assuming that the schedule represents a plan the intersection between Enterprise Resource Planning(ERP) and actual shopfloor activity became the focus. And, they actually renamed from Manufacturing Execution Systems to Manufacturing Enterprise System. That didn't seem to stick with folks; however, the idea that MES is more than a WO system and is at the center of enterprise integration is where the meat is on the topic.

Author: douga.7429
Content: Yes, you will have asset utilization, items production and WO history as facts.  Overlaying WO assignment with asset utilization and item production is the analytical challenge to build insight around.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
So is it fair to assume MES is kind of made up of standard components?
- interfaces between layers (ERP and SCADA)
- database for work orders, routing. Scheduling
- process optimization for planning 
- config/setup of key parameters (e.g. machine properties)

Then there is code that is written around these components, for analytics and orchestration (e.g. populate record in table Work Orders for WO0001 with Status = 'Done' when serial number is generated at last final station

And this would be a combination of OS based interfaces + SQL programming?

Author: douga.7429
Content: Yes, the ERP standard didn't provide plant floor execution so they made this standard to handle what you outlined.  When they baked more into ERP they tended to call it Manufacturing Operations Module(MOM) vs MES.  There is a part of  MES model that is in part redundant to ERP, so data has to be synchronized between them. By using MOM some of this goes away.  In ither case there is manufacturing detail that would not be in ERP standard that MES, MOM is an attempt to add it to ERP.  I am not suggesting MOM is better, ERP systems tend to overcomplicate the relationship between activities and cost accounting.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
I missed visualizations! But thank you...i appreciate this insight, and also explaining MOM which i dont come across often. 

Very helpful!!

Author: douga.7429
Content:
As far a code, most MES system where made around 2000 and use SQL as a backend, and have some sort of a middle ware to make it more deterministic, faster at inserting production data.

My take on what is happening here in the community is that there is a progression to a new architectural approach which decouples components in SQL. Adoption of edge computing allows for "- config/setup of key parameters (e.g. machine properties)".  Whereas in SQL dynamic schema definition isn't possible.  The whole AWS or Azure stack that allows for this dynamic allocation of schema solves this need in both ERP and MES modals, which SQL handled poorly.

Author: douga.7429
Content: The lines between ERP, MES, and SCADA are getting blurred to everyone is realizing they need to be a Real-time enterprise.  So "- process optimization for planning" would normally be considered an "enterprise" activity not MES.  As edge devices become more capable deviating from plan in real-time becomes advantageous; however we sill need to forecast and make planes and evaluate if they could be better next time.

Author: douga.7429
Content: The SCADA aspect normally links recipe/ERP BOMS to the plant floor.  But, often Scada has to have more granular trends and support production in ways that would produce to much data to integrate into MES or ERP systems.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Got it - makes sense, mes goes to a SCADA / production server, which then manages recipes to devices....

I now remember we had lots of SMT eqpt. And did have a vendors management server handle the last mile of recipe mgmt. and control....so MES would talk to this server, which would then report back status 

So that's where products like ignition fit in?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Ignition will load the recipe at runtime and send set points to the PLCs.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Got it - couple questions:
- by ignition "loading the recipe", that means passing along the work order requirements from the erp, which (in discrete mfg.) Will be read in by the MES to determine a route (based on schedule) and communicate to ignition (based on schedule) what recipe(s) need to be loaded on a machine at any time, and ignition does data exchange to PLC / controller from there? (TCP packet data to PLC with recipes, or discrete IO).

- MES has 2 types of integration, machine or work center. Machine is like above, work center is done at a station with a PC to log data manually/semi automated (work instructions, fill in fields, perform tests and log response etc.). More focused on user entries, form filling, etc.

Am i understanding correctly?

Author: douga.7429
Content: Yes, but this ridged routing to predetermined order of specific work centers is the typical short coming of this a approach.  So a lot of the innovation I see here is breaking from that rigged modal. In most manufacturing they have to do whatever it takes to make it right, regardless of disappointment that enterprise planning had to be reconsidered.

Author: flowurpatch
Content: Fair point Rick.   In reality,  enabling some more  folks who generally have more programmatic oriented minds to build tools is a good enough first step.  I think, however, with the upcoming generations having more and more digital natives, that these sorts of transformations will accelerate.  Although, I am continuously surprised by how mysterious most people think software is.

Author: arnesvendsen
Content:
I have been away from this discord for ages .. 
I am glad to see that the MES talks are still live and relevant ..
MOM was mentionend above ..  Where ERP and other business systems, procure,planning is layer-4, then MOM is layer-3 i.e. it is the systems, needed to "operate the Manufacturing".  I.e. systems placed in the factories, or.. that was up to "yesterday". As and when you build a cross-site manufacturing data warehouse'ish, then I would still see this as MOM layer-3 functionality, just pushed up to a central server. E.g.  Historians I would in 2023++ move away from factories and into central (NOT cloud, just central data center). 
Layer-2 is the SCADA/Automation, where the SCADA does nothing other that visualisation. MES talks directly to Automation, SCADA just a side view.  I know this SCADA interpretation differs across organisations. The ISA 4 layer model, I think is pretty consistenly used out there.

Author: arnesvendsen
Content:
So MOM is the MES systems, the quality systems, the warehouse control systems (high bays, AGVs and what have you)  as I see it.. 
(As someone can hear I am still a bit religious towards ISA 95)

Author: arnesvendsen
Content:
As a 1-man MOM advisor (stopped coding  while ago), people ask me, what are the new MES-systems to look out for.. 
Here in the Nordics, I rolled out WW MES in 2004-forward on 50 sites in Arla and it became the guiding star for many other supply chains, so we have a lot of WW around. We seem to get TrakSYS popping out as well. 
Now these two systems WW(now AVEVA) and TrakSYS is what I would call "classic" MES systems. They have quite some functions and/but are rather cost-heavy. 
I hear about Ignition, Libre, FrameworX but dont see it in practice out there("here around"). 
There must be more systems, that should add to my "gross-list" - pls comment 🙂

Author: douga.7429
Content:
In my last role, I aggregated data into data warehouses for MES.  And, understand some of your concerns.  Walker is making an open implementation of MES and has an incredible amount of engagement.  My hope is that with the advancements in AI and the need to drive down while aggregating data for oversite, we will quickly produce a solution to offset these growing ownership costs. Right, know there is an opportunity to influence what requirements could be.  I have been spending a lot of time thinking about what a modern Industry 4.0 to MES could look like. 

I too have experience with Wonderware 
 MES and have some perspective on what Walker is promoting that is different.  The traditional stack with enough time money and effort can provide the solutions you describe.  One of the most compelling things about the "Industry 4.0" approach is cost reduction.  Not only in the spending but in time and resources to implement solutions.  This Industry 4.0 approach leverages that edge devices became capable over the years, while MQTT emerged as a more efficient messaging protocol.  As data science applications become more data-hungry at the enterprise level this approach can provide more granular detail with less configuration effort.

The IoT approach allows for upstream systems like SCADA, MES, SCADA, and data warehousing to leverage object definition at the edge.  This is accomplished with the sparkplug specification.  In an ideal solution adding new assets would seamlessly integrate into all these systems without the need for advanced programming/configuration.

Author: loris6780
Content: Those software you listed aren’t MES software but more IIoT platforms (scada) where you can eventually add third party mes solutions. The general idea isn’t to replace classic MES - even do I’m curious to understand why you call them classic - but more to work on the architecture where they are running. Here it’s all about the UNS approach where a mes system can subscribe and publish information. From your experience it would be to use System platform as an IIoT platform rework the ERP and MES information into SP using the model based on ISA 95 and publish via OI MQTT into the UNS to serve any subscribers - same flow can be used then to consume data into your mes/erp.

Author: douga.7429
Content: He mentioned WW MES, which was previously FactTelligence.  Building out data ware housing solutions against has caused me to become disenfranchised with them.  This is why I have sought out the community; however, the convergence UNS and MES is still a work in progress from my point of view.  The MES boot camp and the potential for an open MES implementation to bring this all together.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
The idea to define objects at the edge and bring them into the UNS makes WW System Platform a redundant object definition.  In an ideal world object definition would happen once at the edge.  WW System Platform emerged as PLCs were also becoming more object-oriented.  Then ERP systems have objects and systems in-between like MES. Then we have to tread them together.  The UNS concept attempts to move object definition forward from the edge and a schemeless store and other mature data practices facilitate the IoT concept. Yes, WW has a stack where you can do everything, the question is can it be more efficient and cost-effective? 

Consider what is the business value of your next forced WW upgrade, based on MS support of Windows Server X.

Author: loris6780
Content: I think you’re not up to date regarding both aveva mes and system platform. If you consider system platform as your uns where your object definition should be create you already making a mistake. System platform is used like this in a industry 3.0 architecture. Now think the following architecture : multiple aveva edge close to your machines (this product has a lot of features, is cheap, can go on linux/windows) so basically an agnostic HMI which is mqtt sparkplug b compliant to push into UNS with the desire structure and store & forward. Other systems pushes as well (in the ideal world independently erp, mes, any other subscriber/consumer), the issue you still have is that x different software will need the same x user interfaces to display their own information. Now think about subscribing with system platform all these data with automatic discovery, creation an deployment of sp objects. The next step is to use OMI in order to have one single user interface at the enterprise level than can embed other user interface/information in the same UX/UI but most importantly with context ! Look all the apps already available with OMI, it’s massive and completely open to new dev

For example rebranding Kepware and taking what should be the open part of the platform and closing it.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The way I think about it is that there is no such thing as a MES. There are a lot of Manufacturing processes that are carried out by different systems. 
Some times that is the Operators filling out Travellers, or it is a Manager reviewing records etc...
You can certainly build OEE, and downtime functionality into a Schedule. Or even have a SCADA retrieve the Bill of materials from the ERP

So your mfg.Moduie, is that MES functionality that is  provided by the ERP. 
You could have Plant with a SCADA and ERP that provides all the MES functionality that exists.
I could even argue that Ignition is a SCADA that can develop MES functionality. I would lose that arguement but it's not an realy wild view either.

As for experience, Mentorship and Bootcamps are a good place, IF you can build some proof of concept in your plant using a trial version of ignition that would be the gold standard. Fulfilling an actual need for the company as part of the training. Then you just need to get the company to provide the cost of a licence, and you can start expanding out.  
I would try to doe the prework first though ,i.e. Digital strategy , minimum technical requirements, DTMA,

Author: pewright
Content: In my recent experience, Plex reps will describe their offering as "configurable, but not customizable", meaning the code is off-limits.  I know lots of enterprises who signed up for Oracle in the cloud, only to find their single-instance approach horrible for multiple locations/business units, etc. I expect to hear a similar loud cry from companies operating multiple plants who try to deploy Plex, even if only a single plant. Manufacturing is a dynamic environment, the product is always being evolved and that drives change in the shop floor processes. How many factories would be content with an off-the-shelf product at the MES layer of the stack? I'm sure there are verticals where this would work, but I'm not in one.

Author: pewright
Content: On a related note, I have an Engineer far from the home office who has built a small empire of end-of-line testing systems using National Instrument's NI Test Stand. Now he's trying to tell us we should build the entire MES layer over it, because it's "just like Ignition". I know that isn't the case but now I have to go prove it. Anyone who can offer an informed opinion with the tools at hand, I would love to hear from. I used to work for an NI Silver Partner but I've never heard their Test Stand product accused of being more than a peripheral QA platform.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Can you clarify what you mean by single-instance?

If you're referring to tenants, most Plex customer run a separate tenant at each site.  Each tenant is an independent configuration with its own GL.  In a multi-site context, they can be "grouped" into an enterprise.  There are modules with enterprise functionality (e.g., central treasury, consolidated financials, workflow) and the consistent schema can be queried across tenants.

With multi-tenant SaaS apps running on the same code base, there are certainly limits on what can be customized.  This is nothing new with Enterprise and cloud applications.  But, Plex has pretty extensive configuration.  There are thousands of settings and tons of functionality that can be rapidly put to use.  Most of the functionality was built out by customers paying for specific enhancements to solve real-world problems in their plants.  Does it do everything you want always?  No.  Does it quickly provide functionality that would be hard to build out yourself or possibly find in other platforms?  Depending on the vertical, yes.  Can be it extended or augmented with integrations?  Yes.

All the stored procedures and data sources can be exposed to APIs and the UI builder.  There is a full access to the transaction schema in the reporting database.  Customers can submit their stored procedures for review and get them approved to be deployed in the production environment.  

For most orgs leaving a legacy MES running on AS/400 or something improvised/unsupported/non-existent, it's massive improvement and it can be deployed relatively quickly.  

Customization is not a free lunch, though.  It requires sufficient digital maturity and allocation of resources not just stand it up, but sustain it.  Most who go down the path of customization, fail to lifecycle and they remain stuck on the version it was implemented on.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
[1]
Overall pricing model is a percentage of revenue.  It varies, but 0.3% of revenue is a good baseline.  Some customers have worked out per seat or per employee deals as an alternative model.

[2]
Not sure what typical is, but it does vary greatly.  Revenue-based pricing and breadth-and-depth of modules complicates this.  I'm aware of some implementations with very experienced end users that have been as little as 40 hours professional services.  Many customers can self-implement after they've been gone through the process of standing up for the first site or two.  If it helps, I've heard overall revenue from software is ~70% and services is ~30%.  This doesn't include implementation partners.

[3]
While it can be deployed as a point solution, it's not that common.  At this point, it's likely more of a commercial (i.e., bundling, deal size) limitation than a technical one.  In general, there's a lot of value leveraging the functionality from other modules because it integrates well.  The marginal cost of standing up more functionality is relatively low.  I've heard of some standalone quality customers.  The more common scenario is two-tier ERP scenarios where a traditional ERP may be ran at HQ for corporate workloads (e.g., financial consolidation, corporate performance mgmt, HCM) and Plex deployed at a site as a manufacturing ERP/MES.  The A/P, A/R, and costing are tightly integrated into the production, inventory, shipping, and supply chain modules.  Large enterprises will often as expose this as a sub ledger to their corporate ERP as a sub-ledger.

[4]
Unfortunately, not much is event driven.  There is a legacy "outbound" SOAP client, but it's largely been deprecated.  Most the APIs are data sources / SPROCs wrapped as SOAP/XML or HTTP/JSON.  It requires polling from a SCADA or middleware to detect changes and derive events.  For many years, the integration strategy was "let's expose this SPROC" or whatever the customer paid them to do.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342

Yeah, ERP projects are expensive in general.  

It's inexpensive for some that have had SAP or Oracle projects run 2-3% of revenue or more.  Some more traditional, labor intensive orgs with low tech-to-employee have gotten their total IT spend down to <1% by migrating to Plex.  Multi-tenant SaaS can really lower implementation and service costs.

Author: douglasalbright
Content: The initial focus should be to assure the quality of the events we need. Our understanding of MES systems needs to evolve from being simply glue between ERP and MRP integrations, and quality system integrations. With real-time digital operations, we should become more event driven than centrally managed. Old MES systems emphasized on work orders rather than capturing events, which can limit their adaptability. For instance, when studying OEE availability loss over time, many systems aggregate these values by work order operations and overlook the need for custom groupings.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
They're a GSI acquired by Rockwell.  From what I understand, they're basically the professional services arm that will stitch together Rockwell's sprawling portfolio including the FactoryTalk suite (gateway, historians, MES), Plex (ERP, MES), PTC (IoT, PLM), Fiix (CMMS), Ansys (CAE), Arena/Emulate3D (simulation/digital twin), etc for customers.  It appears they're white labeling Cognite under "FactoryTalk DataMosaix".

Seeing how these types of acquired portfolios have played out in the ERP world, I would be concerned about how well everything works together.  If the people who own the source code are not motivated to refactor portfolio into something coherent, what does that mean for the end user and those supporting them?  Buyers are usually not thrilled when they find out they need to pay someone to integrate what they thought was, and marketed as, integrated.  Sometimes the level of effort is not really much different than if one randomly selected disparate solutions from different vendors.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Tulip is not an MES per se, but rather a solution that sits at the MES layer to solve manufacturing problems that involve operations and operators.  It's positioned as a "frontline operations platform" for this reason.  It's an MES in the way that Photoshop is art work or Excel is an income statement.  One uses Photoshop or Excel as tools to build something.  They're not stock artwork or a general ledger out-of-the-box.  Mendix is viewed by some as a competitor to Tulip.  It's another no-code / low-code application building platform for the manufacturing space.
 
A traditional MES will have a master data model with specific modules related to executing a manufacturing plan.  Sometimes it's a part of a manufacturing ERP suite.  Other times, it's a standalone application with some capability to run on its own or integrate with ERP for planning.  The plan might consist of a work order, kanban, batch, etc.  The plan can be associated with workcenters or assets that will "consume" resources (e.g., labor, material, asset hours) to run production.  It will have specific capabilities to enforce the production process and track the progress.  For example, state events (e.g., setup, run, down) that impact availability or utilization are logged.  Additionally, production records are logged (source inventory, processed inventory, rejections/defects).  It can go much further than this.  Off-the-shelf MES solutions will typically cater to specific modes of manufacturing and verticals.  While they're configurable and can be customizable to varying degrees, they're prescriptive in how they're used.  On some level, one has to "accept" the MES as a business process.  This is where the buy vs build topic comes up.  There exist tradeoffs, but this is a separate topic.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Tulip does not have specific modules and master data with this functionality out-of-the-box.  It has pre-built "apps", but they're more like templates.  It’s not a part of a comprehensive suite of functionality that are maintained and enhanced to all work together.  They’re more of a starting point.  For example, there is no formal concept of a Work Order in Tulip.  It would be a generic table that one labels as “Work Order” and creates the necessary columns they feel should define a Work Order record.  If one wants to do something with a work order, they must build an app that will specifically call up that table with its unique schema and then read/write to the row that contains that work order.  Extending this example to an MES, a work order is a distinct object that other modules or screens specifically depend on.  
 
I don’t see MES and Tulip/Mendix as an either/or problem.  If the goal is to have a 50k square meter facility run and report production that adhere to a master data model, an MES is the solution.  If the goal is to create specific interfaces or apps to make processes more efficient, Tulip/Mendix is a good option.  They’re actually great options if one desires non-technologists play a role in build and maintaining it.   If the goal is both, use both.
 
Whether bought or built, some of the rigidity of a proper MES can be useful.  It helps enforce a business process that should be highly repeatable and uniform.  For example, if the results of MES are used to determine planning, one probably wants very consistent underlying records and little-to-no flexibility.  If one wants to reduce takt time on two dissimilar assembly processes, one may desire flexibility to optimize training, work instructions, and the overall interface to do so.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yeah, it's tough.  While Tulip is in Gartner's MQ for MES, the solution is so different than everything else on there.  Calling it an MES is a bit of a misnomer.  At the same time, who knows what a Frontline Operations Platform is?  I've seen the phrase "connected worker" to describe this as well.

The only takeaway is that software for industry are not firmly scoped around ISA or Gartner classifications.  The lines are blurry.  The solutions overlap each other and even transcend the categories.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Another good point.  There's a lot of use cases where I've seen people try to solve a problem and I think about a handful of APIs in certain MES products that would easily do all those things.  But, then I realize they don't have anything like that.

It has surprised me that the major cloud vendors who want manufacturing data flowing their platforms have not explored this.  For example, imagine some sort of service to define a schedule, log production events, and report them.  Instead, there's always this emphasis on asset monitoring or digital twins.  When there is an OEE reference architecture, it typically involves infrastructure or platform services that virtually no one in operations would play a role in maintaining.  It demonstrates that there exist services to persist and visualize data, but not operationalize it.

Author: dapomeranz
Content: It depends on use case scope, digital strategy, how involved IT is (sounds like zero). My general suggestion is to start with one CI/Lean minded engineer to become the champion and see how much value they can create by streamlining critical processes and/or adding critical data capture in the weeds BEFORE pursuing something large like eBR. Unless you have very low mix.

Content: eBR/eDHR at scale can be very complex and might negate true "citizen development". Many companies have success with central Tulip teams who are able to connect closely with processes and iterate quickly on customization, yet sit centrally.

Author: jdingus
Content: We are implementing an MES in a high mix low volume (HMLV) shop.  Part pc targets don’t really make a lot of sense in these situations.  We typically think in concept of hours in regard to each part has a rate and when you produce said part you “earn” that amount of time.  So over an elapsed period of time say 8 hours you would have then earned 7 hours given you a performance of 88% for the shift.  Just seeing if this resonates with anyone and if there are any online examples that may help me explain this concept to others and/or approach it in a better way?

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: Sounds exactly like my last company. We had a lot of discussions about OEE vs. ESH (earned standard hours). We ended up building an typical OEE system in Ignition/Sepasoft and then worked with Sepasoft to develop a custom OEE calculation that would calculate OEE the way you described.

Author: jdingus
Content: Good to hear it’s making sense to someone else.  Sounds like the typical approach an OEE engine uses more piece performance driven? Or at least that’s Sepasofts approach. Wish I had completed the MES boot camp a lot this would make a lot more sense. 🙂

Author: ctown_kyle
Content:
Yes exactly. Typical OEE calculation with a running part counter. I don't remember the formula we used for ESH but it was exactly as you described it. I basically took a formula from our Continuous Improvement team to the guys at Sepasoft and they made it happen. I think the main gist of it was instead of adding 1 to the part counter every 15-30 minutes (literally 1, since we were low volume) we were doing a calculation based on the standard cycle time and then adding that to a cumulative ESH count.

Also, I think you can still purchase the bootcamp recording. Since I had already gone through this project with  Sepasoft it was pretty easy to follow the bootcamp.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I'm doing something slightly different. For machining anyway, CNC programs are validated so the operator really has no control over how long the cycle is (we'll ignore the feedrate override knob for this discussion). My SVP wants to look at things through a "zero loss" perspective and has agreed that for long cycle time operations we can substitute asset utilization for the productivity part of OEE. We have 1000s of SKUs and obtaining all the theretically perfect run rates isn't practical.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Some of the machines have pallet changers and so could theoretically run 100% of the time during a shift.

Author: jdingus
Content:
I’m very familiar with that world.  From a supervisory standpoint keeping the spindles turning is the best your operators can do.  The issue that comes into play is when the machines are not running at ideal cycle time for whatever reason.  That responsibility will typically fall on engineering or maintenance if say the tool change arm was slowed down or something like that.  From a complexity standpoint just monitoring if your spindle is turning gets about 80-90% of the value without needing to do all these rate calculations.

The pallet changer aspect has definitely complicated our MES implementation as well.  You can  have 2 different part numbers running at a single time on one machine each will have its own rate associated with it.

Author: rickbullotta

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Just track the three constituent metrics, and then, only if you can do so accurately.  For example, most companies cannot track work center/machine level quality accurately.  Also, OEE unfairly punishes people/work centers for issues upstream and downstream.  I would also then add in key measures around worker safety, energy/resource usage, on-time delivery, and other relevant measures for your business.

Author: hiptopjones
Content: Is there any sort of generally-accepted guideline or best practices on how to calculate these metrics?  Walker talks about how most people calculate OEE wrong.  You mention accuracy, and other comments here discussed whether material shortage should be treated as an availability or performance problem.  Do we all have to figure it out and navigate the territory ourselves, or has some industry sage published a manifesto on this topic that addresses common mistakes and is taken as a standard?  (Laughing to myself as I wrote that, because I'm guessing not...)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Well, if you asked a few of the people on this discord server how they're calculating it, you'd get very different answers.   ALMOST EVERY MANUFACTURING BUSINESS IS DIFFERENT, AND USING THE SAME KPIS MAKES NO SENSE.  That's the summary.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: So if the machine upstream of you keeps crapping out, your machine's OEE turns to sh*t also.  Is that fair?  Is that meaningful?  If you run the machines full out but people are getting hurt as a result, is that good?  If you run the process to maximize OEE but it doubles your energy and water usage, is that OK?  It's all about balance and understanding what really drives results.

Author: hiptopjones
Content: Understood.  Just don't want let perfect be the enemy of good.  Thanks for the insights, Rick.  Appreciated.

And if line 2, has a 30% OEE but its customers are satisfied why focus on that when another has a 80% OEE with a line down situation at the customer.

Author: Deleted User

I like know when there's wasted utilization due to upstream issues, but agree, definitely should not be included in an individual OEE calculation imo.

Author: billireland
Content: OEE gives you an informative  insight into the performance of an asset or a plant but it is often incorrectly applied, calculated and understood. By tracking the productivity (versus design), quality and availability performances one can see potential bottlenecks.  OEE versus schedule should not be confused with what the 24/7 number is. In my experience using a standardised 80% industry benchmark is limiting. Also measuring a metric incorrectly is far worse as we know then not measuring at all 👍

Author: digital_dairy
Content:
Over the last week, I've read this MES thread from beginning to end. Very informative. Here's a list of things of interest I picked up in case it helps others new to the thread:
1. For clarity, the scope of MES within this thread is actually Manufacturing Operations Management (MOM). MOM covers all of Layer 3 of ISA95 (Production/Inventory/Quality/Maintenance Operations Management). Even though MES is a subset of MOM, we use the term MES as though it were MOM as term MES resonates with stakeholders better than MOM.
2. Off-the-shelf MES solutions typically can't cater for the diversity of MES requirements across different organisations. It's becoming apparent that we need a composable MES that consists of modules for each of the various capabilities. These modules might be supplied by different vendors and some might be written in-house.
3. A UNS is not a substitute for an MES. UNS is useful for real-time context of data; the MES might publish it's data to the UNS, and also subscribe to other data in the UNS, but the UNS does not contain the capabilities of Manufacturing Operations Management.
4. Solutions with Ignition seem to be favoured over traditional vendor solutions e.g. Rockwell, Aveva. Traditional vendors can often be 10x the price of Industrial Automation offerings. Sepasoft seems to be a 'native' MES solution for an Ignition Solution.

Author: digital_dairy
Content:
5. Rockwell has a strength in PLCs e.g. Control Logix with Phase Manager ... but ... has a lot of weaknesses in software solutions.
6. There's a sweet-spot in the adoption of standards i.e. too much adherence to standards can stifle innovation.
7. Walkers team uses Ignition, FactoryStudio or WinCC-OA, Sepasoft business connector, SAP Connector (back in 2021, not sure what is used now)
8. Walker has an excellent video on how to calculate OEE and why you need to
9. TEEP extends OEE (solves the planned downtime issue)
10. ISA95 Part 2 seems to be the most useful part of the standard regards 4.0 Solutions
11. The latest B2MML standard has event driven capabilities and BatchML is now part of B2MML
12. Tulip has similarities to ThingWorx
13. Libre seems to be a favoured MES but there are many other choices e.g. Plex. Some have had good results with Plex but are concerned about the aquistion by Rockwell
14. Some likes gotillit for work flow
15. Rockwell FT DataMosaix has components from Cognite (likely relating to ML)

Author: digital_dairy
Content: You'll see quite a bit about Rockwell in this summary. This is because 80% of our 2000 plcs are Rockwell and we've coded most of them using S88 principles. We have 26 locations running FT ProductionCentre as the MES using S95 principles. We have B2MML between these and our SAP ERP.

Author: digital_dairy
Content: My org is a dairy manufacturer (powders, cheese, casein, etc). As such we are very asset intensive and have predominantly batch manufacturing in our processing plants, discrete manufacturing in our packing lines and continuous manufacturing in our utilities areas. I've noted that most of the MES discussion here is generally about Discrete manufacturing and the ISA95 Part 2 model that Walker presents is the Discrete hierarchy (Line/Cell). Have others here augmented their continuous/batch MES with UNS?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
We implemented the entire ISA95 Part 2 and Part 4, along with all the good parts of FTPC in a modern, high-performance, horizontally scalable stack running in kubernetes and exposed it all through a GraphQL api to make it really quick for react devs to build UI frontends against.
We added HA opc-ua agents that use the same tag templating approach the FTPC uses, but also support mqtt, rabbitMQ and Azure Service Bus.

Author: kevinhibbins
Content: Rob I think you've nicely summed up the market situation .... there is, in my opinion, no one-size-fits-all, no silver bullet, no single platform or standard that covers the spectrum of requirements & concerns in MES  / MOM. After many years in this space I am absolutely convinced that a hybrid solution is a very valid & robust approach and the way to go. You may buy a bit, build a bit, etc, and no solution will likely ever be final, and nor should it be as it needs to be extensible & scalable & adaptable without penalty. There needs to be flexibility to match your business in terms of priorities, budget, timeline, capability, maturity and risk, and the changes in these as they happen.

Author: trumster
Content: Hello everyone, does it makes sense to start a MES assessment when you know that the IT / OT infrastructure is going to change drastically during the period the assesment being conducted? Furthermore, does it make sense when you establish 3rd party SW that cover some parts of an MES?

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Here's some things to consider. 

Understanding the Current State vs. Future State: If the IT/OT infrastructure is going to change drastically, it's crucial to assess how these changes will impact the MES. The assessment should not only consider the current environment but also anticipate future modifications. Also how do the changes align with you digital strategy? If you don't have one, you could be setting yourself up for extreme technical debt.

Flexibility and Scalability: A key principle in MES implementation is ensuring the system is flexible and scalable. Even if the IT/OT infrastructure is changing, the MES should be adaptable to these changes. The assessment will evaluate how well the MES can integrate with both the current and upcoming IT/OT environment.

Integration of Third-Party Software: The inclusion of third-party software in an MES environment is fairly common. The assessment would answer how these software components will interact with the MES, through establishing your Minimum Technical Requirements. A thorough evaluation of the compatibility, data exchange capabilities, and potential bottlenecks or redundancies that these integrations might introduce is needed to mitigate unintended issues. 

Risk Management and Contingency Planning: Also want to think about incorporating risk management and contingency planning into your overall strategy. Identifying potential risks associated with infrastructure changes and developing strategies to mitigate these risks.

Phased Approach: In a situation where significant changes are expected, a phased approach to implementation might be advisable, if at all possible. You want to allow for adjustments and refinements as the infrastructure evolves.

Obviously we suggest starting with a digital strategy, why do you want to be digital. If you can't answer that question, we always advise against purchasing anything. Moreover, through the  assessment process you will reveal your current state, desired future state, minimum technical requirements, suggested architecture, and then the iterations of the transformation journey. Basically, undertaking a transformation journey, whether an enterprise wide initiative, or just replacing one component without an assessment is like getting in your car for a cross country trip without checking your tires, fluids, etc, and not bringing up your GPS for directions. You're travelling blind.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Is anyone here aware of any open source MES initiatives? The MES solutions I see on the market seem to be either very expensive COTS systems or libraries tied to a specific platform like Ignition. Same goes for batch control systems (often sold as part of MES).

Build it yourself is a solution but I feel like everyone starting from scratch and reinventing the wheel is a waste of time + a pain to maintain. 
A good basis for a standardized DB schema and some core functionalities would be helpful to many integrators I'd think.

Google points me to Libre which I'm definitely going to have a look at, but no one seems to be maintaining that open source project anymore and from what I understand.

Author: thedavidschultz

Author: geoffnunan
Content: I am the CTO at Rhize (formerly Libre). We started with an Open Source vision. We fairly quickly found that the feedback from Venture Capital was negative, and also found that the feedback from customers was negative, so we had to move to closed and expensive because thats what the market told us they wanted.

Author: brianpribe
Content: This is really intriguing. Could we get more details on why the market pushed Rhize to being closed?

Author: nickn5549
Content: Market...I doubt, investors I can see why...they protect the money...especially the old-school ones...

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Our customers told us that they view Open source as a risk. They did not see value in us as a software vendor taking contributions from the community. This is mostly due to the strict regulatory requirements on software vendors in the Pharma industry.
Investors just could not easily see the path to being able to get a return on their investment in a Free and Open Source business model.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: It takes a lot of money to build enterprise grade software. Its difficult to get that money back without charging a license for the software. Open Source creates an expectation of Free which is not realistic.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: What Geoff said. That's been my experience as well.

Author: kevinhibbins
Content: What "MES initiatives" are you looking for? COTS and BYO are certainly at either end of the (high) risk spectrum imo. The sweet spot is in the middle.

Author: utf_lifeform
Content:

It's still pretty minimal, but I expect that over time it will have much more detailed guides, explanations, and technical references.

Disclosure of interest: I'm leading the documentation effort at Rhize―feedback and requests are welcome!

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Do you have any examples of that middle by any chance? Agree that that would definitely be the sweet spot!

From my experience the products out there have either ridiculously expensive license models, or are tied to frameworks for which you need additional licenses and depend on multiple companies, are hard to interface with, use outdated technology, or all of the above.

I've seen (and participated in, at a previous employer) building from scratch too, which is a pain to maintain, dependant on the team (internal or integrator) and because of that a risk. It also costs time reinventing the wheel and often while things will work they're far from optimized since it's done by generalists like myself instead of having the DB schema designed by an expert DBA and so on.

With an open source initiative I mean (ideally multiple) people/companies building/maintaining a solid basis on which they and others can build and add features without paying ever increasing license costs. Start with a solid DB schema and some standard functionality, built with popular and free technology, for example start with a postgres DB and a .NET application exposing a REST API.

I really liked what I initially saw from Libre and starting from ISA95, even better if owned/maintained by not just 1 company.
