Author: vaansocial
Content:
Hi everyone. I am new to the world of MES so the messages here have been extremely helpful in learning and validating most of my assumptions. 

I have a specific case in mind that I'd like for you all to comment on:

Let's say I have been using RA FTPC as the MES and SAP for ERP. 

In my research, I saw several ways to integrate these systems, namely: 
1. B2MML connection
2. Mulesoft
3. Connect MES and ERP to UNS and establish relevant pub/sub 

Which are possible and ideal? Which method is most prevalent in the industry? 

Thanks!

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Rockwell has pre-built connector for SAP. Have you considered that?

Author: vaansocial
Content: Missed this lol, thank you. I was trying to perform a what-if scenario with the aforementioned options. Does Rockwell support UNS architecture?

Author: brianpribe
Content: Believe it or not, they don’t.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: The Rockwell Enterprise Integration Hub was based on Apache Camel last time I used it, which does support MQTT, so in theory you could achieve a Pub/Sub architecture with Rockell FTPC and EIHub.

Author: kevinhibbins
Content: I think it's really a methodology and approach, it certainly is in what we do. If you can keep things somewhat decoupled, it lowers risk and accelerates value if something needs to be upgraded or swapped out or added or retired or extended or duplicated or enhanced or customised or personalised. All while maintaining flexibility and scalability. I'm not sure whether this is art or science to be honest.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @kevinhibbins, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: kevinhibbins
Content: If you just consider SAP .... SAP has a number of integration options. Our go-to for many years (note I am not an SAP person rather a manufacturing integration guy) was to leverage MII and use IDOC transfer via an RFC destination configuration and direct RFC / BAPI calls via the JCo / JRA connections available in Netweaver (all straight forward in MII, thanks @RickBullotta  👍 ), though will eventually be phased out for DM / DMC which will leverage BTP / CPI / PCo et al. Rest API's may be available, plus PI/PO is likely around in places, and the dreaded flat file 🤨  I'm sure is still hanging around and used somewhere. I've seen many products say that they "integrate with SAP" but really they leverage an interposing SQL database or similar (which of course may work fine for certain use cases). I guess it depends on what type of integration you need, how often, how big, who owns it, how is it triggered, how is it monitored, what quality of service is important, how "bi-directional" it actually needs to be, etc. Need to consider the use case .... is it for flowing production & process orders to the shop floor / goods movements / production receipts / master data sync & transfer / quality plan & results integration / batch integration / etc. Lots of considerations!

Author: robin_pinna
Content:
@Vaan  Hi, I did some kind of integration between SAP and Siemens MES in the past year. Some key takeways about my work, that you might want to consider :
- SAP team wanted to do the least work possible on their side, so we were forced to initiate all transactions from the MES side. Let's say that it didn't go well since we had to get lots of data from SAP (WO, operations, instructions,...). SAP has to push data at some point.
- We used APIs for the communication MES -> SAP. If you were to use this, keep an eye on data size, it can seriously impact performance.
- We used IDOC for SAP -> MES communication afterward, and it was a decent way to get lots of data.

In the end, it's that first experience that made me come across UNS, when trying to find solutions to our problems 🙂

Author: nickn5549
Content: Well, you do your best...even in EMS you check optically the board for defects real time, but in circuit test can find some issues that optically you can't check, then any concerning fall out is reported back to SMT. Concerning fall out - lower than target yield, 3 same consecutive failures. ICT reporting complements the SMT OEE and can stop the SMT line if Quality at ICT is bad, which will affect the SMT OEE. We also calculate rolled yield for a product, not only OEE per area and it tells better the Quality story for the entire line.

Author: nickn5549
Content: For lazy C-suite people I want to run a sentiment analyst KPI, when lines are running at capacity, quality is good, people are happy an injury free, money are flowing then we are 😀 otherwise 🙃☹️😖😩😢😭😱

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
It can (theoretically) but it's not particularly useful to do. OEE is a lagging, comparative metric that has some use in comparing longer-term historical performance trends, but is of little use in real-time as it's too highly aggregated. OEE is a metric that help to assess the impact of performance improvement initiatives. Example: We fixed an issue with the case packer, did that have an impact on OEE?
Most Operational Excellence methodologies have a framework for 'Short Interval Control" which is typically hourly and about as 'Real-time' as a Shift Supervisor wants to be.
The question should not be "Is it possible" but rather "How would it change the way Operations run if"
The answer for real-time OEE is that it would not change the way most shift supervisors manage the day to day operations on a line, and nor should it. Digital Andon though, very useful in real-time

Author: nickn5549
Content: Well, we do measure in real time the A, P, Q, OEE and he have an Andon system for alerting who's needed to support the line. All together give you a good indication how the lines are running.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Do you have people watching the OEE dashboard as part of their job, and do they take real-time action in response the the OEE KPI exceeding some threshold?

Author: geoffnunan
Content: I imagine the Andon has already done the alerting, so the real-time OEE, while cool, is not actually the thing driving the behaviour

Author: nickn5549
Content: What do you call Andon - alerting system we need help from X?

Author: nickn5549
Content: We have targets, colour coding and notifications for A, P, Q and OEE. You sense the danger when everything is red. And all this stuff is also displayed on each line...difficult to miss...big screens suspended from the ceiling.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
I get it. But A, P, Q and OEE are historical KPI, calculated over a time period. If you make the time period short enough for the alerts based on thresholds to be usefull for real-time decisions, they just become defactos for line status.
The "I need help from X" is much more usefull to operations as its action oriented. Im not saying that you cant make OEE a defacto for line status, im just saying there are better options

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, do you really want your people interacting with the OEE system punching in microstop reasons and individual quality issues or focusing on getting the issues resolved? In Nick’s case he has very high levels of automation and automated test coverage.

Author: mattylevy
Content: Yes - People tend to think that just because the assets are running, then everything is fine. But in reality, all those micro-stops or speed losses are adding up and you’re nowhere near running at the technical capability of the process. Assuming you set the standard correctly, providing a transparent view on the simple OEE%(even if the quality element is back calculated) will likely lead to better performance if managed correctly. Even just a rolling X hours(depends on nature of process) at a 15 min refresh rate or something around those lines - nothing crazy. If you have multiple processes in series with no inventory buffer in between, the time series trends of that rolling OEE will also tell you where the live bottleneck is, which may shift and go unnoticed. Real time downtime classification can also be powerful if it is objective, automated and the model incorporates other data sources that the operator may not have a view on through the HMI.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Right. So not real time. 😈

Author: nickn5549
Content: OEE is calculated for each shift, people are working shifts, reporting is per shift and questions are about a shift - hey, how is this shift going?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Yes, thats pretty common, but particularly towards the end of the shift, a delay takes a while to impact the metrics, making OEE alerts a bit lagging.
Again, not saying you cant do it, or that someone wont find some value in the visibility, but its a lagging indicator that does not mean that much to the people on the floor in real-time.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @GeoffNunan, you just advanced to level 12!

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
the "I need help from X" alert, particularly when part of a workflow that then tracks the response time and resolution time are more valuable to most operations teams.
Combine that with rule based escalation times, and reason specific thresholds and your getting somewhere. Ive also seen companies implement operator specific throughput or takt time targets to great effect.
Moving outside of real-time is where there can actually be a lot of aditional value to be created. Simple things lile making the list of open issues for that machine visible to the operator, along the the status, assigned person and expected resolution time.
Tracking these tasks gives you leading metrics rather than lagging like OEE

Author: nickn5549
Content: I wouldn't focus on the lagging part of the OEE (which by the way I update at takt time) I would focus on overall message that it tells.

Author: geoffnunan

Yep, but this thread is in reponse to the question "can oee be a real-time metric?"
I still say yes, but it does not add any aditional value for it to he real-time

Aka they focus on optimizing a number instead of looking at operations holistically. Imho OEE and other KPIs should be an indicator that something is going on that warrants further investigation. The ultimate goal for a factory shouldn’t be to optimize OEE but to optimize operations, which is obvious when said aloud but people get hyper focused on KPIs

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Is that not saying." People are using OEE badly so OEE is no use"?
As @GeoffNunan said, it is a lagging not leading indicator, 

Any organisation I have worked with, more than 20, would look at the high OEE, and look to find the root cause. maybe the 5 Whys.
And then find the root cause and fix it.
None would look at a shift see a low OEE and say" no Bonus for Shift 2 this year"

I was talking to a Plant Operations lead,on Friday. We were showing how to drill down from a Plant view to the machine view, and how to look at Shift, Day or customer ranges  and he literally said,
He's not too interested in the Shift OEE but the Daily( 3 Shift) figure and the weekly figures is where he operates.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Most trivialize this.  One of things that confused me early on learning about MES and IIoT was how people handled revised records and late arriving data.  The material flow and events can be incredibly complicated with cellular manufacturing, sampling, tool offsetting, etc.  I realized most were simply ignoring quality - especially "in-process" quality.  To me, first pass yield / first time through is like the most important indicator of the integrity or efficacy of a process.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342

Author: r.pop
Content: I’ve had a few instances of customers where OEE made no sense to measure. Their cycle times were days, weeks, months, not seconds or minutes. For them we just looked at Utilization and Downtime. In a 24 hour period, how long was a machine “Utilized” vs. when did it sit Idle. Other customers had their own way of measuring OEE that they thought was best for their business. Don’t get too caught up in the “gospel”, at the end of the day we’re trying to deliver systems that help our customers be better today than they were yesterday. Who cares whether it’s “true” OEE or not.

Author: pjgeldenhuis
Content: Has anyone used the AVEVA  Web API to integrate a Siemens control system and traditional MES? Also, has anyone seen a successful integration between a traditional MES and control system through an UNS in the life sciences space? @MikeBartlett, @js, @giladl curious to get your thoughts here.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: Hey PJ - last I knew AVEVA PI has native connectivity to PCS7 and to some traditional MES  systems (pulling information TO PI), for the purposes of aggregating recipe and batch events with process data.  You should be able to use a flavor of OPC to go back in the other direction.  Old school unfortunately.  Not sure where you'd need to fit WebAPI in the mix, but info on the use case would help.  I left AVEVA before UNS became more mainstream so haven't kept up on streaming capabilities, but have seen the cool HighByte integration to PI that seems like it would be more efficient and open for connecting these systems.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @MikeBartlett, you just advanced to level 8!

Author: pjgeldenhuis
Content: @MikeBartlett - thanks for the quick reply! For example, let’s say there is a requirement to have a batch start and end time captured in the MES, which originates in PCS7. Ideally this will be event driven and automatically be pushed to the MES system. Using the PI Web API the data can be pulled into the MES, but not pushed I think - probably the same if native MES-PI connectivity is possible. Not having done this before I assume a direct integration between PCS7 and the MES system will be possible, but more complicated and may “strain” the PCS. Going the other direction, let’s say you are making a certain product with recipe in the MES system and would like to automatically push the recipe to the PCS to eliminate the potential for selecting the incorrect recipe. I am fairly sure the PI Web API will not make sense here, but could be wrong. I think HighByte, HiveMQ or something similar will be ideal here for both examples - @MikeBartlett do you agree? Also, how would you architect the above two examples? @Omar curious to get your thought here.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: @PJG The last time I saw a demo, your MES (if it is the one I'm thinking of) supports pulling data in via OPC-DA, so if you have the OPC Server licensed from AVEVA that may be an option instead of PI Web API.  Otherwise, yes, if the MES can query a REST Endpoint, that query is possible.  I wouldn't query the PCS7 unless it persists data somehow.  Going the other way, if the PCS7 has a Batch Execution System, I would think that recipe push capability would be native or conform to some sort of standard.  If you are building the recipe out of logic, it would be odd to use the PI Web API unless you are storing those recipe parameters in PI.  You might be able to push OPC via an output from MES to PI tags or use a PI connector to query a REST endpoint on the MES if that exists.  To me HighByte or HiveMQ would be more ideal for this use case.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Can you elaborate on the HiveMQ part?  I know there are some enterprise extensions, but I thought they were for logging publishes from topics to databases, kafka, etc.  How is PI or MES integration approached?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Rhize is in use in several Bio Pharma companies, and is the global standard for Moderna.
There are 3 use-cases that we see in Bio Pharma:
1 - Real-time batch record. The Rhize platform sits between the DCS and the MES and orchestrates workflows between the two, capturing all the data as it goes. We can then do some really smart things with deviation management, and can generate a real-time batch record.
2 - Brown-field MES. There are a lot of factories that have DCS / PLC systems that were implemented long ago, and adding a new MES on top of them in the traditional "Top-down" command and control approach is not feasible. In the Rhize platform, you configure your processes and the platform listens to the equipment status, keeping track of batch execution and phases even if the PLC does not. This is the basis of a "Bottom-up MES approach for Bio Pharma that can be implemented without a wholesale re-implementation of the control system.
3 - Predictive batch analysis: In Bio Pharma, batch harvest times can vary greatly from batch to batch, and knowing when to harvest can have a big impact on overall throughput. By using the "Bottom-Up" approach, we can get contextualised, real-time data that can be used to predict batch harvest times. At one customer's site, we are able to predict the optimal harvest time 24 hrs prior to harvest with an accuracy of +- 5 minutes.

If my scada is down I want hmi to execute these recipes but then how does the handshake between all these PLCs work?

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
All depends on what your system looks like and what your priorities are.

I find that MES (and batch control) systems are way more efficient in doing recipe management and coordination control, especially across multiple PLC's.
Easier to build, easier to maintain, easier to update and validate. Of course if there's real time interfacing needed between units you'll need to do that on a lower level.

Yes you can build all this in the PLC's as well, but this might be a big effort up front and a pain later on.
Often people indeed start with the question "but what if MES is down?" and conclude they have to make sure they can run without it and build everything in the PLC.
But then you have to consider the additional costs (now and down the line) and/or limitations in the future, and ask yourself the question how long can you really run without SCADA/MES, usually recipe management is not the only function here.

In my opinion it's almost always better to spend your efforts on making SCADA/MES more robust rather than adding extra complexity on the PLC level.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Also just replied on LinkedIn, mostly agree.

What's needed is AND modularity and open interfaces AND a solid underlying data model. 
The article words that well "A robust MES requires a comprehensive data model, transactional integrity, traceability, and control mechanisms".

Unfortunately today it seems to be one of the following:
- Stick with "oldschool" MES vendors and end up with an expensive monolith of which a lot of functionality isn't used, and on the other hand is missing functionality but is hard to build on or interface with
- Apps are the new MES, end up without a proper data model and a SaaS license model that doesn't scale with your enterprise
- Build your own MES, big initial effort both cost and time wise, and hard to properly validate and maintain

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
We've definitely come a long way in the past year with the product. Here are some answers to your questions:
- kubernetes is not for the faint of heart, it's a very powerful but complex platform that takes some time to master.
- under the hood is a react UI for configuring ISA95 entities, a bunch of golang microservices, NATS as the MQTT Broker and message queue platform and our graphql native, graph based, ACID compliant database which started as a fork of dgraph 2 years ago, and to which we've added and refactored quite a bit. The database is now our own code. We are also embedding AppSmith as the UI development platform for low-code user interfaces.

We are not yet suitable for small manufacturing companies due to the complexity of kubernetes. At some point in the future we will offer a cloud-hosted version of the platform so that small manufacturing companies don't have to worry about the infrastructure.

@Andy German  is the best person to talk to for the rest of your questions. He looks after the UK and EU and is based in the UK.
Our docs are open-source, the product is not.

I have used Sepasoft for OEE and genealogy (track & trace). It is based on ISA-95 and employs most of the Part 2 models. I have not used their Batch module, but have heard positive feedback. Author: rutger_18900
Content:
And because for building (a full scale) MES you need a good understanding of the production processes and flows in the company, as well as the architecture and functionality of connected business and plant floor automation/controls systems to a certain extent. Of course it all depends on what MES functionalities are required in the project phase.

The main reason I see for failing MES implementations is not enough collaboration between business stakeholders, integrators and owners of the different systems. You can't just walk up to an integrator, say "build me a fully integrated MES", give some vague requirements and expect a successful result. Building a system that connects business and plant floor systems requires extensive collaboration.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Use a well defined and preferably standard interface, e.g. ISA88/PackML.

Make sure each system has its own data structure to write to, to which the other system has read-only access.
I've seen multiple implementations where there was for example 1 integer value for a handshake to which both PLC and SCADA/MES were writing, and then there'd always be timing issues and systems "speaking out of turn".
Account for abnormal situations in handshaking signals, foresee alarming and a way to recover.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
What do yo mean when you say "handshake"
Is it just a watchdog to monitor comms, or is it acknowledgement that data has been received, i.e. is the record of the barcode scan now stored in the Database?

Author: Deleted User
Content: The latter. Data collection confirmation, MES logic feedback, push/pull data request, etc.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: We generally assemble up transactional data from the PLC and trigger via Ignition gateway tag change scripts.  Part of the assembled data when we trigger is a transaction number.  The PLC logic is such that if a response is not received in the required timeout then we fault the equipment.  The logic also allows the user to retry the transactions from the HMI.  so for example if there was a network outage for some reason. Once the network connection was restored the transaction can be retried.   We also have buffers in the PLC to allow for situations like these.  Quite honestly  we rarely ever use it.   We also do some stuff with linked DB's if we need to run unconnected from the network for and disaster situation.  Never really use that either.   In terms of feedback of MES faults. The PLC/HMI faults match error returns from MES for the most part.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I had a user case a few years ago where we were scanning a Barcode, comparing the String to the Item No from the ERP, if it did not match the line would stop, but we wanted to capture all the results of the test. Similarly we would check weight the item and record the weight the pass fail and the label barcode.

And Quality insisted that we would not lose any records , 
and Operations insisted that could not stop the line because of IT issues. 
Our Stack was AB PLC -> WW IO -> System Platform -> WWMES->MII ->SAP.

So the results would be buffered in a 100 long array.
If the position 0 had data in the buffer, a Data Available Tag would be set to 1 by the PLC. 
That would trigger a script in System Platform that would Insert the Data in the MES DB Table.
if the script ran without an error, then System Platform would reset the Data Available Tag to 0.
In the PLC if the Data Available Tag was 0, the Buffer would position shift and if the position 0 had data in the buffer ..... 

If the Buffer overflowed, then the line would stop. 
It never did but it did get to the 80's, until the scripting was refined 

We updated it so instead of setting a Data Available Bit, we gave each quality check a unique ID, QCID and then instead of  resetting the bit we passed the Sam transaction number back down to a "Last Stored Transaction" Tag, and if that matched the same QCID in Position 0 then the buffer shifted.

I'd probably approach it differently today and pass the data in Position 0 to a MQTT Broker, and have my MES subscribe to the buffer and parse out the transactions and store in a DB, and then publish back the last Transaction ID and allow the PLC to subscribe to that. Not sure if you could pass all the items in the buffer as a single JSON, and do a multi read, assuming you could pass back multiple Transaction ID' s it could work

Author: Deleted User
Content:
This is great. Aligns with my idea of a good implementation. 
- Response timeout logic
- clear fault visualization (HMI and/or stacklight)
- HMI front end manual retry capabilities
- potentially, small iterations of staggered auto-retry logic (1 sec delay, 2 second delay, 5 second delay, fault)
- passing rich error codes
- pushing error message to avoid unnecessary dictionary management in the client
- avoid using 0 or null for error codes
- avoid writing to the exact same tag to avoid race conditions
- offline mode / bypass mode with client side data collection

Author: Deleted User
Content: I wish there was a standard and clear documentation available which outlines these design principles. I also wish there was something like REST API used instead which enforced many of these principles natively

Author: Deleted User

I like the idea of MQTT with business systems which are cloud based or vulnerable due to the fact that a shop floor client must subscribe to receive data transmission. I assume this makes it more difficult for bad actors to abuse a device via a DMZ exposed MQTT broker.
But, I'm not confident in the MQTT configuration change  management or SparkPlugB yet. I'm not confident someone won't accidentally change the MQTT publish data and that it would be easy to troubleshoot.

Author: Deleted User
Content: Plus the amount of gateways potentially needed to enable this architecture..

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The buffer in the PLC would operate at PLC cycle time so 100ms
The Insert mechanism took a few seconds.
Depending on the line in the plant some were filling at 2 per minute, some 8 per minute, and some were 30 pails a minute.
The Insert into the DB was initially taking a few seconds, and sometimes it might take 60.
Our first machine to go live was the 8 per minute, and the buffer was filling,
 
We changed the Polling frequency for the buffer related tags, down from 1 Second to maybe 200ms. But the main culprit was the insert scripts.
I didn't recode the scripts, but I think that initially there were two scripts one being called by the other, and that was where most of the problem was.
after the change the script processed in a few hundred milliseconds, I think , but certainly the buffers on the 8 pail per minute machines never filled, and the buffers on the high speed machine might get as high as 20 over a few hours, but a break time or downtime would allow the buffer to be cleared.

It was the sometimes taking 60s was the the big issue,

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I understand the concern about the Publish, 
that is one thing I like about Sparkplug is the Device ID can help with that.

In I3.0 world I wouldn't worry that someone might change the IO driver settings, and certainly I have seen people polling the wrong tag , or register in Modbus.

If I was implementing it to day ,on a machine that doesn't have SpB natively
 I would have node red running on an edge device in the Machine and do the buffering in that. 
If you run a edge broker locally you can have node red, read the data from the PLC, and publish to the Broker. QoS=1 and Retain.
And enable store forward 
A client with QoS=1 will then get all the messages.
or you can use a timescale DB
The issue with buffers in the PLC is they can take up a lot of memory, a lot of the machines we had were running AB 17XX-L85 but we had 8 to 10 Quality checks, and wanted a buffer size of 100. On smaller machines with smaller PLC's we ended up with 10 buffers( those were the slower lines but it was ok)

I have some Node red flows doing that I can send on if you want.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Ahh I see. Could sending batch jobs and reporting back aggregated data back have been an option also?

60s sounds extremely terrible. 
Pretty creative to implement a buffer as interim until the query was more performant!
That is a very nice way to buy troubleshooting time without impacting production

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Yes, polling wrong data can definitely be an issue. I guess I already had a pretty streamlined process with the tag polling method I was comfortable with. All our tag configurations were stored in a SQL DB with a station assignment/mapping reference.  So I just created a query which returned all the tags in the PLC handshake in XML format against their station assignment. Then I would just add one header line to the XML file and load the XML file in the OPC client, which would allow me to poll/view the tags on my PC. 
With this I could see each station handshake in realtime with a timestamp. If data changes occurred but the SQL database did not update or the manufacturing system front end did not reflect, I knew there was some errors in the logic. And vice versa if I was expecting a PLC action.
I really liked this because the manufacturing system was configurable and I could easily replicate viewing the data on my client within a minute.
In Addition, I could easily browse the device namespace if I had any doubts or needed to pull some tag names. 

My hesitation with MQTT has been the lack of browse ability, configuration, and troubleshooting. But now that you describe it, I think I could just subscribe to all topics on my PC client manually through a custom script, like python or something, using the MQTT handshake configuration data. And, as you mentioned, if QoS=1 then should receive all messages, including the last stored value upon MQTT client  initialization. Essentially recreating OPC client. I like it. 

With QoS and store and forward, I wonder if PLC buffering would ever even be needed anymore? 
Won't the broker handle that instead?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
that is a really nice approach for the Tag Polling.
someone might have a better approach for the MQTT topics

But 100% if I was solving the same problem today, I would not buffer in the PLC and would install an edge device, with Node Red and a Broker
When I tried to use node red to publish to a broker on another node, even with QOS=1 and retain It did not buffer for me.

you can use an AEDES broker within Node red if you want.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I have not tried it out at a scale so I am surer there will be issues, but a Raspberry Pi and FlowFuse to manage the devices.
My view is that standard HA clusters, are great for scheduled downtime but
- I have had issues with It updates being applies and services not starting after reboot (and the IT guy not checking them, maybe be cause the OT guy tell them to, or update the correct details)
- for unexpected downtime events,  while l I am told it is seconds, I found it was normally in minutes( 2 to 5 I would say), and that could be over 1000 quality records
- for Operations Fault Tolerance is required, but there is normally significant  push back on that for cost. when I worked in Terminal's for one upgrade we were looking at ExaBytes of Storage, if an application needed 100GB of storage and 2000GB of  Data Storage, (X2 for RAID, X2 for HA X2 for FT across 20 or so VM's and an Identical Preproduction setup, along with Dev and test environments and some IT VM's as well.

I favour, High Availability (HA) setup with active-passive redundancy. you have two applications running on separate servers, and both the primary and secondary are monitoring, each other and you get a failover that truly only takes seconds.

Or how we used to do it in the old Days, Two Desktop machines running the same InTouch application. Sometimes we even turned the monitor on the secondary off.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Yeah, I understand. It's not always a perfect world, and IT is not always the most supportive or understanding. But, I think in these scenarios we should hold IT accountable. Any mission critical on premise service should be properly monitored, by a services like solarwinds/splunk/grafana for instance, during all operational hours. This should have proper alerting thresholds configured, at the bare minimum, alerting if a service goes down. And, ideally the OT poc should also be alerted if this service goes down, but that may go into an ownership debate lol. In addition, a great IT will have strict change management (while a pain) and good RCA investigations, with the option to submit emergency change request when needed. A VM should not take weeks/months to provision, firewall changes should not take weeks/months to be applied, IT changes should not be unplanned/uncommunicated, changes should happen according to business downtime windows, and security patches should be as up to date as possible. 

I've seen a good scenario where OT owns the applications and shop floor OT hardware (non-networking), but IT owns the infrastructure and enterprise hardware. Of course there was fighting, especially because of the technical language barrier between the 2 teams, but I believe it is possible. 
In my opinion, OT will miss out on far too many great IT inventions like HA clusters and now even container orchestration if OT keeps pushing IT out.
These HA inventions/designs are truly fantastic, in my opinion, which is why you see AWS, meta, and Google have like 99.99% uptime with 24/7 operations.

Author: rafaamaral
Content:
Take a look at TilliT (www.gotillit.com). We have been maintaining number one on software reviews (https://www.softwarereviews.com/categories/manufacturing-execution-systems-midmarket) (midmarket and not gartner yet)
But we are a cloud hosted low-code MES platform that gives you a ISA95 data structure and API out of the box and a configurable workflow engine with cool features like inbuilt barcode scanner, PDF reports via email, configurable dashboards and embedded analytics.
Plus, if you are a ignition user, we have an ignition module that allows you to do 2 way communication with TilliT in a very developer friendly experience. DM me for a demo. We can organize demos/trials and the pricing is based on consumption so it scales well, typically 1/5th of traditional deployments.

Author: diederik9434
Content:
Hi everyone, I'm looking for a historian fitting for my usecase.
I have a beginning OEM that wants to collect data from its machines worldwide.

Ideally it should be: cloudbased, easy to setup & maintain, able to connect to MQTT and/or OPCUA and cheap

We very price bound and not very IT minded. Ideally i would have a historian as a service somewhere in the cloud. I dont know many of these. (Factry.io & Canary?) These are pricy. 

Second best option i could think of is to reproduce their functionality kinda DIY.
using cloud grafana, cloud influx/timescaledb and nodered connection i was able to make something.

other option is to have a local NAS with some docker containers and visualize locally (and connect over VPN?)

Anyone has some experiences/recommendations? 

Thanks! Diederik

Author: naderock
Content:
Hi everyone,
Does anyone here have any experience with using MongoDB for MES system?
I want to have some feedback the pro and cons.
I ask this as we see SQL will drop some events in heavily load and I'm thinking of using noSQL DB for our MES.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Can't specifically say in your sitution, but Tulip uses MongoDB for the machine monitoring side of the platform which must ingest a lot of attributes, then machine state is calculated with a bunch of other metadata and written to another table in MongoDB.

Author: dapomeranz
Content: @nader I do not think choosing between NoSQL and SQL is relevant to the problem you are describing. Sounds more like DevOps/Networking issues. Can you describe more about the database you currently have in place?

Author: naderock
Content: Client use MS SQL and we Dev track and trace function. The problem is our events is too much something like 3000 per seconds. I increase no of change script thread in ignition and pool size. We also separate backend from frontend in two different sever.

Author: naderock
Content: The MS SQL is use only for MES data and use separate server for ignition history and all connect together locally with 1gbit ethernet port

Author: naderock
Content: May be using mongodb help me to horizontally scale the system to increase performance

Author: dapomeranz
Content: Again, the benefits of NoSQL are not usually performance related. I would investigate historian databases like TimescaleDB or InfluxDB. Others in this community know a lot more than I do about heading down that path.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: Nader - one approach we've been adding into our MES architecture is a more distributed "execution", where you have master data in a central datastore and push the running order down to edge compute and batch load the MES events back to a central data store. MongoDB could probably solve some of the performance issues in your database, but could be a complete rewrite of your MES logic. Without understanding the bigger picture and technical details of the MES implementation it's hard to say if MongoDB would solve your issues. I can say that moving into a completely new backend built for flexibility and scalability as it leverages documents rather than fixed schema with indexing.  You've got me curious about the requirements that drove 3000 traceability events per second. Can you elaborate?

Author: naderock
Content:
The client manufacturer MCB which includes several steps to make it in several lines and also the MES include OEE calc as well and some custom check sheet control for operators.
I really like your idea about batch load events into central dB. 
I believe this will fix this problem easily. 
Also eventually our history data of events for both t&t and oee getting larger and larger and without using partitioning the data on tables, some day the query will be very slow. On the other hand partitioning logic makes performance down so what do you suggest for this problem?

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @nader, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: jpmoniz
Content: We are in the process of working on a hybrid approach  where we are using SQL and Neo4j for MES.   The Idea being SQL is basically runtime DB and short term storage of MES events and configurations.   Longer term storage gets moved into Neo4j,   We have been finding that a labeled property graph like Neo4j is more conducive for querying large long term data sets like this. So far the idea seems to be working out well.  We have much still to figure out on technical aspects but  seems to be a logical approach.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Nothing fits a geneaology/traceability use case better than a graph database!

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Yes it works very well.   I eventually see us shifting over to complete usage of it as the core.  Starting small just to learn and figure things out

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I have a lot of experience using Neo4J for "non-traditional" (read: non-graph) use cases too.  The key is to leverage the various index providers along with Neo4J (versus graph traversal in some cases).  I even wrote a high performance time series database using Neo4J - in 2012 I was getting 25,000 inserts per second on a laptop, while actively querying it.  It can do a lot!

Author: jpmoniz
Content: It would be interesting to see the timeseries solution. The whole time bucket thing start to push the limits of my grey matter.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Here ya go:

https://www.infoq.com/presentations/Graph-Database-Power-Web-of-Things/

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Here's the slides.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Huge fan of the Mash up point of view.  One of the visions I have is merging the the MES graph with the other domains within the org to work towards that MashUp view point.  I think there is a ton of unknown upside by doing so.

Author: singhnitish.disc
Content: my organization has decided to build its own MES... we are basically deciding whether to start from scratch or use an established platform/software to begin with. The focus is on easy access to data and dashboards, ease of use, report publishing. Personally, I feel building everything from scratch might be a lengthy endeavor. Thoughts/suggestions?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Tulip

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I certainly would not say build from Scratch.

I always suggest , that you start with an open Platform you can build a MES, and other solutions on and Integrate into .

Building from Scratch is very hard, if you a really starting from scratch. 
Project 1 is create software, Project 3 is solve problems.
Configuring a platform, and augmenting that with some custom build, lets you start solving problem at the start.

Of course you can build what I would call a "Proto-MES" using the MING stack or similar to give you access to Data and some Dashboards, and even some MES functionality but you may struggle as you scale. and that is sort of a Platform too , or a collection of them

Below is one of the first 4.0 solutions video's I watched, and I think the debate really became, is to 60% build and 40$ buy or 40% buy and 60% build
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IfflYuvNrnI

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I think Tulip changes things a bit. You're not starting completely from scratch. You have a composable platform, application libraries, and direct support.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I do wish automations were a lot more capable than they currently are though.  And much better support for getting external data into visualizations, logic and analytics.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: No doubt. Looking forward to seeing what I can do with automations when we upgrade to LTS 12.

Author: dapomeranz
Content: I know I am in the wrong community 🤣  but for discrete MES these weaknesses are way less of an issue. Tulip crushes.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I guarantee that you would get a lot of value out of automations if they were more comprehensive (e.g. like Losant or Node-RED)

Author: nickn5549

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Can as ask the components, and programming languages?
It is a very viable option , and I have been part of teams that build MES with a SQL backend and .Net frontend, but it was sitting on top of Aveva System Platform( given how long ago it was actually Wonderware System Platform), and that did help

Author: nickn5549
Content: EMS by default has a different 'core 4' which you can't get as core in many standard MES solutions. We used an unusual platform, which was not that unusual 8 years ago when we started - LabVIEW

Author: nickn5549
Content: Components wise....its core was focused on WO management, materials traceability, MSL (Moisture Sensitive Devices life shelf), enforced routings (process traceability), Quality Module (Yields, top defects,  SPC, etc),  The other bits came  later on as addons (web-based apps) Production Schedule, OEE, Downtime Reporting...and we are still building on it...

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I meant the components for building, not the functionality , poor wording on my part.

Sounds like what I would call a Labview core with a microservices approach as addons

Author: nickn5549
Content: Labview first, all logic done using it and MSSQL for storage, microservices came a bit later....once we discovered MQTT

Author: jwrkmn4
Content: Oh man our LabVIEW + Thingworx + Diadem chimera for our engineering lab received less than favorable reviews at my company. …And it’s been “in development” for years. Our life testing system is Node Red and Ignition based, thank goodness. Lots of promising opportunities there.

Think SCPI messages and command and control over MQTT and full automation of any instrumentation with a VISA back end.

Author: r.pop
Content: @RickBullotta This was indeed a challenge to overcome, especially when dealing with Barcode scanning.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: So you mean like Tulip? 😉

Author: rafaamaral
Content:
A few of our customers are moving from poweapps or airtable to TilliT. Why? First because you have to keep reinventing the wheel with basic manufacturing data, such as orders, shifts, materials, etc. You end up spending a lot of time with the basic. 
Then you start to miss some basic manufacturing required features like GS1, OCR, connectivity to control system, events, the list go on and on.
So it works to get started and get some forms up. But to then make the factory smart. Non manufacturing tools starts to tap out. Or your budget will.

Author: rafaamaral
Content:
IMHO the trick is to find the right level of abstraction. One that doesn't limit you but is able to solve problems quick. You need to be quick because there are so many opportunities in a typical manufacturing environment. 
You also don't want to build a Frankenstein. So having a standard data model can help a lot. IMHO, biased, option.

Author: nathancarlson
Content: Hey folks - I work in the Midstream pipeline business and I’m trying to translate what an MES/MOM would look like in our business.  I think we typically see companies use their SCADA systems to coordinate and hit their daily/monthly contracted nominations and so I’ve been thinking about this as a batch process based off the intra-day nominations, daily nominations and monthly OBA (over balance agreement).  What are some examples of MES in this business? Is MES more targeted at plant level execution while MOM might combine plants and their connecting pipeline conditions to coordinate/plan and execute across the entire system?  If so what are some examples of software that does this off the shelf?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Comparing apples and hand grenades, generally.  Traditional MES/MOM is usually a lousy fit for any continuous processes (for that matter, so are a lot of the typical KPIs like OEE, industry models like ISA95, and so on).

Author: nathancarlson
Content: Thanks Rick - are there some resources or standards you could point me to that are a better fit for continuous processes?

Author: ultraphoenix.
Content: Hello, has TULIP been adopted in the pharmaceutical industry? If so, how can we ensure that it is FDA/21 CFR Part 11 compliant after having  composed  a new app ?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Extensively. @giladl can provide specifics.

Author: giladl
Content: @ultraphoenix yes Tulip has been adopted by the pharma and biopharma industry and is used in GMP operations. It natively complies with Part 11 and Annex 11 and as well as ALCOA+. You can read more here: https://tulip.co/trust-center/compliance/ The platform comes fully qualified and therefore you don't need to test built in features such as electronic signatures for every app. If you adopt Validation 4.0 principles then app validation for intended use becomes a seamless process. More about Validation 4.0 here https://ispe.org/pharmaceutical-engineering/march-april-2021/breaking-tradition-laying-foundation-validation-40

Author: hobbes1069
Content: As far as specific approaches to validation, we decided to validate the platform through IT and consider applications to be "configurations" of the validated platform rather than custom code. Then any GxP apps which require individual validation have a risk assessment performed to decided if testing, unscripted testing, or scripted testing is required for each data element.

Author: ultraphoenix.
Content: Thank you guys for these feedback. we usually work with Pas-x or Siemens Opcenter Pharma, since we are building a partnership with Tulips so as to adress Composable Apps (as much MES feature centric even we all know that is not MES) if it GXP compliant that is going to be an interesting challenge recommanding pure tradtionnal MES vs composable platform . I like fast time to market app delivery from a existing apps baseline, but on of the cons we were facing at is OPC UA write missing ? tell me if a m wrong

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Where is the line of what should be followed on the ERP and what on the MES? following an production order between machines, fould be on the ERP or the MES? I see it more fit to the MES idea, but see it is done on the ERP so I ask if there is a convention or a reason to do something in one and not on the other. Someone could clarify what should be done on each application?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Depends on a lot of factors - what industry you're in, the level of accounting needed at the ERP level, the granularity of the manufacturing models at the ERP level, and so on.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I always think,
MES functions - Are theses the responsibility of the Plant Manager, Area Managers and Team Leads. Once the Manufacturing Order comes from the ERP untill you tell the ERP is Done, then it is MES.

But some MES functions can be done by the ERP. No problem there.
Some MES functions can be implemented in a SCADA, No problem there either.

I don't get stressed about if MES functions are in a MES or another system.
But, But , But......... The important thing is MES functions need a Production level of response for issues and cannot be caught in a ITSM system that requires forms to be submitted, and then reviewed by a level 1 tech and routed to the correct team ( Or returned because the wrong form was used  🤯 )

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Walker talks a lot of how good tulip is, I saw it has its university. What is your thoughts? Is time better spend learning to build a MES system on Ignition or is better to study and develop it on tulip?

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
We're a Tuilp house and I have about 4 years experience with it now. It's very different from Ignition. It really comes down to how you want to work. Do you want full stack developers with a git repo to store all your python scripts, etc? Or do you want the average Engineer to be able to develop applications?

Keep in mind with Tulip you get pretty much everything. They've already configured the database backend including Timescale for machine monitoring. Application version management. Edge devices. Everything.

Author: vikanchira
Content: Tulip is good for interaction with people where as Ignition is good with machines connectivity. Sometimes use both to complement each other.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: That's kind of true. Tulip only has OPC UA and now MQTT for machine monitoring, but if you add Kepserver, which all their customers do, it's a very powerful machine monitoring platform.

Author: vikanchira
Content: I prefer the Tulip + N3uron Combo. N3uron has great REST API Server and Client that works very well with Tulip. We have been setting up some Machine Monitoring demos since we started selling Tulip in Thailand.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I haven't explored N3uron yet but long term I plan to reduce the need for Kepserver by using gateways and publish from the shop floor up instead of polling the machines.

Author: vikanchira
Content: Give N3uron a try. I would also say that Tulip doesn't do high frequency historian  data storage as well. That's the main reason for us to use both N3uron & Tulip together.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Yes, you're right there, fastest rate is 1Hz. We're looking at a combination of Tulip and Canary at one site with high speed manufacturing.

Author: vikanchira
Content: That is the ideal 'premium' option 👍

Author: giladl
Content: @vikan yes that is a very good way of explaining it. @Richard Shaw also has a good point. Another way to look at it is: Not all factories and processes have or need a SCADA, but they nearly all have people so draw your conclusions.

Author: the_og4249
Content:
Hey all! Still getting up to speed here and learning fast. My company build signs: think car dealerships and fast food/restaurant branding. We also do a lot of directionals for hospitals, and signs/atm surrounds for banks.

We are trying to move from a purely paper-based MES (with different processes across 3 shops) to a Power Apps solution. At first this will be just uploading the work order packet and being able to view it on tablets on the floor, but eventually we could get more complex with distributing information to different departments. 

For those who have mentioned Power Apps as a solution, what are some benefits? concerns? Concerns for IT/support? We are looking at using Github actions to manage environments and have a pipeline for release.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Tulip would be perfect but your company may not be big enough for it to make sense financially. Worth looking into though.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Check out Tillit , DM me if you would like a demo. https://gotillit.com/

Author: nickn5549
Content: interesting....is Tillit doing MES also outside of food and beverage and other batch manufacturing industries? Discrete manufacturing?

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Absolutely not just a tool for F&B. It does your core mes things like OEE, track and trace. the front line operations aspects by removing paper based forms is where its super powerful IMO. Therefore any events like prestart checks , quality checks can all be captured. All SOPs are then digitised to be able to step operation through tasks. The production scheduling is the best i have seen also.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: @Raf Amaral is the brains behind Tillit. He's a great guy, and I'l sure would be happy to answer any questions.

Author: rafaamaral
Content: Hi Nick. Yes. We have customers outside food and bev, including life science, inject moulding shops, and other general manufacturing. Usually the theme is if you have a work order and you are producing things on a relatively repeatable way. The low code and workflow nature allows you to model the system in a wide range of ways.

Author: the_og4249

I have been told there is nothing so permanent as a temporary solution however

Author: mariano.beracochea

Author: r.pop
Content: From what I have observed. Tulip is well placed in heavy manual operations. Where a human drives the majority of a process and not the machine.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I worked with one customer who was told their process was too fast for Tulip. ~200-400 pieces per minute
and speaking with Tulip at Hannover they really talked about human speed.

Hands down it is the slickest Operator Interface I have seen, but I see it as a node in the ecosystem not a single solution

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Tulip is not an HMI. It’s an interface for a manufacturing process or broader workflow. The value is in the ability for a wider audience, outside of just industrial control systems engineers, to play a roll in building apps.

The vast majority of Ignition projects I’ve seen are classic HMI projects to read and write tag data from machines. Most Tulip projects I’ve seen are focused on guiding an operator through a process with interactive work instructions, enforcing quality procedures, with audit-grade logging, executing complex manufacturing transactions, etc. This is not say that there are not exceptions to this, but rather there is probably a good reason for these observations. There is a difference in the focus and problems the users are solving.

These discussions would better be oriented around “what capabilities do I need to support specific types of use cases with the right time to value” rather than “how many HMI clients can I get for the lowest cost?”.  Understanding what scales well is function of what are the things operators need to interface with. Do they just need to monitor and interact with machines? Or are there more comprehensive business processes that span beyond the machine? Who will build and maintain these screens?

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: Thanks for the mention. Indeed we have a deployment of more than 1000 stations, about 1500 frontline workers and almost 200 active citizen developers.  Tulip must be part of a strategy to offer those closest to the problems a simple yet powerful solution to help them solve them, based on the principle that IT can only be a bottleneck in a digital transformation. We use Tulip for the majority of our manual and warehouse activities, but increasingly as a unified HMI that federates the various "systems of record" in the form of "role-based apps". Tulip is connected both to applications primarily via REST and to machine data via UNS. Tulip also plays a key role in contextualizing data from manual operations.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Anyone use CDC (change data capture) with an MES tables ? Currently we are using query based capture to Kafka  which works well but not sure if the negatives for enabling CDC.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The approach I've generally taken with this is API calls for real-time consumption ("right now") and utilize the report server options for historical consumption (e.g., last shift, yesterday, last week) as well as BI workloads.  In many cases, "slightly-stale-but-high-quality" MES data can be better than "fresh" MES data.  For example, I'd rather wait for a record of four hours of idle time to be reviewed and properly reclassified than accept rolling KPIs that are volatile and don't reflect reality.  Because the real-time consumption can differ from the historical consumption, CDC may not necessarily be beneficial or worth the effort.

Quite a few HighBye users are using CDC for replicating their disparate site-level MES.  Another approach users take is indexed reads.  This works well if the changes are only new records.  The queries will be setup to pull a batch of records against an index.  The index will be maintained and updated only when data successfully reaches its destination.  Both CDC and indexed-backfills work well.

The upside to CDC is that it can efficiently pick up modified records.  It's very common in MES to make adjustments to logs (e.g., misclassified downtime event, adding notes, lagging quality events).  The downside is sometimes, if abused, CDC can be problematic in terms of system resources.  Depending on what other workloads the database is running, this may or may not be a problem.  There are other replication techniques beyond CDC.  It's probably best to choose one based on the consumption patterns and use cases for the data.  For example, some KPIs in an org's business intelligence layer may not necessarily benefit from continuously running aggregate calculations on MES transactions second-by-second.  There might be slower, but more graceful and efficient alternatives.  It's also worth mentioning that if it's database-to-database, the native replications features (e.g., MS SQL snapshots, secondary replicas) are tried-and-true options.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Rhize does CDC natively with a Kafka sink off the Write Ahead Log. We use that for the Audit reports

Author: evjakec

So if you’re concerned about performance, something like Fivetran could help you. It doesn’t actually capture the change data, just uses the internal SQL changes to stream into your destination of choice

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Here is an example of a Generic Solution Guideline Structure

Introduction: Addressing Key Challenges with Flexible Solutions

[Customer Name] is facing a range of challenges in [key areas: machine monitoring, operational processes, workflow digitization, etc.]. Our proposal introduces a flexible solution tailored to your specific needs, integrating three key technology platforms: [Platform A], [Platform B], and [Platform C]. These platforms address various pain points such as machine data collection, workflow digitization, real-time visualization, and production planning/scheduling.

Questionnaire: Understanding [Customer Name]’s Key Pain Points

Provide a list of targeted questions to understand the customer's needs:

1. Machine Monitoring

Do you need real-time machine data collection from sources like PLCs or sensors?

Is real-time monitoring of machine performance and downtime critical to your production goals?

Do you need a system to store and analyze machine parameters for long-term insights?

2. Operational Processes

Are manual processes (like paper-based logs or quality checks) causing delays or errors?

Do you require digital work instructions and standardized workflows?

Would you benefit from tools for production planning and scheduling?

3. Visualization and Reporting

Is real-time visibility into production performance important for your team?

Do you prefer an on-premise or cloud-based solution for data visualization and reporting?

4. Budget and Licensing Preferences

Do you prefer a one-time licensing fee or are you open to subscription models?

How important is minimizing costs when selecting a solution?

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Solution Recommendations Based on [Customer Name]’s Answers

Based on the responses, recommend tailored solutions:

1. N3uron + Tulip: For Comprehensive Workflow Optimization, Machine Data Collection, and Digital Work Orders

When to use: If the customer requires real-time data collection, manual processes causing errors, and production planning/scheduling with cloud-based flexibility.

Key Benefits:

N3uron handles real-time machine data collection and stores data for long-term analysis.

Tulip provides digital work instructions, real-time dashboards, and production planning tools.

Cloud-based flexibility for easy deployment and lower costs compared to using both N3uron and Ignition.

2. N3uron + Peakboard: For On-Premise Machine Monitoring, Real-Time Dashboards, and Work Order Execution

When to use: If the customer prefers on-premise solutions for machine monitoring and visualization.

Key Benefits:

N3uron collects machine data and sends it to Peakboard for real-time visualization.

Peakboard offers real-time dashboards and work order execution within an on-premise setup.

Lower cost with one-time licensing, ensuring no recurring subscription fees.

3. Ignition Only: For Advanced Machine Monitoring, SCADA, and Long-Term Data Analysis

When to use: If the customer requires advanced SCADA integration, machine monitoring, and historian capabilities.

Key Benefits:

Ignition provides advanced machine data collection, protocol conversion, and historical data storage.

Real-time dashboards, SCADA control, and the ability to monitor OEE and machine performance.

Ideal for machine-centric operations focused on automation control and long-term data analysis.

4. Tulip Only: For Comprehensive Workflow and Operational Efficiency, Including Planning and Scheduling

Author: vikanchira
Content:
When to use: If the customer focuses primarily on workflow optimization, digital work instructions, and production scheduling with cloud-based flexibility.

Key Benefits:

Tulip offers tools for digitizing workflows, issuing work orders, and creating production schedules.

Cloud-based for fast deployment and easy updates.

Best for operational efficiency and task management without complex machine-level monitoring.

Author: atbusch
Content:
I work for a company that implements MES projects (standard software + project specific customizations).
One of our customers is into a big digital transformation: UNS + new MES (my company) + new ERP + new LIMS.
One issue we are constantly facing in the MES implementation is that we are customizing the standard interfaces to accommodate to the legacy L2 capabilities and the new ERP constraints. This is being done modifying the MES standard code, and while it’s a common practice when we implement projects, I’m not sure if it’s the best practice when having a UNS.
Right now we have the following workflow: L2 sends the production report of one of the lines, MES process it, modifying some data and applying some production logic to it, and sends it immediately to the ERP (there is no manual data added into the MES).
Based on that, is it ok to do that “interface mapping” in the MES or would it be better that the UNS broker does it? On one side, with the current implementation we break the principle of reducing intermediate interfaces, but it’s also a bad practice that the broker does some production logic…

Author: brianpribe
Content: Your problem seems to stem from the L2 layer. If you were to publish the production report to the UNS, you would still need to modify or add more information to it for your ERP to consume from it. May look something like L2 -> UNS -> MES -> UNS -> ERP. Need more information about what the goals are, how the current system operates, and how do you want the new system to operate, before getting to applying it to your use case.

Author: atbusch
Content:
Yes, ideally their L2 would send the data like we want, but at least in the short term it’s not an option to change it.
Now we have that workflow L2 -> UNS -> MES -> UNS -> ERP, but the UNS is not doing any processing on the intermediate data, that’s being done in the MES.
My question is if it might be better to have 3 workflows: L2 -> UNS, UNS -> MES and UNS -> ERP, and in this case the UNS broker would process the data to what the MES and ERP require.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I don't think the UNS should ever process data.

It routes it from publishing nodes to subscribing nodes.

So I think your first work flow is good. But if the ERP or LIMS or CMMS need data from L2 that data should not have to go through the MES.

Sometimes that is unavoidable, because of a lack of MTR

Can you say what products you are using??

Author: atbusch
Content:
Thank you for your response.

In this case, the ERP needs the line reports from L2, but it can't directly use the raw data that L2 sends (the same applies to the MES). Since the MES offers more flexibility in its interface mapping, we are processing the data the MES needs there, and we also process it according to the ERP's requirements before sending it (MES -> UNS -> ERP). This way, at least the UNS doesn't process any data.

As @Brian Pribe mentioned, the issue originates from L2, but it's a legacy system, and replacing it is out of scope for now.

Unfortunately, the project is already being implemented, and there is an NDA in place, so I can't disclose the products being used. That said, do you think something like HighByte or Litmus could help in this situation?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
It sounds like you are using the MES as the Data Ops Platform.

Nothing wrong with that in principle.

but if you have a lot of Data Ops to do, and then Litmus and HighByte are certainly worth considering.

Author: brianpribe
Content: If you have the option to use Litmus or Highbyte (dunno how you’re interfacing with L2), have it go L2 -> HB -> UNS -> MES and ERP topics. If MES or ERP or CMMS need dataops then you already have a great tool to use.

Author: atbusch
Content: Thanks, @Mark O'Donovan and @Brian Pribe! I'm currently working on the MES portion of the architecture, but I'll recommend that the customer consider HighByte and Litmus. Processing data in the MES is a project-specific modification and may impact future maintenance.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Alberto Busch, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: brianpribe
Content: Absolutely! FYI another benefit is that you can decouple your MES, so down the road you can replace it with minimal impact.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Your problem is exactly the problem that all UNS architects have, and why the UNS cannot be 'just an MQTT broker', and why DataHubs exist.
Transformation should be the role of the Hub. On any reasonably large system, it's not feasible to enforce standardisation across all publishers, so the role of the Hub is to keep a standardised format, which requires transformation.
In large systems, Transformation can also require MasterData management. Example: Equipment A is called Equipment B in some other system. Master Data management is also a role of the Hub.
In large systems these functions need to be manageable at scale, which means templates with hierarchical inheritance / composition. It can also mean table and row based access controls to facilitate governed, group-wide templates and site-based extensions to those templates.
I say `In large systems` because of course all of this can be easily managed with some scripts in ignition on a small system.

Author: atbusch
Content: Thanks for your answer! Maybe this is not the right channel to ask, but where can I learn more about DataHubs products/options and best practices? Any recommended video or tutorial?

Author: brianpribe
Content:
United Manufacturing Hub @Jermuk:
https://learn.umh.app/blog/the-unified-namespace-as-the-strongest-architectural-proposal-for-industry-4-0/
Go through all 4 chapters, plus they have a lot of great blogs.

Rhize Manufacturing Data Hub @GeoffNunan:
https://rhize.com/resources/
There blogs, docs, and podcasts are great resources especially in regards to ISA95. They probably have the best implementation of S95 out there.

HighByte Intelligence Hub@aronsemle:
https://info.highbyte.com/data-modeling-guidebook
Just about every digital transformation initiative has an instance of highbyte  and for good reason.

Author: atbusch
Content: Thank you so much!

Author: brianpribe
Content: No problem

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Following the discussion, I think @Brian Pribe and @Mark O'Donovan nailed it. L2 should be edge driven and publish the format that the MES and/or the ERP need. If it can't then a dataop product should be use to convert before publishing to the UNS. Highbyte and Litmus are goods but are sold in a large chunk. i.e. per site price. 

If you only have one node to convert, try a light weight and lower cost tool to do the dataop. E.g. N3uron, Ignition Edge, or even Node-RED.

Good luck

Author: vikanchira
Content:
You make a good point. Although I would recommend the Nodes to do the transformation and publish in the standard format as much as possible. Edge driven in my experience has been much cheaper.

1 Gateway now a day are really low cost
2. Reduce bandwidth. Not publishing raw and processed data
3. Reduce the Hun's load. Doing the job of a broker and dataops put a strain on the resources (CPU, ram, etc) Best to decouple the broker and the dataop part too or you are one bad code away from screwing up the entire platform (We are not talking from experience, promise 😅)

In reality as you say, subscribing, processing, and publishing the processed data in a standard format using dataop/IIoT platform maybe unavoidable in a large or a brownfield system.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @vikan, you just advanced to level 11!

Author: atbusch
Content:
Thanks @vikan ! When you include a Gataway in the dataflow, does it do the data processing from L2? I ask because I was familiar with using gatways for security or load balancing, not data transformation.
Also, could you explain how the third diagram works? There you include a DataOps and Gataway, what would each one do?

Author: vikanchira
Content: My meaning of 'Gateway' is 'IIoT Gateway' Typically an dedicated hardware device such as Red Lion Flexedge, Opto22, or an IPC with Node-RED/Kepware/N3uron/Ignition Edge software installed.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
3rd diagram shows two cases
1. L2 connected to an IIoT Gateway say N3uron converting OPC-UA to MQTT while using Derived Tag feature to process and also model the data into ISA-95 format.
2. L2 that publishes it's data that has not been modelled and peocessed into ISA-95 hierarchy and aggregated for MES/ERP. Seperate this from the UNS in a section/topics in the MQTT broker so that they don't mix with your UNS topics. A dataop software, say Ignition/N3uron subscribe to this, processes ans then re-publish it into the UNS section in the format that MES/ERP need.

It's a big reason why I believe in a headless-mes architecture where the backend and formulae are fixed, but citizen developers can build what they want ontop of the standard headless backend.

Generic web development or UX app platforms that aren't aware of the underlying APIs and data models of the headless backend are less-than-convenient to build with and DIY UX's can be a maintenance nightmare since they tend to have the "style" of a single developer, versus a product that many developers can be trained on.  With Tulip, the UX is an integral part of the experience and the defined processes.

Author: markyfreeds
Content: Hey I agree with the other folks talking about how governance can really empower citizen development. I recommend creating a new workspace in Tulip and importing the common data model, then tweaking it to your needs. Base all of the templates you make for your team on a shared data structure. In my opinion that’s a best practice and “table stakes” (pun intended?)

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
If I want to query all the fields of a type such as Equipment, I just need to get those fields first with an introspection query like this
query{
  __type(name:"Equipment"){
    fields{
      name
      description
    }
  }
}

that will give me a list of the fields of the type Equipment

Then I can use that list to query the equipment like this
query {
  queryEquipment{
    iid
    acl
    recordEntries
    _createdOn
    _modifiedOn
    _createdBy
    _modifiedBy
    effectiveStart
    effectiveEnd
    versions
    activeVersion
    nextVersion
    id
    label
...

Author: geoffnunan
geoffnunan
Content:
Notice how the result of the introspection query does not just give you the name of the field, but also the description of that field. That's graphql's self-documenting nature. You put the documentation in the schema itself so that all the clients have access to it.
I can use the same technique to get enum values and everything else I might want when building a UI.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: We have a demo coming out very soon of a full MES build using a headless architecture with Ignition as the UI that David Schultz has been working on with Andy German, Rene Verleg and Jeroen Janssen

Author: nickn5549
Content: So, you buy Rhize and Ignition and then start 'coding' and build your own MES? It Looks like a very expensive exercise for me....unless the rewards are fenomenal...

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Whats the starting price and pricing model for Rhize?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Rhize is a Headless MES platform, so it's agnostic to whatever you choose to use for the frontend. If you already use Ignition, then use that. If you have Mendix you can use that, OutSystems, AppSmith, Budibase, PowerApps, or build you own frontend if you choose.
Cost wise, we offer a better value proposition than the 'Off-the-shelf' MES platforms because we are designed to be customised and extended. 100% fit to requirements without bending an off-the-shelf system to do things it was never designed to do.
Implementation times are typically faster too. We recently built a fully featured MES for a 5-factory roll-out in 4 months. 100% fit to requirements.
I've had customers tell me that they've been quoted figures of USD$40M to USD$50M for an enterprise MES deployment. I've seen customers spend over USD$10M on a pharma MES that only covers the Weigh&Dispense step of the process, and I know companies that have spend over $100M on an ERP version upgrade that added no additional functionality.
Doing things at scale across multiple sites, with mutiple governance teams is hard. Headless enforces governance at the right level to allow large-scale deployments that give the right balance between 'Composable' low-code and Enterprise

Author: geoffnunan
Content: It's definitely more expensive than Tillit

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Curious why you do it headless? Alot of my clients are loving tillit for the problems it solves and the look of the UI. Sad to say but parts of the business just want a good looking dashboards.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Most controls engineers are not great with UI/UX

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Tillit solves a different problem.
Most control engineers are great at designing a UX that solves the needs of the machine operator because they are close to the problem, and can empathise with the person who is using the software they design.
Low-code tools like Ignition, Tulip, Mendix, AppSmith, OutSystems, Budibase, PowerApps, etc provide a way of controls-engineers being able to iterate quickly to improve a design with learned experience. Innovation is application design is largely a factor of how fast the designer can go through the cycle of build, deploy, learn, build, deploy, learn.
The problem is that scaling that innovation out to 200 controls engineers across 40 factories like one of our customers did with Tulip creates a problem of governance. How do you balance innovation with standardisation? How do you balance creativity with comparable, analysis ready data?
Headless solves that problem.
If you only have one site, or you only have a couple of control engineers looking after the MES for your enterprise, Headless may not solve a problem you have.

Author: nickn5549
Content: What frontend did you use to build the fully featured MES on top of the manufacturing data hub? In this case: "We recently built a fully featured MES for a 5-factory roll-out in 4 months. 100% fit to requirements."

At my previous employer we had a few Operations Support personnel that went through the Tulip training and one of them became our lead app developer with no prior experience in any sort of web design/MES system. This also helps with buy-in and they can help ease any concerns of other shop floor personnel who may be "CAVE" people.
