Author: rickbullotta
Content: It's actually a really interesting challenge for ISVs - products that save CUSTOMERS tons of money often take that money out of the billables of INTEGRATORS.  Smart integrators know that they're more like to rollout a successful, cost-effective MES than a one-off expensive implementation, so they play the long game and put their customers interests first.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Yes but as an Integrator if you recommend the best value for the customer , they keep coming back.

Sometimes that is lots of licences and little engineering cost.

Sometimes vice versa.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Agree completely.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
And more powerful software, just allows more complicated problems be solved for a reasonable amount of hours.

So the Integration hours stay constant.

But if you want to launch a software it must make an Integrator be able to do more in less time.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
My experience with multi million dollar MES projects as an engineer is that software is rarely the real problem, although lacking vendor support definitely doesn't help. 

Giant misaligned teams, multiple levels of management on both customer and integrator side with conflicting incentives, finger pointing and umbrella pulling over constructive collaboration, strict waterfall approach while requirements change on a daily basis, and so on ...

That's what makes these projects expensive.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Completely agree.
The relationship between size and cost when it comes to the number of different teams involved is not linear but exponential.
That's where technology choices can make a difference. If the technology requires fewer teams to be involved, the savings are also exponential.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I’ve found software to often be a significant part of the problem. Specifically, software that was not designed to be customized or extended to accommodate the unique processes, systems, and needs of specific customers. In those cases the cost of customization (and ongoing maintenance of those mods) can balloon to huge numbers.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
That's a big reason why we built Rhize.
We purposefully built a platform with extension as the primary objective.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Sure, part of, and don't get me wrong I'm super excited about platforms like Rhize.

Just from my experiences in big pharma, that's far from the biggest reason why these projects are so expensive and often fail.

Author: geoffnunan

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I have to dig more int RHIZE.
Bt to me the role of the Integrator and certainly the system Architect is to understand the customer needs and recommend the correct product.
and top find out where n the line between uncustomisable but fast to get moving( i.e. low hours) or completely customisable but needs a lot of hours. that @RickBullotta alludes to .

But if a company takes a major platform for the MES( and we are in the MES channel) so Ignition, Aveva MES, even System Platform, WinCC, Op Center. They are likely to be ok on the software side.

But  the issue is that as we build out our Industry 4.0 infrastructure, the MES platform often is being asked to do more but it isalready the intesection between the IT and OT Apps. And if we are in Brownfield situation in particular, it can be difficult to recommend a sperate IIoT platform, or Data Ops software, or both, when the MES or even SCADA software can do a good job.

Do I really recommend ripping out Aveva System Platform with a custom MES that is doing all the SCADA and MES functionality well , and rebuilding it with Ignition, RHIZE, Flow, Highbyte or Litmus, or some combination of the lot

And I am still trying to learn where those fit into the Venn Diagriam of Capabilities, and in particular where they can really reduce the integration hours by more than their licence cost.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Completely agree.
There are many factors in the decision on which MES to implement, and a good SI will work to find the best fit for the customer.
There are many Off-the-shelf options that are a better fit for specific use-cases than a headless option too.
I've spent more hours than I care to count trying to bend some of them to do things that they were not designed to do, and that's where the Platform versus Solution decision comes in. When is a platform the right approach for a customer versus a collection of solutions.
Low-code like Tulip, Mendix, OutSystems and others is changing the equation on buy versus build. It's a constantly moving playing field

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Is Rhize accessible for automation controls engineers or more aimed at Devops teams to manage integrations?

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Buy v build and everything in between are hard decisions.

Can you create everything yourself from scratch with just open source stuff? Yes, but don't underestimate the TCO. 

Slightly easier in Ignition? Probably, but harder to scale and properly structure. 
If you're planning on aligning with ISA95 and use a lot of common MES functionality it quickly makes sense to add e.g. sepasoft's DB and api.

Same for using AVEVA system platform and adding AVEVA MES.

Then if you go further ideally you want less tightly coupled and more customizable, but keep it well structured around a well designed core, enter something like Rhize?

Then adding low code apps on top I'm again not sure about scaling wrt license costs

Author: rafaamaral
Content:
I 100% agree its a spectrum. You need to find the right level of abstraction to work on that doesn't make compromise and doesn't make you have to keep redoing things.

I did a lot of custom code with Geoff at Nukon and I found myself rebuilding the same thing over and over. I also spent a ton of my career on a super opinionated tool called SAP and had to become a wizard to customise the tool in order to fulfil the customer requirement, it was super hard, painful and hacky.

If you go too far on the abstraction, creating a product with all the tables and screens you think the customer will need, yes, you may create an environment that is lacking and will require customisation and that will be painful and will probably block upgrades.

If you stay too low on the framework every project is engineering, needing coders, and they will cost $$.

My goal in TilliT is to try to nail that sweet spot where you have building blocks like Lego and you are trying to fulfil the customer requirement (not letting her down), whilst moving fast and safe. So part of the model is defined, things like machines, materials, orders, you dont have to build those. But we have a powerful workflow engine built for manufacturing (Not BPMN - lessons learned there), that allows the customer to compose a solution. And yes, you can add in some code for behaviour and custom UI components.

I think our customers are getting satisfied and their requirements solved. But our customers are limited to a range of industries. So not all customers fit this model. But the ones that do, get a real good experience. If you are trying to do lights out, no operator, than I'd suggest skipping TilliT. If you are just doing Connected Worker, QMS, LMS, Track and Trace, well, I think we have a very interesting tool.

Author: rafaamaral
Content: One last bit around the TCO Rutger. I wonder when cyber will come down heavier on on prem legacy software full of CVE. I understand now what it takes to keep software safe (cloud forces you to do that), and I look back at my past with some strange feelings around systems I left behind that are solely protected by 1 network layer. But thats another topic.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
I'm not at all a professional in cybersecurity but I'm not convinced by the "cloud is inherently safer" sentiment. 

Yes there's (a lot) of horrible security practices in on prem systems, absolutely, but just starting from zero trust and only allowing connections that are absolutely necessary solves a lot.

For cloud I will have to trust the security of the vendor. 

Curious to hear other (more educated on the topic) people's opinions on this.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
It's easy enough to build an insecure cloud, but I completely agree that cyber already a big issue and getting bigger every day.
In my opinion, It's the older software from the big vendors that was built 30+ years ago that is the stuff that's a worry. It was never built securely from the inside out. 
Our external penetration tests get harder every cycle and we can be agile in how we address new challenges as they come up. I often wonder how the big vendors with massive legacy code bases keep up with the pace of change in cyber.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: I'm also finding that most companies I speak with want on-premise with 2 firewalls and a DMZ between the OT network and their internal IT network which might include private cloud. Public cloud or even VPC connections to SaaS still scares their IT cyber teams.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If you're opening up connection to your plant from the outside, a cloud based solution could well be less safe.

Author: r.pop
Content: Depends on how you evaluate Cloud security. If you are talking about the interactions between services in an AWS instance, then it is absolutely inherently safer than application interfaces on your enterprise network. If you are talking about from local networks to cloud networks, then the answer is more about what you mentioned in your comment and managing connections.

Author: rafaamaral
Content:
Agree with Geoff. I was talking really about the old legacy that is still there and hasn't been updated. 
And yes, you can 100% build unsafe cloud systems.
But once you are in the aws or azure ecosystems, they provide some really good toolset to have an online validation of your own system. I'm talking package analysis, anomaly detection, DDoS protection on and on.  If you activate those (and you have to intentionally activate and pay), then you start to become safer because of all that security layer.

Author: IIoT#4707

Author: jbonhage155
Content: We self-host our MES via AWS --  any time we submit firewalls from on-prem to AWS alarms bells go off in the global security office and everything is watched closely. None of our traffic is publicly exposed, all traffic is zero trust like you mentioned. Source code pulled via CICD is scanned in repositories.  I would say the cloud is super safe compared to on-premise but then you see headlines like what happened with Snowflake / hackers syphoning off 500+ million Ticketmaster accounts -- like they had access to root file system, lol. Black swans events seems like they aren't that far away for the big cloud providers.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Not an expert with Sepasoft, but I've seen similar problems hosting full-stack apps. Are you hosting the database as IaaS (AKS cluster + storage)? Or are you using PaaS (Azure SQL)?

Couple of high-level things to look into:

-Are you following reference architecture for hosting databases?  Databases have different requirements than micro services.

-Are you using appropriate storage/disk service tier for hosting a database? Databases need IOPS to avoid slowing down everything. Avoid storage tiers designed for backups or hosting images for CDNs to cache.

-Are you running compute and storage out of the same region, available zone, cluster, etc? Is there latency between the front end and back end? 

-Independent of infrastructure, does the database and its queries look in good shape? Is there something misconfigured that is driving inefficient execution paths? Is Sepasoft making reasonable queries?

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
we look at this a lot with our MES. But when we hear of poor performance many times it's the latency of the the network as clients are on-premise and the MES is AWS hosted. If there's a lot of materials/PO moved to the line, the MES can do up to 300 calls back and forth between client and server to load pa page and that's where if you don't have low latency (pings) then that latency really shows itself. Using chrome dev tools really helps here as we can trace out where the delay happens in the tech stack. If Sepasoft is Perspective based then you could probably get this info but if Vision I'm not so sure.

I would say it's good you have a fast pipe between OEE app and backend DB. But overall I would get some sort of debug session going on the client to see which calls are holding up the load of the page. If it database/stored procedures slowing you up then that's a whole other can of worms, lol

Content: Reach out to Mark French at Sepasoft. He can help.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
curious if anyone has thoughts on managing MES deployments with a lot of data stored in database. We have a few sites where MES data is piling up in MSQL DB's and find queries are taking longer and overall system performance is slowing. We have a realtime database which is 30 days truncated then an online datastore which is indefinite. The main issue we are running into is the datastore some tables have about 40M records ~ 40GB storage, to which a report 1 day ago needs to query the same table as to a regulator wanting to know about a product up to 14 years ago.

At what point to relational database break down and the long term storage needs to be moved to a different type of database storage/technology (oltp vs olap)?

Author: jbonhage155
Content: our "off-the shelf' "SAAS not not really SAAS" MES is heavily API based -- even if we find thru Chrome DevTools which API are the offenders is hard to trace why APIs are taking a lot time to process -- they could be making network / database / filesystem calls and hard to nail down where the latency resides.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: I've now seen 2 large MES deployment where SQL/stored procedures become the bottle neck and sometimes needs to be re-written. They work when great when first deployed but then run them against and large, unoptimized DB that has been in productions for a few years all hell breaks loose... lol

Author: evjakec
Content:
I’ve worked with a large OLTP database before (a couple tables with low billions of records because our warranty was 25 years). Now we had direct access to the database and DBAs so they were able to partition the older data to a different disk and keep the recent data very performant. 

Our plan for archiving was to offload to the cloud in a semi-unstructured path, meaning capture all of the relevant data for warranty into a JSON object and store it away. 

Do you have any opportunity to work with the database itself?

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Good ideas! Yeah I have admins right to all the databases.
I really like the idea of not having to run queries to retreive data 10 years ago, instead store the final results in a JSON. We do have images attached so would just need to create a hyperlink in the JSON.

With the partitions, did it then cause you to modify queries since they would have to reference the partitions for a certain time range?

Author: jbonhage155
Content: even with OLTP you needed to partition? I guess even low billions can take some time to parse, haha

Author: evjakec
Content: The one caveat with partitioning (SQL Server by the way) is that not all of our tables had a PK that was good for partitioning. In my example, we just used auto IDs for the PK, but then later had to rebuild the PK to include a date column. Our stuff was very date driven or product ID driven and if we had the product ID, that index would perform well in most cases.  We had queries working off of dates anyway, but that was mostly for reporting. That’s where the partitioning was helpful. Actual execution down the line was product ID 99% of the time and everything was indexed.

Author: evjakec
Content: We needed 1 second or sub second response in some cases, and it made the DBAs lives easier in some of their work. But we also had all of engineering running queries on a read only copy. The general guideline was that unless they were pulling 100k+ records back, the query should return in 1 second or less

I was curious about the 'breaking point' for relational database -- is there one? Assuming you needed to build custom indexes on the columns you need to search on to keep the ETL performant ?

Author: evjakec
Content: Same as Rick. I built my own recently for a discrete shop (window units) and it was .NET Core REST API with sql backend. I think you can still do good volume on data collection with SQL, but like a record every 30 seconds or more, not every 1. It could handle it with robust hardware but getting full value out of that setup could be tough.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: do you find if you walk away for a few years and come back the database is in shambles and the entire system is slow? Or you have a 'realtime' database and then archive off data off to a warehouse for longer term queries?

Author: evjakec
Content:
I’ve personally never been through that but to prepare for it, I follow a general pattern. Normalization is important and use sql jobs to keep transaction logs and backups clean. Then I only use absolute necessary columns on the tables and augment the rest with key\value pairs in separate tables. For example, your Part table. A part number, type and description are all you really need. Then each part can have 1 to many attributes. Using the window example, attributes would be length, width, thickness. The goal would be to hopefully never have to change that schema, yet still be able to support all kinds of production types. 

I’ve never had the fortune of a database getting old and non performant. We did have a case where our PK was an auto id and we hit the int limit (2.1 billion). We had to reset the PK to -2.1 billion and let it count up while we cleaned up the table lol.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Good insights on keep main tables low in column and build out with key/value pairs.  Crazy about the PK, that must have been a fun one to troubleshoot!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: SSDs or old hard drives?

Author: jbonhage155
Content: it's part of a VMWare cluster, I'm so I'm not exactly sure what type of underlying storage. I should probably find out

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
That's the way I used to do it with SQL.
The data platform in Rhize does not require this. We can serve reports directly from the transactional data performantly. The example with DeltaV and Syncade, Rhize is the integration hub that sits in between them and captures all of the records into the Rhize ISA95 database in real-time. The batch record reports run directly off that ISA95 database, no ETL.

Author: nickn5549
Content: We use Postgres, MySQL and MSSQL. Postgres we observed that even if it is properly config, with proper indexes, enough RAM, it can slow down significantly if CPUs are not high frequency. MySQL relies heavily in fine-tune config, indexes, optimised stored procedures and lots of RAM. MSSQL is probably the slower out this bunch and we could speed it up through optimised stored procedures and proper indexing. Our MES backend is MSSQL and we had to do another thing - use 2 servers, one for recording and one for reporting.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Having just done it, I can say that I would not use SQL (or postgres for that matter)
When you think about SQL, there are a lot of problems:
- it's difficult to horizontally scale. SQL databases are mostly designed to be scale-up rather than scale-out. Of course there are exceptions, but those exceptions add complexity, and require additional skills to operate.
- you need a Database administrator to keep it running and performing well.
- Most graduates out of university don't get taught SQL any more, so you start from a clean sheet teaching you team about the difference betwenn left joins and right joins.
- you need a whole other application ORM layer in your application.
- row-level security is painful.
- version upgrades are a pain.
When I designed our stack for Rhize, I wanted to avoid all of these problems.

Author: nickn5549

Author: zeratall
Content: Regarding the “most graduates don’t get training on SQL” is that actually true? If so that’s insane, SQL is still widely adopted and in use in industry.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: It's a graphql native database, similar to graph but not the same. horizontally scalable, ACID compliant. The Rhize DB started as a fork of the dgraph open-source project with a lot of our own additions now.

Author: geoffnunan

Content: It’s all a trade off though.  If you want ACID transactions you have obviously more to do than with an eventually consistent (more often that not should be occasionally  consistent) data stores.  Depends on the use case obviously.

Author: zeratall
Content: I recently did a little bit on that very subject, ACID gets really hard with distributed systems because of long running distributed transactions. That’s why you see a lot of Sagas in most modern reference architecture  s which is why we see so much eventual consistency out there today.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Yes, that was a hard one to solve

Author: geoffnunan

Author: jbonhage155
Content: what makes something ACID compliant? ( assuming it means Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability?) Does MSSQL or any type of database have feature baked into the source code? First I'm in hearing of ACID ...

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yes, needs to be designed in. Many nosql databases do not guarantee consistency.  Two queries from two clients could return different results.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
As @RickBullotta said. There are 4 parts to it, but it's the C for consistency that gets the most focus. SQL server, and most SQL systems sacrifice speed for consistency, meaning 2 queries from different clients at the same time will always get the same result.
'Big data' NoSQL databases sacrifice consistency for speed by using eventual-consistency, meaning eventually, some time after a transaction occurs, all clients will see the same results.
That's often good enough for analytical databases, and never good enough for transactional source systems.
The biggest problem with distributed, horizontally scalable system has been that there are very few databases which are distributed and consistent, but the benefits of that architecture to an MES are huge. It's not even about the horizontal scalability mostly, it's the ability to have a completely zero-downtime stack, where every component including the database and operating system the database is running on can be upgraded as often as you like, without taking the system down.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Any recommended resources for learning more about ACID compliance with practical examples? 

I think I understand the general concept, but don't have a deep enough understanding.

Taking MS SQL Server as an example, what part does the product itself play in ACID compliance, and what part is design of the schema (constraints) and transactions (e.g. stored procedures)?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: We used to joke that "eventual consistency" was the same as "occasional consistency"

Author: evjakec
Content: One example would be if someone is updating 1 million rows of data. They start their query and then someone tries to select data from the same table. The select will be blocked until the update finishes. The are ways to bypass that with a “NOLOCK” statement but then of course you’re risking old data.

Author: evjakec
Content: I agree this would be nice to have, but you can also achieve zero downtime without. It of course requires a specific architecture, but it’s doable and I’ve been a part of a team that’s done it. But we absolutely would have evaluated a distributed approach if it was available at the time.

Author: zeratall
Content: The definition of a distributed architecture from a micro service pov is encapsulated data. Aka each service has its own datastore. That’s where the data consistency issue arises because you now have data spread across multiple data stores.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: That's a completely different concept to a distributed database.

Author: zeratall
Content: Yes I know which is why I said “from a micro service pov”. The point I was making is it all relates back to CAP in one form or another.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I assume you’d use SSDs on everything. Converted all my PCs to use them.

Author: evjakec
Content:
Brief discussion that is recent on CDC. Of note, of course the answer is “it depends”. No official guidance from MSFT. Just because you have a simple recovery model doesn’t mean you stop backing up the Tlog. 

What is your use case? I’ve activated CDC many years ago, the performance was poor so we found another way.  There are also products that can capture the transactions from the log directly and not actually save the data in SQL (Fivetran was what we used). Data was sent out to snowflake with this software. 
 https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/sql-server/impact-of-cdc-on-sql-server/m-p/3990813

Author: geoffnunan
Content: We don't use SQL DB, but do use CDC, which typically works from the Write-Ahead-Log of the database, so no performance or disk hit.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
there is a corporate initiative to offload all reporting from local MES instances into Snowflake/datalakes. The issues is there's no contextualization or ETL happening on the database/source side, so high percentage of tables are CDC'd for future day consumers so reports can be re-build to leverage the data warehouse.

There's about 20 transaction per minute spreads across multiple tables to process an MES event. I'm trying to get my head around the true disk IOPs impact of CDC. My understanding CDC reads the current DB transaction logs, creates it's own change table and I think adds buffering to make sure it's stay in sync with SQL transactions. (this is where it gets fuzzy to me)

Plants are struggling everyday with MES performance issues so I'd really like to avoid adding any overhead to current MES backend with CDC but I'm not sure how much difference will make with CDC on or off.

Author: evjakec
Content:
There’s a market for everyone. I see many MES projects lead by procurement specialists. They have zero interest in customizing and just want something simple. But then there are the tech savvy customers who prefer build. The vendors are moving to more low code offerings to get those folks back but not many doing it well. It’s why Tulip is very popular now. 

At some point if you customize an OTS too much, you’re going to take on a lot of technical debt and really devalue the license and adoption of the product. I think this is where we get the “50% of MES projects fail” stat

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
There is a 3rd option, it's no longer a question of Build v/s Buy
Headless MES gives the option of buying an extensible platform on which you can easily build MES use-cases using low-code app-development platforms.

Author: brianpribe
Content:
There is still a lot of heavy lifting to be done on the equipment side. OPC-UA has made progress towards providing all of the content about a machine you could ask for, but still falls short in practice. Most of the problems manufacturers are solving for with MES come down to three things:
1. Reduce Material Expense
2. Increase Equipment Utilization
3. Increase Personnel Productivity

Each of these problems can be solved from data sourced at the equipment level, but if we want this to be an industry-standard it's up to the machine builders to make it so.

Build vs. Buy will remain a debate, because the problem lies at the equipment level.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Each of those problems can also be solved without data from the equipment.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I had a client, 500+ hundred machines in a plant each on printed out a daily schedule, that took about 10 minutes per machine to go and find and get set up, then after each WO the associated Paperwork was almost 20 minutes closing out one batch and starting the next. That doesn't include any non paperwork stuff, 

So the cost was about 70 man hours *500 per day on paperwork.

Add in the cost associated with finding those records again if they are ever needed.

and the about 30 minutes downtime associated with waiting for materials, that we were able to reduce by alerting the warehouse to the real time needs on the plant floor, that leveraged the same infrastructure.

I know what you are saying about high costs, but the high cost are there already,  for a less efficient system

Author: rafaamaral
Content:
I think if you do the paperless right(not paper on glass), then it's not just about generating data for reporting and checking what went wrong yesterday or last week, but actually avoiding mistake by creating double checks every step of the process. 
The biggest pitfall I find with a machine engineer lead approach is underestimating the complexity of all business rules required to ship product out the door. If you think the complexity only lies in the tags, I/O, etc, wait until you map all the process flow (people, machine, material) that happens inside the four walls of a factory. 

And then you take the level of maturity of 80% of these factories. There are so many low hanging fruits it's crazy. 

I think if you are at level 4 on your maturity curve, then you should be chasing zero manual input. 

But every factory I go to all over the world tells me they are so far behind that they can reduce 10-15% of waste and rework by just implementing the simplest bom check with a barcode scanning. Everyone I spoke to that did this reported that the system blocked operator from loading the raw material on the line on the first week. 

Yeah, great, your machine are super tinned running at 90% oee. Except that it's producing the wrong product with the wrong raw material.

Author: nickn5549

It took them 10 years to give a shit about digital, from what I heard, I changed Honchos in the meantime.

They're both work orders so I usually see them handled the same way by the MES system. 

Except for creation and scheduling. CIP and other cleaning orders created and scheduled either manually, or ideally automatically based on resource optimization (not only equipment but also materials and personnel) with parameters like production schedule and clean status expiry (times, use counters, ...)

Right before a production order is unlikely to be optimal. I'd rather start with manual scheduling then.

Author: ralf05700
Content: Where do I define the model of my factory digital twins? In my MES or in my UNS?

Author: vaughnturner
Content: Define your factory digital twin in your UNS. The UNS is the central real-time data hub, ensuring scalability, interoperability, and real-time contextualization. Your MES is a consumer of that data, not the source.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
MES is perhaps a complicated term, but in many architectures, it is the system of record for these models.
Why? Because it is the system that is implementing the model behaviours like property inheritance, rules and configuration UI.
MES is many different things, and perhaps terms like MOM or Manufacturing Data Hub make more sense these days. Nothing is 'Defined' in a broker, it simply stores messages in topics.

Author: atechmu
Content: in a general sense when building a MES scheduling system, can you build it out to optimize different scenarios like I want to produce the most dollars over a time period say 1 month, or based on most productivity. Could we use it to schedule avoiding certain parts based on operators who run the worst scrap with those parts? What would need to be involved to execute these things. I'm essentially working on a write up for how sophisticated a MES can be and want to provide some context on where the core 4 would land, and what would be needed to expand past the core 4.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: The 'Core 4' has been a trojan horse for decades.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
you may have some of this done but
1- Set your Digital Strategy - Why are you implementing a MES
2- Where re you currently, what can you connect to, are you collecting information  etc( DTMA or SIRI worth looking at for this but not essential)
3- Define you MTR and model Architecture, so a Hub and spoke arrangement, real time Data store, Batch/WO data store, and use a Light weight ,Edge driven , Report by Exception, and Open Architecture
3b - Decide what platform a you are going to use to Connect, Collect( normalize and standardise) , Store, and Visualise the results on
4 - See what problem you want you MES to solve
5- Solve the biggest problem
6-Roll that solution out to other machines - you need to figure out how to get data from machines that are not connectable easily( maybe new sensors, maybe additional sensors and a new PLC)
7 - Solve more problems

Keep the phases small, and don't; build a detailed plan for building a MES for the next two years, split it into 2 month sprints and have a plan for maybe 2-3 sprints. you might need to fill in the next 2 years worth of sprints but they will change.

Ask you self in the architecture parts, what if I replace this software in 5 years, how much rework is there in the other systems?

If you don't know what those 7 points mean, but want to , Sign up to Mastermind or the MES bootcamp
If you don't want to know that what they mean, find an Architect, that does and build a relationship with them

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Short answer - Two table and auto schedule the CIP
but allow for things to get moved.
Lets define a few terms first
a Work Order, is an order from the ERP, it has 1 SKU/Product code going to 1 customer
a Production order is an order that runs on a machine, it might have a number of work orders but is same finished product.

Normally when you create the production Orders the Scheduling software, or the person with the excel sheet, will need to allow for CIPs to be run before a production runs typically.
there may also be rules like a CIP must take place x hours before a Production Order, or a CIP is needed every 24 hours
Depending on the Previous product the CIP required may also change, so Product A to B might need no CIP, Product A to C might need a rinse only , Product   B to C might need a full CIP and Product D always needs Kosher CIP.  

But those CIP's are Production Orders that are assigned to the Machine. you genrally need a rules engine of some sort to decide the CIP type needed. If you are very simple, and every product always need the same CIP, I would recommend that when you create the Production order the required CIP order is created, and you have two tables a CIP Order table and Production order table, the CIP order is linked to a Production order entry. 

So the operator looking at their screen should see the Production and CIP orders in a single table, but you also need to validate the CIP before you run it. Maybe you are boing from A to B but there is a rule that a full CIP is required every 24 hours and it has been 26 hours since the last one. 

and you need logic that will not allow a new Production order to start unless the correct CIP has been performed, according to the rules. this is more important if operators or supervisors  can change the schedule, i.e. we were planning to product B after A so a rinse was scheduled, but some materials are missing so we want to do Product C so we need to validate that a full CIP was performed

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Good explanaition, i see lots of experinces and value on this

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Give me a shout if I can help with any specifics, 
What is the industry, big difference if you are going from skim milk to full fat in a pipeline, or if you are going from brown fizzy beverages toa clear one.

Or madly cucumber flavouring is incredibly difficult to shift,

But CIP compliance is a huge headache for Quality to track and normally ends up with Operators defaulting to the full wash when it's not necessary. A lot of downtime potential saving's with a good CIP Rules Engine.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
I have to disagree with some of what you're saying here, at least from my experience which is mostly from the (batch) process industry but I think it extends. Same goes for COP or any cleaning procedures. I'm curious to hear some other opinions, since your phrasing makes it sound to me like it's the absolute truth and I'm not convinced it is. 

My opinion / experience:

- A CIP order is definitely a work order, regardless of its origin. Work is done. Same goes for maintenance orders from the CMMS for example.
- A CIP order is not a production order, no product is being manufactured in a CIP order.
- A CIP order is not inherently linked to a production order, it can be if it makes sense for your process, but often it doesn't.
- CIP orders are generally created on the MES level (we agree here I think). Using a rule-based engine as a detailed scheduler (or at least scheduling assistant) for both CIP and production orders (you want to optimize both) is a great idea.
- A CIP should update equipment properties (sanitary status, expiry time, ...) which are validated against equipment requirements of a production order.

Whether you have your CIP orders in the same table as the production orders is a design choice, and I'm not sure what I like more there. From my experience though, I usually see them in one and the same wo table in a relational DB.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
my big point however was , you need a CIP rules Engine to manage the CIP rules, and yes those rules will change depending on the system, and I think there we are in complete agreement.

I think we agree what a CIP order is too, I was using terminology form the plant where I did most of my CIP work.
and in that case they said, because it occurs on the production floor it is a production order 🤷‍♂️ 

but using what I think using your terminology( which is better I admit)
 Work Order is any allocation of time on a machine
There are different types of Work Order that can be assigned to a machine
 - Production Order where Stuff is made
 - CIP order, where cleaning occurs
 - Maintenance Order where the equipment is maintained.

and in that case, I agree with everything above,
the only difference was the linking of the CIP to the production order. and I have had systems where the CIP requirements were purely time based so that did not apply.
but when creating a schedule, where the CIP required depends on the previous and next Production orders, having that link allowed the initial schedule to be created.
It did often get deleted when things on the production floor were changed, so maybe there was a butter approach but it was helpful in creating that initial schedule, and in understanding why a particular CIP was chosen. but it was possible to schedule a CIP not linked to a Production Order, i.e. first ting on Monday morning

if you only have one CIP recipe , it might well be overkill, but in this case there was a massive Matrix of potential SKU's to process. 
 WE probably could have done without it , 

the reason we had two tables was because , apart form the scheduled time the particulars of the CIP order and production order are not the same

Author: karltbraun
Content: You can build that in to your system, though, can't you?  If the ERP says to start a job at 3:00PM, MES can say "Starting job at 3:00PM" (the "ACK").  If the ERP doesn't receive it, it can't send the "ACK-ACK" and MES knows it needs to resend the ACK after some period of time.  It's still not 100% but isn't that the way you would handle this?

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Great discussion @Mark O'Donovan and @Rutger Van Aelst . My quick summary: 
Terminology is important - Perhaps `Work Order` should be the parent of all order types, in a sense the top level class in an object oriented programming language, and each other type (production, work, CIP) is a child with extra child specific components. 

I'm not generally a proponent of wide tables, which would happen if you had "one table to rule them all" for all order types. I would put each in a separate bespoke table to track status and then perhaps an event table where the all the orders, and the associated asset involved, would be tracked. 

Need to think about it more but that's my 2 minute drive by thoughts 🙂

Author: rickbullotta
Content: With some other middleware. A broker won’t do it and the assumption of most UNS architectures is that the edge devices aren’t that smart.

Author: karltbraun
Content: Of course - I didn't think about level 0-1 edge and acknowledgements (my lack of shop floor experience is showing).  I suppose you would have to have something polling for tags which indicate the job kicked off or something like that.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think the primary disconnect usually comes down to what we need to do at the application level vs the protocol level.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Yeah it's frustrating there's not just one widely known and used terminology. What I said above is also just my personal experience.

In an ideal world we'd all speak ISA95, in this case work and operations. I think currently that's the best standard we have. 

But I rarely see COTS systems properly adhere to it, let alone engineers in plants or even integrators know it well (so gets misused).

Myself included btw. 
I blame the high barrier to entry. The standards are massive and dense, and also behind a paywall. 

I think the team at Rhize is doing a great job of democratizing this knowledge. Here specifically on this part:
https://docs.rhize.com/explanations/how-to-speak-isa-95/#work-done-and-requested

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
You've just created a point-to-point integration over pub/sub, which would have been much simpler as a  synchronous request/response.
This is a great example of an anti-pattern.

Author: karltbraun
Content: True; and it's been said you shouldn't do controls with MQTT (et al), so probably not a good idea.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Karl Braun, you just advanced to level 10!

Author: willemrs
Content: This is true however doing this through MQTT allows any other peripheral services to also be alerted or made aware without any other additional programming.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Not really true.  MQTT is not an ideal transport for reliable transactions to external systems on its own.

Author: willemrs
Content: Yeah I agree on the protocol level but I think it’s a trade off between doing a direct api call vs using the described acknowledgements via MQTT.  They are kinda a work around but the benefit is potentially less individual connections in the long run.

Author: _dyland
Content: Why not do the API call and if necessary, publish the results to the broker after the transaction is confirmed?

Author: _dyland
Content: Basically why limit yourself to one or the other when you could use the best of both?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
There is an assumption in this that none of the other applications being alerted will need acknowledgement.
In which case, it's a point-to-point message that is also being published, which would seem to be combining 2 things that should be separate.
Any new application subscribing to the message would need to also monitor the ack and the ack/ack in order to know if the message was actually successful.
There are several better integration patterns to handle this. One would be for the sender to use an API call to send the message to the receiver, and then if successful, publish to the broker. Another would be to move the logic to a message queue.

Author: willemrs
Content: Yeah I’m not arguing for only using MQTT by any means.  One of the things i like about the UNS/MQTT architecture is that it allows us to reduce the point to point when not specifically needed.   Also opens up some visibility for the acknowledgements .  For example if you see an MES ID within a topic.  You know it’s been consumed mtn the MES.    Other applications don’t need to individually reach out to the MES application to see this.  Overall definitely a few ways to go about it.  Most likely our end result will be a mix of everything anyhow.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
@Will S there are definitely benefits of a UNS. In IT architectures, it's just called an Event Driven Architecture (EDA).
The trick is to think about events as being immutable. They are a statement of indisputable fact and therefore don't really change over time.
They are different to commands, which are a request to make something happen, which may or may not happen.
Events generate state, commands do not.
Events populate a UNS, commands should not

Author: willemrs
Content: Ok thanks, this helps my understanding.  So in a typical IT EDA,  the events are published and they may trigger commands and may not.  If they trigger commands those commands would typically be sent via a point to point protocol or API?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
That depends on where the responsibility for handling errors lives. There are a few patterns, but it's either with the sender, or with the integration layer if that is part of the architecture.
The questions to ask are:
- does the sender care if the command is ever received?
- does the sender care who received the command?
- does the sender care if the command was successfully actioned?
- does the sender care who actioned the command?
The answers to these questions determine the architecture required.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I still think commands should be a node in a full featured UNS/IIoT platform.

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: You raise a key point here ! Event is not command

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Just that a UNS model of an entity/asset/device/system should expose its data, events, and functions/services/methods.

Author: jasna4.3.2
Content: Hello everyone. My name is Jasna, and I am currently employed in Germany with the specialty chemicals sector. As a solution manager for MES, my role involves crafting an enterprise-wide strategy utilizing a “standard” COTS product. The challenge is not only in selecting the solution, but also in navigating the company’s culture, which prioritizes two principles: 1. SAP first and 2. Always opting to buy rather than build.

Author: evjakec
Content: Not necessarily a bad strategy, as long as they know even the COTS offerings will require some “build” to be properly deployed.

Author: diederik9434
Content: sure sounds like BASF :p

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content: SAP DM can be chosen as the product since it meets both requirements. However, in this case, the project might come across as being executed just for the sake of completion.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Implementing a DataHub based integration pattern can have a lot of benefits. SAP is integrated to DataHub, MES is integrated to Data Hub, LIMS, WMS and any other layer 3 applications are integrated to DataHub, and layer 2 is integrated to DataHub.
That gives flexibility when it comes to implementing use-cases, and allows the COTS MES to do just what it was designed to do. Use-cases that don't exactly fit the MES can be implemented directly in the DataHub.
In my opinion, where the company has a buy rather than build strategy, and an SAP first strategy, the flexibility offered by a DataHub approach can be the difference between success and failure for the solution.

Author: jasna4.3.2
Content: Good guess! The company is quite similar to BASF in terms of the history, marked by numerous acquisitions. This has led to a diverse OT landscape.

Author: jasna4.3.2
Content: Thanks for your honesty. We did receive a bid from SAP for one project, but their prices in comparison with other vendors, as you can imagine, are “way out there”.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content: I’ve been implementing MES projects integrated with SAP for about 10 years. In European companies, we always prioritized SAP. For this, we used MII, adhering to SAP data structures and always acting passively. Our primary priority was to ensure stock consistency, accurate activity time calculations, and prevent cost issues between consumption and production by consistently sending records from MES. However, these were all custom development solutions. MII is no longer available. DM might be closer to the approach you want, but you’re right about the cost. So far, I’ve only worked with one MES vendor that centered around SAP, which was PSI Software. However, they were more specialized in the discrete and flat steel sectors.

Author: jasna4.3.2
Content: Thanks for your input and comments. I appreciate how you put “build “ in quotation marks, because MES vendors never refer to the customization of their products as “build”. To properly deploy it enterprise-wide they standardize interfaces and package a few basic functions as a template. What MES vendors try to sell as a template should be nothing other than our MES that we should “build” in-house. I’m convinced it is a profitable alternative to paying for their engineering of a customized (vendor “build”) solution, plus ongoing licensing fees.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I don't like the concept of MES as a software,

To me Management Execution Folks(the MEF) needs software tools to help them.

Talking about an MES to me implies that the solution needs to be a Software, and ideally one with MES in the name.

But if you look a series of Functional Needs that the MEF have, then perhaps those functions can exist on different software.

and Regardless of whether you say you are going to build or Buy, you end up with a bunch of configuration anyway. I think the Walker and Sean Robinson Build V;s Buy debate, really came down to (60% build, 40% Buy) V's (40% Build, 60% Buy). And whether you end up with the Software Vendors Customising or a System Integrator Building it is still essentially people creating DB tables and writing scripts.

That said, I like the openness of an Architecture led approach, where you can have a highly customisable IIoT Platform. And any decent system Integrator will have a MES template( in fact more than one) based on previous systems they built, to start with that can be customised for you. It's not like they will be starting from Scratch. And certainly froma corporate point of view, because no manufacturing plant is the same as another no single software will suit. What a lazy  CTO expects from a COTS is just not possible at all .

and there are a lot of profitable Integrators that build MES solutions on Platforms that don't; have ongoing licencing costs, for a lot less than what a software vendors customises their solution for. There are quite a few of us on this platform too. 

Integrating into SAP is not a problem either, and some of their modules lie SAP PM are pretty decent, but they don;t have a proven MES solution IMHO. The sam as they do not have a SCADA or PLC solutions. Lots of MES and IOT platforms though will integrate no problem.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
some background on this  and maybe this is a gap of my understanding of SPC. 

I'm assuming SPC can be both long and short term. From what I've seen in the past, an X/Y chart showing pump speed over time and alarm if speed over (x) for (y) time. This I see as a SCADA/IIoT function. If I extrapolate this and say I'm going to do this in MES, now MES database is being used for time-series stuff when it should be used for transactional data. Then I see a slippery slope, as the MES database grows larger, query take longer, system slows down, etc...

Now if the source of the data is from MES and it's longer term SPC analysis then ok to do it in MES. 
Or simply do not allow MES to do any SPC, instead offload an necessary MES data via API/change-data-capture to a data warehouse where any and all SPC can take place with a database suited for SPC. (time series vs transactional)

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Can I ask why does it matter?

To echo what I said earlier it's all just tables and scripts at the end of the day.

I've certainly seen it implemented by SCADA software. But to me I don't think the Management Execution Folks and more either Operators or quality that are interested in it.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: because storing large data sets in high frequency shouldn't be in MES -- keep transactional only?

Author: jbonhage155
Content: we have an MES site that's been running for 5 years with a small amount of SPC, SPC related tables are about 20 GB and queries take 10 mins to load a report. I think if MES vendor has a good SPC module /software then I guess it would be ok

Author: jbonhage155
Content: also does SPC go in transactional or time-series DB?

Author: jbonhage155
Content: this is for large enterprise deployment. Then SPC will have dependencies on validation with MES operations functions. I think for large enterprise, separatate MES, SPC and OEE. (or maybe ok to group SPC and OEE)

Author: jbonhage155
Content: how fast will your MES queries be in SQL when you are queries have dependencies on 1M+ row tables

Author: evjakec
Content: I think a lot of folks will separate their production and process data. Then, only blend what makes sense. For example, maybe one data point of many is needed to make routing decisions in MES. First capture the raw data in ProcessData, then extract the one attribute into ProductionData for MES purposes.

Author: evjakec
Content: SPC typically will pull from ProcessData, but you may want to display the charts in your MES.

Author: karltbraun
Content: There is a #mes-bootcamp channel

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Is that not coming from the concept of monolith MES solution.

Embracing an Open Architecture, and looking at functions and solutions, allows me use the right tool for the job.

You could have the data stored so it is optimized for a particular query to show on on the visualisation. But then adhoc queries are slow.

We can have single source of truth for current but when we look at historical neither a SQl relational DB nor a time series DB nor a NoSQL nor a GraphDB can give the performance needed for all use cases.

You can still have a master with all the data, but try not to query it and use dedicated "functions specific" tables and DB's

That's where I would start anyway a SPC application with dedicated DB's and publish back results to my UNS and store somewhere

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The MEF really is the people, but You need an self owned Eco System that solve the problems of you Manufacturing Team.
To me it does not have to be a single "MES software", Use Litmus, to Connect, use HighByte for Data Ops, use Tulip as the Operators Interface,  Grafana, for the Dashboards in public Area, 
Or maybe you have a Ignition/FrameWorX/InTouch as you Platform and Connect , publish into a Central MQTT broker, and perform different Data Operations, in the Platform again and republish the results. 

But that EcoSystem needs to be owned by the business. Maybe you have a key partner help you build but you need to be able to take over, or switch to another partner if needed.

I would not use the Magic Quadrant to help me find good software, I would only use it to help me convince someone in corporate that the decision is safe.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: right but shouldn't the right type of database for the use case?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Yes, did I not say that. Right tool for the Job.

I have gone to all sorts of lengths previously to get performance up retrieving lots of data from a SQL DB. And it was very cleaver in one way, but it is a bit like congratulating myself for using a hammer to drive a screw into wood instead of getting the right tool for the Job.

I do that quite a lot I find,


But I think in the OT/MES world and here on the server there is a drive to thinking that , if a Single Source for current state is good, a single source for history would be even better.
And I am only recently fully understanding the issues with that. You could in theory have a Historian like PI as your Single source of historical truth but creating batch records, or SPC graphs as you point out would not meet performance expectation.

Author: .killnine
Content:
> right but shouldn't the right type of database for the use case?

> I have gone to all sorts of lengths previously to get performance up retrieving lots of data from a SQL DB

We ended up having a 'data warehouse' (pre "data lake" terminology) that rolled up metrics and only kept hot data so long. You can have all the architecture in the world but if you're constantly querying huge data sets theres only so much you can do.

So we might have 2 years of historical data, but we'd use Informatica or something to pull that data into our KPIs and only store that beyond a 2-3 year period. That data would live 'forever' but it was so compressed by comparison with the raw data that it's fine.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: yeah it's brutal. We have an MES that has been left alone in a dark corner for 4+ year (runs on MSSQL) and it's a total mess. Up to 10 mins to run a report.

Author: .killnine
Content: Right. I guess my point is, that's not really a technology problem at that point

Author: .killnine
Content: You ain't gonna "NoSQL" your way out of that 😄

Author: jbonhage155
Content: haha yeah

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
how did you pump data from your sources into the data lake? 
We are starting to use CDC in Ignition (Postgres events), then do the same with MES

Author: jbonhage155
Content: when you dump everything into the data lake at least the core systems stay performant, and the data lake can 'self manage' itself to allow queries on large data ?

Author: .killnine
Content:
I think it was a periodic task on a weekly timeframe. The team would run an ETL (extract, transform, load) process that would push the data to the warehouse.

It was done once the data had been audited, so it was likely a few weeks old. It wasn't my team so I don't know exactly but you want to make sure the data is as correct as it can be because editing it later is kinda a pain

Author: .killnine
Content: So there's a tradeoff in 'latest data' versus 'immutable record'

Author: .killnine
Content: Honestly, the warehouse might have been even older than that and people used more up-to-date reporting on the hot data source, I'm honestly not certain at this point.

Author: .killnine
Content: But yes, it kept the core system very performant.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
Hello,

Every challenge I encounter in production is calculating OEE by shift. It might sound funny to you, but I haven’t found the correct method for this. The production facility’s shifts are changing. In fact, sometimes I worked with shifts like 23:00-07:00, which span two days.

When the shift changes, reports can become meaningless. For example, if we take a two-day report, the concept of a “day” itself changes. If we try to determine shifts dynamically in the table based on their validity times, the system becomes slow due to the large number of records. Is there a best practice for this?

I also faced an issue with recording downtimes. Splitting downtimes at the end of shifts made calculations easier. However, splitting downtimes seemed meaningless, so I performed dynamic calculations instead. For example, consider a machine:
    •    It stopped halfway through the first shift,
    •    It was completely stopped during the second shift,
    •    It started again at the beginning of the third shift.

There is no record for the second shift. However, the machine was down during that shift. I handled this by performing calculations, which worked fine, but managing dynamic shift changes became a separate problem.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: My take: MQ's are out of date the moment they're published, they're incomplete, the criteria for inclusion/exclusion are bizarre and inexplicable, and the criteria for position on the MQ are even more opaque.  They should never, EVER be taken literally, although customers and vendors do, and Gartner does nothing to dissuade them.  I think they're useless, personally.

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content:
If a schedule is mutable I've seen "ProductionDate" and "Shift" columns added to production data in addition to the timestamp. That would include relevant info at the time of data insert. Queries reference those instead of timestamps. Quite often the workday isn't midnight-midnight but may be 7am-7am. So data with a timestamp at 5am on Tuesday actually has ProductionDate of Monday and Shift = 3rd shift.

If the schedule is immutable and you don't want to/can't edit db schema and only have timestamp info, you can make for example a 7am-7am workday instead of midnight-midnight just through query logic. Although any edits to schedule would also (probably unintentionally) apply to past data in this case.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Great points. I always like to have 'CreateDate', 'ReportDate', and 'ShiftKey' columns present in these types of tables. It's also useful to have a set of normalized shift/schedule tables that account for historical changes. This makes reporting so much easier. It's not fun to reconcile how multiple plants have scheduled over the past decade in the middle of developing a report or kpi.

Author: .killnine
Content:
Yes, this is what we did. We had a separate shift table that was populated regularly to account for plants moving from 7a-7p to 5a-5p or to 8-hour shifts or whatever. 

Then, subsequent systems would use that for when to trigger shift start/ shift even events.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
The ERP and the MES have different needs, and therefore different attributes that need to be defined for a production line.
Unless your system is exceptionally trivial in its functionality, you will need to configure the production line in both systems.
The best you could hope for is that when the production line is configured in the ERP, a draft, empty version of the line is automatically added to the MES

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Some SAP customers and those from other vendors have used ERP modules as their MES over the years. Duplicating master data can be problematic, and ERP vendors should consider building deeper MES functionality.  Not suggesting it’s ideal, but it can work.

Author: milanhurban
Content: What's the problem with the citizen developer pitch?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
The problem is that no one talks about governance, and instead pitch Citizen Development without Governance as a good thing. Then companies find themselves with hundreds of apps that no-one wants to support, and that are all doing roughly the same thing, just using slightly different logic and rules.
It's been the same pitch for 20 years, starting with self-service reporting and analytics, and then to app development. No one wants to say that you still need governance because it gets in the way of vendors selling licenses.
(I am a software vendor, who sells low-code app development MES software, we just don't pretend that MES should be built without governance)

Author: zeratall
Content: Totally agree. A question for thought, isn’t at least creating a common platform that centralizes citizen developed apps where governance can be established a step in the right direction vs excel ? Which if you think about it, excel is probably the bulk of citizen developed apps we see in industry today.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
No. It's worse.
Low-code enables more apps to be built faster.
It's excel on steroids, with all of the things we don't like about excel.

Author: zeratall
Content: I agree, but I do think there is something to be said around the increase in visibility when apps are being created in a platform vs excel. Hard to monitor what’s being built if it lives on someone’s local drive.

Author: milanhurban
Content: Would this governance be similar to what Walker advocates for with UNS namespaces, i.e. let people create them, then check in periodically and standardize? Or have stricter guidelines from the very beginning.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That's not a bad thing.  There are LOTS of use cases for "disposable apps", most that never actually get done because of the IT police.  This is the reason personal computers and spreadsheets first gained popularity - people had problems they needed to solve and IT moved too slowly or not at all.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Why the low code hate?  Weren't you/aren't you really doing the same thing? And Excel et al have delivered MASSIVE value over the years, even if the IT nazis lost control.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The real myth with "citizen developer" stuff is that it's end users developing the apps.  That's very, very rarely the case.  It's usually IT or integrators or plant engineers.  So there can certainly be governance processes put in place, and usually are.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, low-code/no-code "apps" are a helluva lot easier for someone else to pick up and modify than a pile of javascript in some obsure UX framework and a backend written in Go because someone read about it in a blog.

Author: brianhaselton_33457
Content: I'm not sure I can relate with the idea that cit dev proposals ignore governance. Governance is almost always the key topic for customers considering cit dev approaches in my experience.

Author: brianhaselton_33457
Content: Agreed. The idea is good, but so often it translates to the company buying the software trying to put another task onto a process engineer. It's easy enough to learn, but learning the system still takes time. Time they often don't have or they need to put it off to go deal with production issues/their primary job. I've seen it work a couple times, but those individuals are typically exceptional

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
There is no low-code hate. 
Just 'Citizen Developer' myth hate.
Yes, we are a low-code platform.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
There can be governance processes put in place. The companies with the failed Tulip implementations did not put any in place.
As said previously, this is not a complaint against Tulip or low-code, the tech is good.

Author: evjakec
Content: The Stanley Black&Decker Tulip example is one that I’ve seen mature into a good setup. Very much focused around a CoE and using core libraries. Took time to mature of course.

Author: giladl
Content: @GeoffNunan I could not agree more! Governance has to be in place and its much more than just control - it is to make the solution building effective and makes sure the company business objectives are met. Governance is a critical component of the the digital transformation strategy execution. Letting people configure, build, change with no framework, guidance or guardrail is a recipe for disaster. Also in regulated industries it is a must to meet compliance - non compliance is unlawful.

Author: giladl
Content: To add @GeoffNunan. Citizen Development is just a component of Democratization. What really sets digital technology apart from traditional is that its "Democratized". This means that everybody has access to use it and benefit from it. There is much more to democratization than the citizen developer. In fact I have seen many of these citizens build solution that are monolithic, not democratized and go against the tenants of composability. This in turn leads us to the governance discussion.

Author: ralf05700
Content: Would one add human workers to the UNS dynamically or abstract that away in the MES? Performancetracking, QControl, EBR etc

Author: antonmelander
Content:
Hi everyone. I'm working with a newly started startup (www.ronja.tech) to build a "next-gen" MES targeting the small/ medium-sized factories (typically relying on Excel today) and startups building out manufacturing capabilities. In both cases, most existing MESs are overkill or too expensive to implement. As we're just getting closer to the alpha version of the product, we'd love to leverage this network and see if anyone would be willing to jump on a call and provide feedback. 

Furthermore, we're planning to build "in the open" and share progress, etc, on LinkedIn. Would there be an interest in this group to follow our journey? (admins please provide guidance on where such updates would be suitable).

Author: evjakec
Content: Is anyone in here from the Sepasoft team? Have a quick question.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Build it and they will come.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: They might not have any money to pay for it when they get there, or know what to do with it, but they will definitely come.

Author: _dyland
Content: Worse, they might have the money but still not pay for it.

Author: brianpribe
Content: All large manufacturers were small manufacturers once.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: I don't follow what you mean?

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Yes! That's another group it's best to stay away from

Author: brianpribe
Content: Large manufacturers make up only 5% of the industry. That’s a small pool to fight over. Small manufacturers make up 75% of the industry, yet they get little help. You can either fight over the ones who exist, or you could grow the next one.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Of the small ones, how many want to spend money on MES? 
How many understand what they want MES to do for them?
How many have the capability in their internal teams to own, run and maintain an MES?
And when I say MES, I don't mean an OEE dashboard, or some basic performnce metrics, that's not MES.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: They need education , alot of small to mediums i talk to dont know the term.

Author: brianpribe
Content: How many want to reduce the amount of materials they waste in production? How many want to double the utilization of their machines? How many want there personnel to do more with less? This is true for every manufacturer, but tell me how many machines out there in production are being tracked on their performance? Like cycle times, count, machine state change. Large ones at some capacity generally are, but zilch for the vast majority of the industry. So of course they don’t need MES, they can’t even count what the fuck they did in the last hour. We pride ourselves on the technologies and problems we get to solve, but the industry as a whole is just starting in their 3.0 journey.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Maybe, but it's not because of ignorance or lack of availaable technology to solve the problems. Sensors, dashbaords and databases have been around for longer than I have. It has been possible to monitor cycle times and machine counts digitally and report on them in an automated way for at least 40 years.
You have to ask Why. Why do the majority of the industry not see value in doing it?

Author: brianpribe
Content: They do. They don’t have the fucking time. They are putting out fires 24/7. Small manufacturers make $1M-$5M in revenue a year, 5-20 machines, 5-20 staff, and maybe 1-2 IT level ppl who can understand this shit. But they’re the ones maintaining their existing processes, and usually are the only ones who can solve why the line is down. Now how can any team dedicate 12-18 weeks to build a PoC when this is their reality.

Author: brianpribe
Content: The worst part is the ppl this technology is for (the younger generation) don’t want to go anywhere near a plant floor. They don’t get the tools they need or the support to be successful. There’s a reason why manufacturing in the US has dropped to 8% of GDP and that is laughably abysmal for any developed nation.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
That either means:
- we don't want to invest in improving the business. There can be a reason for this. I've seen small business that are profitable enough, and don't need / are not motivated to be any better.
- we don't believe we are doing poorly, and so think that the opportunity to improve is not big enough to justify the investment
- we believe that we have bigger problems that technology won't fix. like we can't get workers to turn up, or we don't have sales orders, or we have a bad culture
I've seen all of these reasons. I've never seen 'we don't have time to do better', always one of the others

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Honestly the best approach to helping these companies is to recommend a good private equity company to buy them and turn them around.

Author: brianpribe
Content: The best thing these companies can do is bring in and empower the next generation of makers. Our industry is filled with old farts who already have one foot in the casket and no one there ready to take the torch to make the thing we need.

Author: brianpribe
Content: I bet the average age in this discord is north of 40. What does that say about our industry? (Psss..It’s dying)

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
I don't know about that.
Rhize has trained 10 new graduates over the past 2 years, and I've certainly had many conversations with others about how we train the next generation.
I don't see the industry as dying.

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Does Rhize target small to medium manufacturers?

Author: geoffnunan
Content: No, our ideal customer is not typically a small to medium manufacturer. That's not because they don't have the same problems, it's because our platform's value is in the enforced governance inherent in the schema, and that is more relevant to large  or heavily regulated organisations

Author: brianpribe
Content: Survivorship-bias. In all respects, Rhize is sick, but the rust belt says otherwise.

Author: evjakec
Content: What are your thoughts on folks like Pico offering their MES for free. A valid way to reach small manufacturing companies? Wonder how many free instances are running.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
If you're not paying for the product, you are the product.
There's no valid business model in Free

Author: geoffnunan
Content: There's a reason it's called the rust belt

I go  and take UNI interns and then hire them to be the next generation of engineers on the shop floor. A fresh perspective always helps especially if you empower them to implement their ideas.

Author: geoffnunan
