Author: rickbullotta
Content: Running in real production is the statistic that matters.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It’s really hard to sell to SMEs and maintain a decent margin.  A lot of work (almost as much as a big company) for a lot less reward. It’s a structural thing. Plus, any fixed cost investment up front (typically labor and some hardware in the SaaS era) is a much bigger percentage of profit from the customer’s POV. It’s a tough slog on both sides.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: My personal experience is that manufacturers want to improve. If we accept that assumption and then ask why they are not improving, could it be that they can't afford to? And by that I mean afford a FTE with sufficient knowledge and experience. I think Walker is right on this one. In my organization I don't see the possibility of me making more than the plant manager.

Author: _dyland
Content:
For the small Manufacturers there are a few different ways I group them - this is far from a comprehensive list and is really only based on my observations working for the little guys.

The first two buckets are:
1. The ones that are small and will stay small.
2. The ones that are small but looking to grow.

The first one breaks down further into:

1.1. Small and Content - These guys are likely not going to invest a dime in this stuff, they are content where they already are. If the world goes digital, they hope to be retired by then.

1.2. Small with an equally small addressable market - These guys could digitize, but if they cant sell any more than they are already able to produce, they may not care to invest the time, capital, or energy into this. Some may want to do some level of digitization, but usually to increase efficiencies, maybe the goal is to get production down to a single shift. This is where architectures like what you were showing at ProveIt really shine - Low Cost, Easy to implement, and enterprise scale may never be a real concern.

1.3. Small with room to grow but a fairly low ceiling due to a small addressable market - These guys are basically in the same boat as [1.2] but will benefit a bit more directly as there is still room for sales to increase as production capacity does.

1.4. Small and looking to sell - These guys may have an idea that digitization would make them more attractive, they may freeze spending at a moments notice... I try to stay far away from these as even if they cut the budget today, the intent is all wrong and chaos ensues.

The second one is a bit more simple:

2.1. Looking to Grow ready to go - This the most fun for me - Small and Medium, they are driven to improve and view the implementation costs as a driver of that growth. Using measurable KPIs and Actionable insights to drive efficiencies in not only production but every facet of the business. From Supply Chain, to Marketing, to Production - They just want to get better at what it is they do.

2.2. Looking to Grow but not yet ready to go - They will try to minimize the budget and ask for a stack like what you were presenting at ProveIt. That stack will get them to the next step but they will pinch pennies and argue that the open source stuff is good enough - until it isnt and they scale out, often this ends in overtaxed systems failing and blame being thrown left and right... I try to avoid these situations...

Author: rickbullotta
Content: …and most of those classifications won’t spend significant time or money as you describe

Author: _dyland
Content: Not if you limit yourself to plant floor use cases.

Author: _dyland
Content: 2.1 is the only one I would target for anything more than a largely open source stack - like UMH.

Author: _dyland
Content: 2.1 is the only one I would personally target - and for that I am selling to directors and above if I want any type of budget to get approved.

Author: _dyland
Content: 1.3 can be fun, but I have been there and been burned too many times.

Author: zeratall
Content: I’m definitely not the expert on the business side (this conversation is actually really interesting to me). I’m an architect and I just like to build cool stuff. That being said a real problem with 2.1 outside of small or medium manufactures. Is it’s very seldom a single entity that needs to sign off. You might have 19 people ready to go and have funds but 1 stakeholder is holding out. Large corporations have resources but there is also more bureaucracy, politics, and just BS in general that really slows things down. One of the main reasons I left corporate life.

Author: _dyland
Content: All of those classifications were for Small Manufactures. The game changes a bit for Medium and is a whole different one with Large Manufacturers.

Author: zeratall
Content: Aaaah gotcha fair enough and absolutely correct!

Author: _dyland
Content: And I am open to being wrong, this is just based on my personal experience with the ones AI have worked with.

Author: zeratall
Content: Im not an expert in the business side (my comment above was just from experience), but everything you said above makes sense to me. We talked about this at conference but the business side can get fuzzy just because it’s mostly a function of culture.

Author: _dyland
Content:
100% - In my experience a lot of it boils down to culture, politics, and education. There are too many example I have of the client asking for a more expensive and strictly worse solution... Automation isn't sexy, at least until we make it so. 

That said, as mentioned above, sometimes it doesn't make sense to digitize or automate more. The production is just one part of the whole ecosystem, if constraints exist elsewhere increased production wont help in the slightest.

Author: _dyland
Content: That culture, politics, and education is as much a problem with the integrators - if not more... not understanding the whole of the buisness and pushing something that isnt needed.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Do they really have the resources to support a cobbled together OSS stack though?  I think they want/need cheap, not open source

Author: zeratall
Content:
That’s a really good point. I think we all know this but digital transformation in many ways is just a naturally progression in overall business maturity. 

One of the last presentations I created and gave at my last company to executive CIO leadership was making that point. This idea that Digital Maturity will fundamental identify and help facilitate changes in operations to improve business. To me it’s all connected.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I am not on the Open Source or nothing train - Cheap enough to maintain a desired ROI while still completing hte job is the important part.
Open Source was the wrong word tbh.

Though there is a difference between something like PLC4X and  Node-Red, Appsmith, or UMH.
It doesn't take much to spin up portainer, a couple Node Red instances, Postgres, and Appsmith. A Single employee could handle it in a 50 or less person single site manufacturer no question, they could even be a recent graduate... so wouldn't even need to be that expensive. 

Removing the Open Source Requirement, at a small scale site! (this would not scale!!!) - Node Red, n8n, EMQX, Appsmith, postgres, and Timebase would get you a good enough UNS for that 50 or less person single site manufacturer.

Author: _dyland
Content: If they are using open source to build their own applications in a full code enviornment it would be impossible for most small manufacturers.

Author: zeratall
Content: Some verticals won’t/can’t look at OSS. At my former employer it was seen as a risk.

Author: _dyland
Content: Yeah, NG is pretty far from small - if anyone suggested Node Red at that scale I would probably want to slap them

Author: zeratall
Content: Hahah yeah although it had less to do with scale and more to do with cybersecurity. You’d be surprised some of the things you’d see at large corporations because in reality they are companies within companies. That’s actually why I was an EA under the CIO, the CIO  was trying to create an enterprise wide reference architecture so each BU would stop doing their own thing.

Author: _dyland
Content: Though I wonder how deep that goes... Its pretty hard to get the full stack without Open Source if you drill under the hood enough.

Author: _dyland
Content: Like I am assuming that doesnt mean that nothing could be written in JAVA?

Author: zeratall
Content: Can’t get into specifics for obvious reasons but let’s just say getting something approved for enterprise use that had a OSS component was always under much more scrutiny than something completely proprietary.

Author: _dyland
Content: Not asking you to 🙂 there are reasons I dont live in that world.

Author: zeratall
Content:
I always joked with some of my colleagues, I always wanted someone like walker to speak at a A&D  conference because I think the first words out of his presentation would be “your all dead/f$&@k’d” lol.

Jokes aside, it’s just a hard domain to innovate in, in many ways it’s a function of the customer and the requirements they have established for that industry. Which is why I’m interested to see what happens with some of these valley startups like anduril and palantir. Etc

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
To innovate is to risk something.
that means for some companies and some industries the risks are higher

We sometimes talk about a manufacturing industry that failed to innovate like the software industry, but there was normally a much worse outcome associated with failures in the IT domain  than the software domain.

I've worked in machine safety where the risk is very immediate, and in pharma, where mislabelling would mean a child receives an adult  dose.

I can only imagine in Aerospace or military the same applies.

Author: antonmelander
Content: A likely reason that keeps popping up when interacting with SMBs (10-100 usd annual revenue) is not that the technology isn’t there - rather it’s not accessible. The types of skills required isn’t a staple at most of these companies. And the ”risk profile” of investing into consultants to get an MES in 6 months (record fast?) is not attractive. And as factory not event measuring nearly any KPIs a full blown MES is too much.

Author: antonmelander
Content: What seems like a paradox is that most of the common philosophies (lean, kaizen..) emphasize small continuous improvements - yet most (all?) MES projects are major big bang projects?

Author: sparkylarks
Content: My companies whole raison d'etre is to try to teach companies to take a small incremental approach to Digital transformation ,and help guide them in a way that  prevents the build up of technical debt so they can accelerate as they go through steps.

Author: antonmelander
Content: Love it!

Author: evjakec
Content:
I asked this question in our market guide survey (time to first deployment and then total time of the project). On average, 3-4 months before first go live. That’s   even with the compostable champ, Tulip. Then usually a full year for the project. This is greatly influenced by two things. 

1. How close does their production fit a standard that will allow a lot of out of the box deployment. 

2. How ready are the people to learn and understand the system. This one can hold things up big time and is the number one reason why projects start to fail and have to be corrected. Big disclaimer on this though is that these are vendors saying this, but I agree in most part.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
But the skills required are readily available in every university intern. It really does not take many skills to operate NodeRed, Mosquito, and Grafana.
That's why I don't think the problem is related to skills or technology, It's fundamentally that the management of the business don't see value in digitalization, which may be a valid belief for their business.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I agree that a full MES implementation is.not the right move for all companies.

And some owners don't need a digital dashboard showing current state. The company is small and they know it.

But I do believe that some digital integration will benefit and I am a fan of the intern + MING approach

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Me too @Mark O'Donovan 
I'm a firm believer in the value of consultants who can help small and medium businesses understand digital innovation lifecycles, and build an innovative culture in their businesses.
It's a message most small and mid-size businesses understand better than `Capture all your data`

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: Yes, we split our offer on « Essential » and « Advanced » QMS requirements. Essential is already cover with SAP QM + Tulip, but advanced capabilities as SPC/APC/Progressive Control… will be managed by a QMS that also expose API to also be execute by Tulip Apps to harmonize UX. We see more and more a requirement of Hybrid QMS (UX with full API)

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Does anyone have any experience or opinions on TrakSYS?

Author: evjakec
Content: I can share general feedback I hear, but I’m not an end user. Any specific questions?

Author: jpmac.s
Content: Nothing in particular, just general feedback from people who have used it

Author: evjakec
Content: Overall, very strong in the batch production industries, such as food and bev. A Microsoft background will be good for your staff (SQL database, customizations in C#). these batch systems are often modeled from the ISA-88 standard, so having some understanding there is good. The only negative I’ve heard come through recently is that they’re forcing their legacy customers into a subscription model, usually at least doubling their annual spend. If you’re a new client, of course this wouldn’t affect you. The other thing I don’t like is that they charge extra for high availability.  This should be standard for any vendor. I have not used the system personally so can’t say how it compares, but they’re all pretty similar.  Sequential function diagrams are used to build your process flow and each step is some process such as a weigh and dispense station.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
I’m an SAP MII consultant, with about 10 years of experience. We’ve also recently started an Ignition project.

Which part of the QM integration are you referring to? SAP MII doesn’t include built-in QM integration. I assume you’re managing the process using custom-built screens.

You can handle the same process in Ignition as well. And in this project, we are also implementing the QM process.

Also, just out of curiosity — why didn’t you choose SAP DM?

Author: youri.regnaud

Author: rickbullotta
Content: None that I'm aware of.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
Hi everyone, 
Has anyone here been even slightly involved in a real SAP Digital Manufacturing project? Have you seen one fully implemented, or heard any happy—or unhappy—customer experiences?

I keep getting questions about it, but so far, everything I’ve seen has been limited to demos. I’m trying to understand if I’m being too conservative by recommending Ignition or custom solutions instead.

On paper, SAP DM looks like it could work. But once I start analyzing real customer needs, I find myself leaning toward custom development instead of sticking to the standard—despite knowing that custom work isn’t easy either.

Lately, I’ve been wondering if the reason I don’t recommend DM is not just technical limitations, but simply because I don’t feel confident enough due to my limited hands-on experience with real implementations.

Author: evjakec
Content:
SAP DM is a big shift from ME\Mii but some of the same core concepts are there. I’ve been asking for examples for months and it’s difficult because it’s still pretty new and the customers have to be willing to share. I am aware of a few pilots and then one customer I’m trying to track down. 

If there’s any clarity you’d like to get, Sam and Matthias from SAP are at our show this week. I could run it by them. 

If not already clear, it is a full public cloud solution. They have edge connectivity offerings but something to keep in mind if you have equipment integration. Their bigger integrators seem to be picking it up well.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Same experience here and you are right not to recommend if you aren't confident in a software. SAP DM got the most criticism from the community and Walker on any software, but Salvatore Castro was here to take it all, so hopefully in the times past that most of these have been addressed.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And AFAIK the edge connectivity is still based on PCO, which MII uses also.  I think the "cloud only" nature of DM will be a challenge for a lot of users though. Local survivability/availability remains fairly important.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content: SAP is selling licenses directly without involving an integrator. Then the customer turns to us for consulting. For now, when such a project comes our way, I’ll take the opportunity to get hands-on experience and share the outcomes.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Serdar Gökay, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
Yes, PCo is still there—only the name has changed, and the old product has been deprecated. Not much has really changed under the hood.

Even something as basic as adding a customer order detail as a column on a production order screen is quite painful at the moment. I’m sure it will improve over time, though.

They’re still trying to stabilize the edge solution; it’s not fully mature yet.

And while the constant updates might seem like a good thing, in practice, they often introduce new objects that aren’t supported in the older setup. This ends up shifting the burden onto the customer, who has to keep adapting to the latest version.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
Thanks! What I’m really curious about is whether there are any truly satisfied customers—especially in discrete manufacturing, with customer-specific production—and whether any real value has been achieved.

If there are genuinely positive references in a few industries, then with the right approach, I believe we can also make it work.

I do have access to a demo system. I still have some doubts, but they’re mostly around very detailed topics.

Content:
Hello guys,

What MES platform do you Think is the best to learn?

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Any MES platform with a solid backend / data model, ideally ISA95 based or at least similar, and more importantly just any platform you can get your hands on.
Since you know Ignition and Sepasoft modules are free to download and try, I'd start there.
https://www.sepasoft.com/downloads/

Last I've tried it didn't seem very ready on the front end but at least had an ISA95 based DB and api.
Sepasoft also had some demo projects (although didn't seem complete/functional) when I tried it in tha past, maybe it's been updated.
https://docs.sepasoft.com/articles/#!mes-module-tutorials/demo-projects

Kanoa is another Ignition-based one that apparently lets you try their software for free, haven't tried it yet myself.
https://kanoa.ai/downloads

I also recommend reading Rhize's documentation (well parts of it, maybe not the most technical stuff that only applies to their platform): https://docs.rhize.com/

Anyway, I think learning the general functionality / structures is a lot more important than learning a specific platform/system.
Curious to hear what others think.

Author: evjakec
Content:
I just want to second the documentation from Rhize. Great stuff out there. 

Any end goals you’re looking for? The big players will have many jobs out there (Siemens, GE, Rockwell, Apriso). Life sciences folks like Emerson. Tulip can absolutely be used for QMS and to track KPIs. 

A lot of the “low code” outside of Tulip is sequential function diagrams or BPMN. I think a lot of it would translate from one MES to another. 

For customization it’s a mixed bag of Java, C# and some scripting. Knowing one of the big two languages is helpful.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I have not seen many true "enterprise" MES implementations with Ignition. When they are, one could argue the "solution" is not Ignition per se, but the SI's professional services or what a really committed team elected to build. More often than not, it's many local MES with ad-hoc implementations. It's still a good tool for learning to "build".

I would qualify this with the industry verticals (and even localities) you typical support. There are not a lot of big, mass-market MES vendors. Most MES solution providers are relatively small (in terms of volume, revenue, install base). Even among the big names, they tend to have own niche or focus. Those that span a broader set of industry verticals tend to have done so through acquisition.

Examples of different industry focuses:

Plex focuses on automotive, aerospace & defense, and some food & beverage. A lot of functionality related to meeting requirements (e.g., quality, materials, delivery) of tiered industry or OEM supply chains with highly repetitive manufacturing. Large installation base in the upper midwest of US, parts of southern US, Ontario, Queretaro, Guadalajara.

MPDV focus on broader discrete manufacturing. It can handle more variety like low volume / high mix, more assembly / kitting, etc in addition to what Plex does, but less functionality to support big industry requirements. Installation base is mostly DACH.

Körber PAS-X focuses on life sciences. Customer base is big pharma. Robust batch management and record functionality. Installation base is global, but skews Europe.

Applied Materials focuses on electronics manufacturing . There is a lot of specific functionality to support fabrication processes, material management, and traceability for semiconductor manufacturing. Installation base is concentrated in East Asia.


For example, a gene therapy manufacturer is not going to use Applied Materials and Plex. An automotive supplier is not going to use PAS-X. Long story short, find an area of focus.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Tulip is like a pure no code / low code application building platform. There aren't prebuilt modules for Work Orders with master data, for example. There are reference apps that can be reworked, but it's not like an MES solution with out-of-box functionality, if that makes sense. All that needs to be built out in the platform.

It's definitely a great tool for experimenting with operator screens. It's very much a "bottoms-up" approach to building out MES type solutions. Personally, having a bias towards repeatitive and automated manufacturing processes, I like to having the option of taking a "top-down" approach for some of the data models. To be effective at planning and reporting, I like consistently defined resources and constraints. There can be flexibility in how they are processed and executed. Ultimately, I want a part to always be a part. I want a control plan to inherit parts, processes, part specifications, etc. I want asset states and reasons to be consistent even if the asset and how they produce are not. I find this hard to do on app-by-app basis.

One interesting thing I've observed among some advanced Tulip users is that they will actually use Tulip to augment an MES. Tulip is basically a frontend and the MES is the backbone.

This thread might be helpful:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/740336189449699408/1156079464736882738

Author: rutger_18900

Not saying ISA95 is end-all be all although obviously I'm a fan of it and standardization in general, just to keep in mind.
Also a good example to show that a lot of MES systems do similar things, even if they use different names for things, and use a different tech stack!

Author: rutger_18900
Content:

Yes Ignition and Tulip are nice tools to build something custom, but are they MES by themselves? No.
If the question was how do I build a nice UI quickly, or how do I build a custom app quickly? Different answer.

.NET is also an awesome tool, you can build ANYTHING you like, but I wouldn't send you to MSDN or Microsoft learn to learn MES.

Author: evjakec
Content: I’ve been finding all of the major players are inspired from one of the standards, if not a direct usage. Batch processing vendors follow isa88 Procedure->operation->phase workflows and discrete vendors use something like Rhize produces (but not Graph). An occasional CFX system for electronics focused vendors will be out there as well.  This is where the object oriented mindset is helpful. Understand the core of how these things work and you should be able to swap from one to another without issue.

Author: nickn5549
Content:
What does “lite MES” actually mean? It’s one of those terms that sounds meaningful until you try to pin it down.
When people talk about “lite MES,” they’re usually describing something cobbled together without proper foundations. It’s like calling a shed with wheels a “lite car.” The comparison doesn’t really work.
Tools like Ignition and Tulip are excellent for what they are - platforms that let you build custom applications quickly. But they aren’t MES systems by themselves, any more than Excel is an ERP system.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: In My Opinion, Lite MES means a system that is only viewing the data, like an OEE reporting system, and not issuing commands to the control system or operators, so is not actually Executing anything.

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: That exactly why we have started our journey with Tulip to onboard frontline workers in the digital transformation and now we integrated Rhize as a « back-end/headless MES ». Rhize enforce a strong ISA-95 schema, create business rules with no code BPMN engine, all expose with GraphQL API - Tulip consume Rhize data and services with agile, lean and easy users experience. I’m a believer of MACH architecture that can be apply to Manufacturing operations, for better agility in a fast evolving world

Author: evjakec
Content: I agree there probably isn’t a true definition for “light MES”, but agree with Geoff. The typical maturity of a customer is to first Monitor, then execute, then start orchestrating with other systems (PLM,ERP). Some are good with just the monitoring and stop there. Ignition is capable of this and that’s where some of these vendors like Peakboard, Leading2Lean, MachineMetrics come in. Typically much cheaper as well.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
'lite MES' could be like SparkMES, Kanoa, Sepasoft or other MES functions that are build or closely integrated with Ignition... From what I've seen barrier to entry is high for a manufacturer to have MES like functionality and tools like Ignition which has so many integration methods and features you can build MES-like function right in the environment. 

I still struggle with the value large MES brings to the shop floor. We have implemented multiple sites to move away from paper to digital operations only to saddle the manufacturing plants with costs --- MES vendor support contacts, offshore support break/fix run support, cloud infrastructure, data lake storage, kafka-stream processing and initial deployment efforts. All these expenses ultimately get passed down the manufacturing floor.  Then manufacturing is left holding the bag wondering where is the promised ROI. But I get it, staying on paper and not going digital is a ridiculous idea -- but I think where I'm going is I like the idea of IoT / MES software platforms that enable 'front line workers' as a swiss-army knife software tools that can be deployment in specific, targeted initiatives with tangible ROI's. Ignition is awesome for stuff like this and seems like Tulip is on a similar path.

Author: jasperlouage
Content:
I’ve been trying to understand why some consider Ignition to fall short of being a true enterprise MES—if anyone can shed light on this, I’d genuinely like to learn more.

From what I’ve seen, MES integrations at large companies often come with steep costs and rarely leave end-users truly satisfied. Big-name vendors seem to offer a “90% solution,” but bridging that final 10% gap often consumes the majority of time and budget. Personally, I’d rather work with a platform that excels at delivering that last 90% efficiently—this is where I believe Ignition shines.

The foundational elements of an MES—order handling, scheduling, isa95 structure, OEE—are relatively straightforward to implement, especially starting fresh in Ignition. And when it comes to that last-mile 10% of customization (which is often the hardest part), I feel like Ignition lets you do it five times faster compared to the heavyweight legacy systems.

Is this perspective shared by others? I haven’t seen it discussed much, but it’s a viewpoint I keep coming back to.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:

Author: evjakec

Very true if the developers hack something together, but many examples where it works well.  Our study a couple years back only showed 14% of manufacturing leaders going all in with build. 

Not sure on the 5x cheaper comment? Maybe in licensing spend, but all in cost of hiring a team of engineers to build will typically mean higher overall spend.  Hence the need to do more than just replicate a vendor solution.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It's usual "faux cheaper", and if the original developer leaves the company it can be a whole lot more expensive!

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Ah the bold statements of a developer finding outdated (technical debt of years of support) COTS software licenses too expensive.
I used to think that as well, but I've changed my mind there in the past few years.

There's no such thing as pure COTS buy in MES, there's always need for customization.
But imo pure in-house custom development, or pure "trust your integrator", or a mix of both will end up more expensive than paying a license cost for tried and tested "COTS" software.
Unless you really only need very basic functionality maybe.

It will all be fine for a POC or a small operation, but when scaling and maintaining there will be pain.
Not to mention the cost of developing the system, yes a license might be expensive, but what's the price of a (team of) developer(s) building a custom copy from scratch that's just less tested?
Oh yeah and better keep them on board forever afterwards if you want any level of support.

Also what Rick says, and I'd go even further than that.
Buy --> relatively easy onboarding of many engineers who know the system (scaling, people leaving, leverage, ...)
Build it all from scratch --> onboarding is a pain, even if this original developer lives and stays forever

I used to work a lot with COTS MES software (and still do, insert Mitch Hedberg joke) I don't love, has many shortcomings and pains, but also has a lot of built-in functionalities that just work, tested, guaranteed and supported.
Seen my share of failed MES initiatives as well, but really I don't think it was ever the software that was the main issue.
It was poor project execution and governance, and that just goes x10 if you build it all yourself.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
In a strange serendipitous moment, I have just spent the evening talking about this with Sean Robinson (who you might remember from such podcasts as Built vs. Buy).

And some of the takeaways would be:
In the build vs. buy debate, it’s really asking if you want to build 60% or 40%—unless you're using Python or assembly.

A well-defined and executed "build" beats the pants off a poorly executed COTS—true, but the opposite is also true.

There are crap COTS MES solutions and good ones, and others in between.

To look at MES, there are 13 capabilities defined by MESA. MES Lite tends to cover the 4 core pillars of OEE, Downtime, Work Order Management, and Scheduling. And certainly, it is possible to build something reasonably basic. But how much time does it take to build an Ignition-based FCS scheduling module? Especially for the first customer.

Or Labour Management? Or building a custom Maintenance Management system?

But the real difference between a platform and a dedicated MES product is the inbuilt abstraction that allows the shop floor data that I—and many others here—think about (and which Ignition handles excellently). That makes it easier to integrate into other systems (e.g., the HR training module), because it follows an abstraction approach that is consistent with other abstraction approaches.

"Cheaper" is very subjective—always much more expensive if objectives are not met.

Author: farid1623
Content: This is an extremely poor solution.  Power apps can't connect to your assets.  It's also hardly easier to use than Ignition - you should just start there.  The trial is free, so build what you want and let it prove its' own value.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
I'm not a MESA member myself and mostly know them for B2MML, can you share this definition of 13 capabilities? Interested to learn more there!

I have a hard time with this "core 4" stuff I often see here.
Sounds to me like an availibility/downtime tracking system, but with more words to make it sound important.

Let's say OEE is a core MES functionality, which I don't necessarily agree with:
-  Why is downtime a separate pillar? Isn't this part of OEE?
-  Alternatively:
  -  How do you calculate OEE without capturing quality data? I'm thinking quality definitions, sampling and/or automated reject counts
  -  How do you calculate OEE without performance data? I'm thinking defined equipment capabilities and data collection

What does scheduling entail here? Is it heavily automated/validated detailed scheduling based on product definitions, material availability, equipment capabilities, personnel requirements and so on?
Or is it an operator clicking a button to add a work order of 500 widgets for next Tuesday?

In my opinion, what is core functionality heavily depends on the type of business and the goal of the MES system, although basic work order management is hard to do without.

Author: farid1623
Content: It's not ideal by any means, but you can use the combined OEE formula to get OEE, without knowing the A,Q,P breakdown.  Good units / theoretical number of units you should have been able to produce (at the ideal run rate during the given schedule).

Author: _dyland
Content: Core 4 is OEE, and the prerequisites to calculating OEE...

Author: rutger_18900
Content: And they define different ones (almost identical, just add a prefix) for production (aka generally MES), inventory (generally WMS), quality (generally LIMS) and maintenance (generally CMMS), but in reality there's of course a lot of overlap

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
That's not by accident. Some of the same people were key to both standards AFIK.

But MESA set out the key functions of a MES, ISA95 looks at how that MES fits within the larger context of manufacturing, and how it integrates into higher (ERP) and lowers( SCADa) laters

Author: vikanchira
Content:
We often use Ignition + Templates for Work Order, Scheduling, State history which leads to downtime tracking, and OEE. If the customer need a bit more QC app or Assembly app then we build. The formular is simple. 17k for Ignition, another 17k for the professional services to deploy the main template. Then the customer get some ROI.

80% of the factories here don't have this. Forget buying any branded MES, 99.9% of customers here wouldn't have the budget.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
https://www.linkedin.com/posts/vikan-chirawatpongsa-1666785_the-cost-of-starting-a-digital-mes-for-activity-7337026414929506304-d-B7
Inspired by the conversation from this thread

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
I really like the stuff you build, and I think it's a great way to get started! 🙌 
But this falls under "trust your integrator" I mentioned in my earlier comment.
They're still kind of buying a product, but just from an SI instead of a software vendor.

The comment you replied to was more about questioning the "Core 4" being basically  "OEE, and the prerequisites to calculating OEE" as @Dylan DuFresne worded so well.
And that I don't necessarily agree with, and this is not what I think of when I'm thinking MES.

Buy vs build (or let your SI build) is not a simple black and white discussion, and for a lot of use cases I'm not sure what the best solution.

But I 100% believe MES products (i.e. licensed products, with a robust back-end, lots of customers and engineers, a track record of years of provable support and customer success, ...) definitely have their place. If you indeed only need OEE, there's relatively cheap product options for that too.
And you'll always need configuration of course, but that will be the case for your Ignition solution too.

Claiming that for 99.9% of customers buying any MES product is not an option sounds a bit arrogant and misguided.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
To go the other direction completely, an example of a recent MES project I was involved in, for a pharma site with >5k employees and many production lines.

Some requirements for the plant wide MES system, I'm sure I'm forgetting a bunch:
-  Single pane of glass for the operator during production
-  Complete EBR, pharma compliant (CFR21p11, GMP, ALCOA, ...)
-  MBR, version controlled, with links to BOM (from ERP), product versions, work centers, ...
-  Guided operator workflows
-  Equipment management and execution (allocation, routing, w/r data, batch and lot allocation, ...)
-  Material management and genealogy (incl. ERP BOM explosion, scrap, complete reconciliation, ...)
-  Interfacing with ERP, LIMS, WMS, APS, Data historian, Digital audit trail system, ... (each piece of data has its owner)
-  Weighing and dispensing
-  Label printing (with gs1 datamatrix codes and approved artwork etc in highly regulated industry)
-  Interfacing with site wide recipe/parameter management system
-  Interfacing with many machines from different OEM's directly
-  Interfacing with the plant SCADA system
-  ...

Author: rutger_18900
Content: I think they made the right call starting with a "COTS" system with a solid backend that could provide most of this (or tools for this) instead of building everything themselves from scratch, or trusting an integrator to come up with his custom DB and some Ignition templates 😉

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
So it's $20k for Ignition and $20k for your templates, but it doesn't end there...
Not saying it's not valuable, similar to what https://www.flexwareinnovation.com/spark-mes/ is offering.
And going a step further and productizing it we get to what https://kanoa.ai/ and https://www.sepasoft.com/ are offering.

Definitely a market for stuff like this, but not a one size fits all, and pretending this $40k is the total cost is very misguiding imo.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Yes, yes, and yes. I do agree that MES like Critical Manufacturing, Parsec, etc. are great and has their place. Your example is the 100% product market fit especially for Pharma.

I'm just reflecting my world, 1 in 1,000 I see would be like your example.

Trust your SI? Definitely, when I'm the SI 🤣

The requirement for MES whether it's build or buy is the MES domain expert. The end user SHOULD understand what they are getting and be able to design it's extension (build) or understand what is being config and customised (buy).

For 999 customer I set foot to are doing paper MES, I would push the 40k solution and see if it stick. If they want to jump in to the 500k solution, I would bring in the package MES. Sadly, I have not found 1 yet here. But I haven't made 1k proposals yet. 🙂

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content: We’re working on a very similar approach and already have two customers onboard. We start with the basic Ignition license plus our MES template. Unlike others, we’ve also built out full SAP ERP integration—master data, routings, BOM, production orders, materials and work centers—packaged into a reusable template. We’ve defined an integration architecture around it, and we’re developing functionality for production confirmations, labor‐time capture, and so on. In essence, we can go to market with “SAP ERP + Core MES” using this same blueprint. On top of that we’re adding QM, PM and EWM integrations. By using SAP as our back end we gain many efficiencies. In particular, if we can leverage EWM to handle all the warehouse management needs in a factory, we can keep ERP lean and avoid building those functions in MES. Of course, this is all still theoretical until we see it in action—but for cost‐sensitive markets like ours, we believe this solution opens significant sales opportunities.

Author: vikanchira
Content: Interesting. I found more sucesss on extending more MES functions than extending to the MRP route. Wouldn't utilising SAP as your backend jack up the cost?

Author: vikanchira
Content: Also... sounds like you are offering the SAP backend part as SaaS?

Author: vikanchira
Content: I love partnering with Skyplanner for the APS/MRP part.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
Not really. In Turkey, SAP is very widespread, and we’ve been serving our customers for years using SAP MII. We’ve expanded our team and now have SAP PP and SAP QM experts. Our target customers have shifted toward SAP users, and a system integrator focused on SAP has invested in us. That’s why we decided to move forward with Ignition instead of SAP MII. SAP has stopped supporting MII and is shifting toward cloud-based MES solutions. Since those solutions are expensive and not very open to customization, we started looking for alternatives—and that’s when we came across Ignition and this group.

We realized we’ve been approaching this mostly from an IT perspective. I’m not sure whether we’ll succeed or not 🙂 But for us, SAP provides everything related to production planning, quality master data, material master data, and maintenance data. We decided to focus on the execution layer. MRP and all planning processes remain in SAP. Once the plans are created, we manage and process real-time data. SAP hasn’t added any cost for our customers, because our target audience already uses SAP.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
Companies can easily secure budgets for SAP, but surprisingly, it’s much harder for them to allocate budget for MES. Interestingly, the entire investment focus tends to revolve around ERP. However, the cloud MES solution that SAP promotes is quite expensive and, at least for now, doesn’t offer much room for customization. While SAP BTP does provide some flexibility, most customers are hesitant to adopt it.

That’s why, in our secondary approach, we’re planning to offer hybrid solutions—off-the-shelf SAP DM combined with custom extensions in Ignition. But I’m not sure yet whether this approach will gain traction. Time will tell.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content: SAP’s OT solutions gained traction largely thanks to @RickBullotta . He helped open up valuable market opportunities for us, and we were able to grow our capabilities in this area. Most SAP system integrators, however, have little to no understanding of PLCs, MES, or production processes. Their expertise in these areas is often quite limited. We’re trying to fill that gap.

Author: farid1623
Content:
Companies need to invest in their own people if they want to get the most value from a custom built MES long term.

I started my MES initiative fully expecting to need to work with a SI.  We downloaded ignition, and got a quote for some key features we wanted to build. 

Specifically we needed:
- Product tracking (with visualization of where WOs are, overlaid on a map of the plant floor)
- Machine states visualized, and downtime (to feed OEE)
- Digital andon system
- Schedule tracking 
- Basic QMS functions 

The quote came in at $75K. 

At the same time myself and my controls technician got into Ignition.  We ended up building a rough but workable product within a month.  Since then we've learned a lot, and cleaned things up a lot.

The main benefit I see is that for small changes (ex: adding an asset) I can easily update the site map, and the associated functions in the MES.  With a SI that would be another PO we'd have to cut.

This was a pet project of mine, but now I'm helping the other sites do the same.  Instead of just building it for them, I'm identifying some promising engineers at each site to assist in the process.  I know the end product will not be the best at first, but as we continuously improve it will get where we need it.   And if in the future we decide to invest in a more advanced system through SIs, at least now we've identified the people we want to be involved in assisting the SIs, and we will have a much better understanding of what we want to get from our engagement with the SIs, as well as a better technical understanding of whatever the SIs develop for us.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
SAP Digital Manufacturing is an evolving product, but successful implementation requires staying close to the standards and being cautious with customizations. I believe it’s more suitable for process-oriented manufacturing environments. That said, careful planning is critical — I’ve seen projects that remained incomplete even after four years.

As for the future of MES investments, it’s hard to predict. SAP keeps moving forward, consistently introducing new solutions on the ERP side and capturing customer budgets. With initiatives like Joule, they manage to keep the spotlight on themselves.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
We have developed SAP IDOC integration for our MES system. You can handle incoming messages from SAP such as sales orders, materials, production orders—or basically any message you want to configure. We use XSLT to transform the data and a mapping structure to write it into our own SQL tables. Of course, it’s very code-based for now, there’s no user interface yet.

Do you think this could be turned into a proper module? As far as I know, Sepasoft only works with BAPIs. The advantage of our approach is that whenever data is created or changed in SAP, it triggers us and updates the records immediately.

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: My advices are to move from SAP « old way » integration to sync/async API with SAP Gateway + a API Gateway (Gravitee, Kong, Apigee,…) Solace with Asapio make a really good job also to make SAP a solution as « normal ». Solution with API and Events/Messages. It is a lot of job, but make SAP « open » is key as SAP don’t really want to do it!

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
I’ll definitely take a look at the products and approaches you mentioned. You’re absolutely right — SAP tends to lock users into its own ecosystem. But even when we try to move forward with the alternative solutions you suggested, we still end up facing SAP.

Structures like IDOCs are quite outdated, but they’re often easier to get accepted by the IT teams. And since even newer SAP products like SAP DM still rely on this infrastructure, I modeled my solution accordingly.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It's not really a technical/plumbing challenge though - it is understanding the semantics and specifics of those APIs, how to use them, in what order, and with what values to accomplish a specific task.

@vikan I have quite the same experiences as you do. @Rutger Van Aelst I guess your pharma example is not one I’ve ever come across with, but I can see buying making sense in such a case.

@Farid N, this is exactly our approach as being a SI, we always train a whole team of promising engineers at the customer. This also overcomes the ‘Trust the SI’ issue. After 3 months, our customers could easily switch to another SI or move along without one.

Content: Agree, but I see a lot of industries still lock by SAP integration. My analysis is that companies have sometimes abandoned their integration strategy in favor of vendor "connectors". The result is a hellish mess of point-to-point technology.

Author: .turk0979
Content: There are a couple active workarounds to deal with maintaining the original ordering/structure of an array while enabling per-event modeling. If you're modeling the events of a single array, the "Expand Arrays" option in Instances would let you iterate over the values of an array. The "Expand Arrays" option will also support multiple arrays, assuming that they're all the same size. If there are more complex requirements around data processing, you may need to do this in a pipeline. With pipelines, if your arrays are consistently sized, you can use a breakup stage and a size buffer stage (with a very short timeout) to break up the data and collect it all together. Finally if you're working with variable sized arrays and have complex requirements around data processing, I would recommend reaching out to support at that point. 4.3 will introduce enhancements that will make it easier to deal with these types of scenarios.

Author: adelle7769
Content:
Hi All. 

I need to evaluate different solutions and choose a partner for the SI I work for to deliver MES Solutions. We are active in different industries, however - Metals industry being the biggest. 

I am looking at Siemens, Aveva & Traksys, as well as possibly Ignition with Sepasoft. 
How does one choose - I know most will say it depends. BUT we are starting from scratch, need to upskill in one of them in order to go to market and formalize a strategy. 

What would you say would be the main considerations?
Also; if you had/ could choose one - which will you go for?

Author: evjakec
Content:
Maybe some technical considerations could help narrow it. Are you open to cloud or even full SaaS? Will cost be a concern? 

One data point to consider is that “high volume of vendors and low differentiation” is the main reason we retired our magic quadrant at Gartner and now just produce market guides. All of the ones listed are good. Siemens is really going after complex discrete. They can handle anything but you may find the solution is geared towards discrete. 

Sepasoft would have an edge if you’re full Ignition users.

Author: adelle7769
Content:
Thank you for the quick response .
My typical customers will not be open to Cloud or full SaaS. There might be the exceptions - but I think it will be minimal, thus we would need to be able to run it on site. 

Cost is defintely a concern - being in South Africa, the exchange rate usually means cost is always a big consideration. 

I was also thinking that if Ignition is already deployed, Sepasoft is a good fit. However, how scalable is it in the long run?

We typically throughout a factory need to be able to cater for discrete, continuous and batch processing.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I cannot think of very many times where the Sepasoft Modules would be preferable to a blank SQL Database and Ignition... Especially in a hybrid environment.

If its more than one site, a layer above the sites will become a requirement at some point. Regardless of it that's an internal network, a self-managed data center, or Cloud / SaaS. 
The lowest cost, good quality options are rarely the easiest and certainly not the fastest.

Doing it without a SaaS or cloud offering will most likely take dedicated staff to build and maintain.

Content:
In general, the 3 of them are not far off in price. 

If you value flexibility, Siemens may get an edge here with their Mendix acquisition. As long as you don’t deviate from the core model, it’s free to use. I see more folks considering Mendix to do the front ends of the MES because customizing Opcenter can be challenging.

Author: adelle7769
Content:

Would you say the Siemens option is open enough as well?

Author: evjakec
Content: It is their strategic direction to be more open, and Opcenter is undergoing some changes for this. Traditionally, it was closed.  I wouldn’t say this is marketing speak either. I’ve seen their plan and it’s already been executed in their Teamcenter product. As an example, offering more options on the DB such as Postgres

Author: adelle7769

Thank you Jake - this is valuable input.

Author: evjakec
Content: They technically have two products (Production Management and MES). The MES is very much focused on the batch standard (procedure, operation, phase) and they will want to build templates around that standard. More rigid I would say.

Author: evjakec
Content: They also have flex pricing. This is something that some people actually like, but it’s pay as you use and can be shared across their portfolio. However, most feedback is negative because PI has now been moved into this model and it’s typically higher for most, 2x or more.

Author: evjakec
Content: Depending on client size, this may be a benefit and actually come in cheaper than the other two.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
You have sort of asked what vehicle should I select for my fleet. And it's really hard to answer but


I don't really like Traksys.
Id put it at the bottom of my list.

A lot of those are solutions are technically solid but it really depends on your plans.

Best advice is hire someone to inventory the business and suggest a shortlist and selection Criteria.

If you are a single plant or a couple.
As a MES I really like GE product, that is more of a buy than a lot of people like. Id put Aveva MES next and Traksys a distant Third 

More are out  ther but I don't know them well enough to comment . But I have heard some good words about Siemens.

Ignition, Siemens OA, Aveva System platform are more platforms that you can build anything you like, including a MES. Normally what happens is you build a solution on that platform that solves your problems, but you can end up with gaps.


But honestly, if you have a good partner integrator that you trust and they know the platforms and they are proactive in offering solutions, that is what you want. 

I would want someone who is actively proposing lots of small sprints( where you can dump them if they don't perform) over someone looking for a single large project. And I would be very wary of large overseas teams. You want a bunch of people who can gets lots of time on site seeing how you work.

Content:
I don't know if you need to change everything.

Technically the big difference I think you need someone who understands database architecture.

You can use SCADA and a DB to provide a lot of MES functionality. Performance, Downtime, recipe, booking production/closing work orders.

Author: brian.mccarver_52117
Content: Hello all. The company I work for is in the beginning stages of multiple POC's for UNS and broker based data comms viability review. I am one of the individuals in the primary group excited and engaged in these efforts. I recently brought up that we should review ISA-95 modeling beyond the basic location and asset type hierarchy so that IT apps/systems could work against a common data model rather than maintaining knowledge about data structure meaning and implementations published from the many different machine and device types in our manufacturing facilities. This seems relevant to me because we have many manufacturing domains where each domain produces a few to many different components and/or product types. Our explicit goal is to provide means for ERP/MES to close the loop on what products/components were made when and where and by whom for traceability and serialization needs in one specific domain. However, the secondary goal is to implement a common architecture or "how" across the company to "quickly" achieve similar traceability and serialization capability in other domains. My suggestion of reviewing ISA-95 modeling to achieve a common data model was met with immediate resistance with specific reasoning provided in a statement saying that, "ISA-95 modeling is meant for use with SAP and we aren't using SAP and we can't have rigid models." I have read through posts here for initial feedback, so to speak, from this community. I am aware of Rhize and Geoff Nunan . I am aware of David Schultz's positive opinion and use of ISA-95 and B2MML. I am also aware of Rick Bullotta's opinions on use of B2MML. I ask the community to weigh in on the statement that "ISA-95 modeling is meant for use with SAP" and other opinions and info you would like to add. I can possibly provide additional info if needed. Thank you.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Short version is that if your applications of choice support B2MML natively, then maybe.  If not, you might end up spending 2X the effort for very little incremental benefit. Focus instead on the real objectives: closed loop (and timely/accurate) updates on what was made and related traceability.  Also consider this data as a critical source of data and context for continuous improvement, with or without AI in the mix.

Author: brian.mccarver_52117
Content: Thank you!

Author: brianpribe
Content:
ISA-95 modeling is for manufacturers who don't understand their operations.

Hope that stirs the pot a little, but the reason we start with S95 is because it provide a good general abstract model that can be well understood by the vast majority of ERP implementations. Is it perfect? Fuck no, but neither are your operations.

Your goal with data-modeling is to represent your business, digitally. S95 gets you 80% of the way there, and you COULD fully model in S95... BUT THATS NOT THE DAMN POINT. We model our data to understand it better, and utilize it. S95 helps with getting a generalized granular view of your data, without going through the tedious task of modeling yourself. Plus, your interpretations of your business will change over time, and so will those models. The questions you should be asking yourself isn't "Is S95 meant for us?", it's "How much do we actually understand?" If your ERP has zero insight, S95. If you have a good amount of integration and understanding, BYO.

Author: brian.mccarver_52117
Content: Thank you for giving the guiding questions. I get your points! Admittedly, I have talked with the internal team currently developing our next gen MES system, but I haven't yet met with the ERP side to get an understanding of their level of understanding of the machine layer, so to speak. It has been on my to do list though. Thanks again!

Author: geoffnunan
Content: There is a significant difference between ISA95 as a messaging model (aka B2MML) and ISA95 as a persistent data model in an integration broker or data hub and isa95 as a Headless MES

Author: slamber12
Content:
Hi Brian - I’ve been on this journey for the last year and happy to share my learnings. It’s a bit hard to type it all but basically I started out trying to use B2MML for our UNS and found it to be too ridgid and verbose for a modern architecture. 

Instead we’ve decided to loosely follow ISA95 object models, we create our own JSON schema based on the available information (and also studying our manufacturing network which has 2 separate ERPs and at least 5 different MES’s just for managing materials at the shop floor which is where most of our SAP<>MES data is going. 

We’ve expanded beyond just level 4 to Level 3 communications and also use ISA95 and ISA88 models batch, alarm and OEE events, it will continue to be the foundation for any system integrated to our UNS - but using our own schemas. 

I’ve studied all parts of ISA95 closely and I think the naysayers have not spent much time reading beyond part 2…honestly can’t blame them it is a difficult read 😆

I really like how this image brings together the standards and how they work together in an integration framework. 

ISA88 is a lot more “sloppy” in that regard, I think it’s due for a major overhaul - the models are almost too “modular” without really giving you a clear indication how you could/should bring them together.

Author: slamber12
Content: But anyways I’ve found a way to make them work, it’s just a lot more decision based rather than following the standard to a T

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Did you find the Technical reference document on integrating ISA95 with ISA88?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
That diagram is the reason most people have a problem with B2MML.
Why would I convert to a common model only to have to convert back again, why not just convert directly to the target. I do understand that it's about re-use, and not building point-to-point integrations, but in this day and age of Data Hubs and persistent brokers, we are rally talking about source -> DataHub -> target.
B2MML is not suitable as the schema of a DataHub, so using B2MML means source -> B2MML -> Datahub -> B2MML -> target which jsut makes no sense to me at all.
The same is true for the Part 7 and Part 6 specs, and don't forget Part 5, 8 and 9.
I get the resistance!
We do it differently.
Source -> Data Hub, event-driven. in what ever is native to the source.
Inside the DataHub we transform the master data and formats to an isa95 based knowledge graph that is fully queryable and persistent.
DataHub -> Target, event-driven or pull, either isa95 or target specific. graphql, rest, mqtt, opc-ua.

The difference is that the logic is all inside the data hub, and there is very little impact on the source or target application, and the data in the datahub is completely queryable and persistent, versioned and standardised.

The UNS approach of building the transformations for each application and publishing json messages to a topic in a broker leaves so much value on the table becuase you can't query the broker.

Author: brian.mccarver_52117
Content: Thank you for your clear, articulate response. I appreciate having the opportunity to learn a bit about how your team is leveraging ISA 95.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I’d actually say the opposite. S88 is far more explicit and widely adopted in a more standardized way.

Author: slamber12
Content: I think there is a section abound it in one of the appendices of the standard, or do you mean one of the separate documents you have to buy to help understand the documents you already bought 🤣

Author: slamber12
Content: What is your data hub? A data lake? We combine a few steps in that diagram but essentially it goes source > global model > exchange broker…from the broker the data is sent to a persistent layer in the cloud. We have an integration layer that subscribes to the broker topics and converts to the target system format/data requirements. This decouples the systems and allows for multiple subscribers to the same global format, a good example is a process order which we need to receive in our LES, MES, and potentially other systems. Each one has its own specific format and we have done some silly things like take an IDOC, convert it to a schema, ship it to an edge MW device where it might be converted again, then the target system might pick it up and do more transformations on it…chasing the paper trail on these legacy implementations is painful

Author: geoffnunan
Content: There is a separate Techncial Reference document ISA-TR-88.95.01 that provides guidance for using ISA88 and ISA95 together and how to handle the overlap

Author: slamber12
Content: Ahhh see I’ve been too cheap to look at the TRs 🙃. Is it worth it? I do recall a brief mention of it in an appendix and I think MESA has some details about it on the BatchML stuff

Author: geoffnunan
Content: The Rhize data hub can be thought of as a persistent broker that contains a full ISA95 data model and store that is queryable and subscribable. The data store is a fully audited, GxP compliant data sore that is ACID compliant. Moderna use Rhize to integrate DeltaV with Syncade and QMS, capturing all the data into the data hub as it is created. The EBR can then be generated directly from the data in the data hub in real-time.

Author: slamber12
Content: That’s very similar to what we’re doing just through a more composable architecture, where it sounds like Rhize is connecting, transforming, and storing data - we do that across multiple applications

Author: slamber12
Content: And apologize I thought data hub was a generic term, didn’t realize you meant Rhize :). do you work for Rhize or just use it?

Author: geoffnunan
Content: I'm the CTO

Author: slamber12
Content: Noted! We found out about Rhize just a hair too late for our POC but it definitely looked interesting and we took some inspiration from you guys - mainly that ISA95 could be used as the integration framework

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
The main thing to keep in mind is that we built the Rhize platform so that it can be the UNS ( The central integration point) but so that you could also build applications directly on it as a headless application backend.
The ISA 95 model standardises the language. each integration translates to ISA95, but then you have a full GraphQL api with subscriptions to be able to query and build new applications directly ontop. You even have an MCP server that has full understanding of the ISA95 entities in the datahub to enable the building of AI Agents that can help out with things like preparing deviation reports for quality deviations. All in the one platform.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: The data model for the datahub is ISA95, but not B2MML. There are some important things that B2MML does not handle that are important when you want to store the data, not just integrate it. The biggest difference is versioning. Keeping track of different versions of definition objects, and the data that was created by them.

Author: slamber12
Content: Yes that’s part of the issue we had with B2MML, it was quickly abandoned lol. Is the data hub on the edge or cloud or hybrid?

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Most companies are putting wherever there other applications are. We have some running on premise at site, some on premise in a data centre, and some in private cloud.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Most of the B2MML implementations I’ve seen also used a lot of custom extensions to the schemas, basically killing interop.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
It might be an unpopular opinion, but interop is a pipe-dream that will never happen.
'Plug and Play' is something that we can't even achieve for electrical sockets so why would we ever think we could achieve it for something as complex as the manufactuing domain model?
The goal is re-use. If I model my manufacturing process, and use the incredibly precise language of ISA95 to model it, I can build on top of that foundation with confidence. I can model discrete, batch, serialized, maybe continuous. I can cover all the use-cases I can think of, and I don't have to design the data model because it already exists.
B2MML tried to solve an impossible problem 30 years ago and understandably failed, but while trying to solve that impossible problem, the contributors defined the independent language of manufacturing. 
30 years ago, the problem was defining data in-flight. the integration between ERP and MOM.
Today, the value is in the language applied to data at rest.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It’s a realistic and pragmatic opinion Geoff!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
PAS-X is very popular in Pharma. It's a pretty sophisticated solution with a lot of interface options. The MSI interface is more of a general messaging system than an API with well-defined methods. There flavors of it for machine builders (MSI OPC UA Methods) and general integrations (MSI Web Services).

Older versions of PAS-X have an Oracle backend and support MSI. Newer versions of PAS-X have a PostgreSQL backend, MSI interface, PAS-X Data Access ("PDA") for analytics/reporting, and the standard API for config and app-level methods.

It seems like most of the install base is still running the older versions. If the data is needed for analytics and reporting, replicating select Oracle database tables to a lake or warehouse using Change Data Capture (CDC) is a common pattern. If desired integrations are transactional (e.g., push recipes to automation, read in data for quality tests), MSI is a common.

Reference project integrating with PAS-X MSI:
https://support.highbyte.com/kb/references/architectures/k%C3%B6rber-pas-x-msi-interface-via-web-services

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
PAS-X is popular, but is old and it suffers from it. 'Open' or 'Edge Driven' it most definitely is not.
Most PAS-X implementations I have come across are not even connected to the controls layer at all and provide an electronic batch record that is purely operator entry.
One global bio-pharma company that I know spent over USD$10M just implementing the Weigh-and-dispense step of their process which took 4 years.
The MSI does enable message based communication, but only between Controls and MES, not between MES and LIMS or MES and ERP.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Can't speak to your experiences, but I've yet to encounter a PAS-X shop without integrations. We might be encountering different demographics.

The most common flavor of MSI is the OPC UA version based off some ISPE working group standard. Many of Körber's machine builder partners in Europe support this. This handles the Controls<->MES scenarios you mentioned. I believe in the MSI module there is a way to configure the routing of messages to different parts of PAS-X. Using this with the web services interfaces for MSI, application integrations with the LIMS and ERP should be possible. Körber positions MSI as a the general purpose transactional interface. Beyond MSI, they seem to be putting a lot of work into their APIs in the newer versions.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I disagree with premise of the question. MES consists of transactions. MQTT is largely a technology to exchange asset/sensor telemetry.

Having MQTT support in an MES is not as useful as it may sound. Modbus register values sent over MQTT are still modbus register values. MES ultimately need manufacturing events (e.g., batch events, state changes, BOM loaded, container depleted). If the MES lacks processing facilities to effectively convert and remediate telemetry into your desired transactions, it's protocol support is of limited value. If it can do this, there is still quite a bit of work. In other words, focus more on "payload" and less on "protocol". Don't select an MES because it does or does not support MQTT. Use an MES that fits your business, manufacturing processes, and how your requirements may evolve. If the MES can't do those things well, adapting protocols will be the least of your troubles.

For example, Sepasoft and Kanoa are built on Ignition. They sit on top of and interpret Ignition tag providers. Ignition tag providers are flexible in terms of being able to bind to MQTT, OPC UA, PLC drivers, etc. But, if these solutions aren't a good fit for your manufacturing processes, the integration benefits don't really matter. The right MES with less interface options is better than the wrong MES with more interface options.

Author: marita.vavoulioti
Content:
Fair, on the distinction even though I would frame MES is more event driven and not transaction driven. I see ERP as transaction driven 
My question or what I am trying to understand is how a compatible component can be in a broader UND architecture or will I need additional components to do adaptation or transformation

Author: marita.vavoulioti
Content: I have the same question as I am trying to figure out the different components of the architecture

Author: marita.vavoulioti

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
HighByte is for engineering industrial data pipelines. Sometimes those pipelines are "south" of L3 and sometimes those are "north" of it. Below L3, this could involve calling an MES endpoint to record production when an OPC tag indicates the end of a cycle or a counter is equal to a standard count. Above L3, this could involve simple replication of MES to a data lake. Or it could be used to construct contextualized data sets that enrich process data (e.g., temp, pressure, position) with MES context (e.g., lot, operator, work order info) for analytics.

With respect to the PAS-X MSI, that's a generic messaging interface and could be applied to many things. The southbound patterns could be anything from writing setpoints or recipes to acquiring data from instrumentation. 

Suppose you're a PAS-X shop and you've standardized on bioreactors from one of Körber's partners. These bioreactors have an onboard OPC UA Server that support the MSI / ISPE integration pattern. This is working well and it really streamlines MES integration. Now, suppose there is a delivery backlog on those bioreactors or your firm just acquired another manufacturer that did not standardize on these bioreactors. You suddenly have a fleet of bioreactors with secondary instrumentation (e.g., cell counters) that only expose their data as obscure text files. How do you make file servers, filled with a ton of text files constantly being created and appended to, fit into your existing integration pattern you intially standardized on? Create an abstraction layer. Build an API. Now, regardless of underlying data sources, the MES can easily fetch instrumentation readings when it needs it. No need to write an RFQ for the machine builder or third-party to build a new interface when they hopefully are available in 15 months. No need to get the already-busy MES team to delay an implementation to support yet another integration pattern. No code or dependencies to maintain. Resilience when requirements change.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Great point. Both are important.

Author: marita.vavoulioti

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
When I started I was really looking at components for my system that would be "UNS native" plug it in and go, and publish events from my devices and systems into my UNS in the semantic hierarchy. But what I found over time that might not be as useful as it sounds, normally from any source I want to add some context into my data as I transmit it to the UNS. So as a simple example, if I have two flow meters , one Modbus and one MQTT , I am probably still going to use some sort of gateway to take that data, structure the payload, and publish it in the correct level in my semantic hierarchy.

so for the Modbus, I typically will publish all the registers into a      Something/Something/something/Something/Device/Raw  and process it out form there, I tend to do the same even with a MQTT device and publish  the data to                                 Something/Something/something/Something/Device2/Raw and process it out from there.

with higher level systems like a MES , CMMS, great if I can easily configure my system to publish the data in context in the payload form that I want, but I would rather have something that can get the data I need and add the context to allow me use whatever solutions is best for me. and having a interface that allow me publish MQTT but is very manual to configure can be more work than just using an API to retrieve the date from the tables and Parse it out and publish to MQTT, 

At some point in Scaling you will need some sort of platform that can collect the date , model it and deliver it to other systems, with a level of structure and governance, and the options available Like HighByte, MaestoHub and Flow software, generally can connect to most things in a better and faster way.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Some MES take a "bottoms up" approach and derive transactions based on incoming signals. Sometimes this is an integration module. Sometimes this works well enough and sometimes it falls short. Some opt to skip it over these integration and build out their own integrates to interface with the core APIs. Other MES don't have an integration layer and just have core APIs.

Some orgs build their MES. This can go either way. This is more flexible. Often, it is fairly coupled to the underlying database schema. Many automotive OEMs, for example, program their PLCs to "dump" a data structure at the end of each cycle or widget produced to a database.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Could you clarify something on Flow? I don't have hands on experience with it.

My understand is that Flow is kind of like a multi-system "event frames". It creates time-bound events (based on schedules/rules) against telemetry and historian data and those get persisted in its own embedded SQL database for visualization, analysis, reporting, etc within the app. Beyond this, there is an option of providing these events to external reporting databases or BI tools.

I didn't get the impression that it was a pipelining solution. I've never heard of someone using it as middleware to egress transactions and feed apps. I thought its egress was analytics to storage or visualization. For example, aggregate queries on a historized telemetry (e.g., tank level by hour, shift, day, week).

Am I understanding it right?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I tend to enforce data governance mostly by procedure, but I’ve started to add some technical controls as well, such as:
      Checking the payload structure before publishing (to make sure messages conform to schema).
      Restricting nodes to publish only to specific topics (to prevent topic sprawl).

Whether you need formal Master Data Management (MDM) controls really depends on scale:
     For a POC with a few lines, you can usually manage with procedures and light validation.
     For multi-plant deployments, stronger enforcement (via tools like HighByte, Litmus, or MaestroHub) is probably necessary.

And I work on small POC projects typically 

On the edge side (PLC and devices), you’re always transmitting a lot of data, and even in a plant network you’ll see micro outages that lead to data loss.
If you need to capture critical values at the PLC (e.g., 100% of test results on a high-speed line), this can be a problem.

Over the years I’ve used several approaches:
PLC-based FIFO buffers of up to 100 records that stop the process if they fill (guaranteeing no loss, but complex to implement).
In other cases, simply accepting the loss when connections drop (lower risk use cases).

Today my preferred approach is:
     Use edge devices that can buffer locally, or  Add a small DIN-rail IoT device dedicated to buffering. ( I love adding Din Rail Edge computer)
    And if you’re going Edge → Cloud, then some sort of buffering is almost always needed.
    HiveMQ Edge to HiveMQ Cloud works well here (with built-in store-and-forward).
    A simpler alternative of Node-RED with a Postgres table for local persistence and replay can work really well

Content:
There is no hard right or wrong answer very often, "It Depends" is the correct answer most of the time, 

and I find what it depends on most often, is 
    What Scale are we talking about
     Where are you are the journey.

and what might be right today won't be right in a few years, and what will br right in a few years would woudl be wrong for today

Author: jeff_flow
Content:
Happy to add a bit of context here. @js you are correct in your positioning of Flow Information Platform Models and the Data Engine. Also part of this suite of tools is the Integration Engine which will push these now stored events and aggregated values to other data consumers and allow you the flexibility to define the namespace and payload in doing so. This includes MQTT brokers, Kafka streams, cloud platforms, other SQL dbs, etc. The REST API can be used to query all stored events and aggregated values as well as query the databases and systems Flow Models are connected to, returing the raw data from historians or SQL dbs.

When we release Timebase Atlas later this year, Flow as well as other applications will be able to subscribe to Timebase Atlas models and get values on change (event driven architecture).
